description: This course introduces viewers to Microsoft Transact-SQL, the language used to input and retrieve data from Microsoft SQL servers. The series is designed for viewers of all experience levels as it walks through running your very first query all the way through crafting advanced server-side stored procedures.
descriptionMD: This course introduces viewers to Microsoft Transact-SQL, the language used to input and retrieve data from Microsoft SQL servers. The series is designed for viewers of all experience levels as it walks through running your very first query all the way through crafting advanced server-side stored procedures.
name: Microsoft SQL Server 2016: Querying Data with Transact-SQL - 70-761
subtitle: Microsoft SQL Server 2016

episodes.description: This course introduces viewers to Microsoft Transact-SQL, the language used to input and retrieve data from Microsoft SQL servers. The series is designed for viewers of all experience levels as it walks through running your very first query all the way through crafting advanced server-side stored procedures.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.386
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.386 --> 00:00:07.822
[SOUND] Hello, thank you for
choosing ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.822 --> 00:00:13.240
We're talking about Querying Data
with Transact-SQL, with Don Pezet.

4
00:00:13.240 --> 00:00:15.580
Don, tell us about Transact-SQL.

5
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:16.830
So Transact-SQL,

6
00:00:16.830 --> 00:00:20.810
it's actually an abbreviation for
Transact Structured Query Language.

7
00:00:20.810 --> 00:00:23.400
It is a language that we
use to talk to databases.

8
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:25.940
So if you have a relational database,

9
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:27.480
there's a ton of great
information in there.

10
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:29.190
You have to be able to get it out.

11
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:32.330
And one of the most common ways
to do that is through SQL, or

12
00:00:32.330 --> 00:00:33.890
the Structured Query Language.

13
00:00:33.890 --> 00:00:38.740
Well, Transact-SQL is Microsoft's
implementation of SQL.

14
00:00:38.740 --> 00:00:40.750
And it's what they use on
their server products.

15
00:00:40.750 --> 00:00:45.662
So if you're using Microsoft SQL Server,
well, really, all the way back, or a long

16
00:00:45.662 --> 00:00:48.190
time, since their earliest versions of SQL
Server, but all the way to the newer ones

17
00:00:48.190 --> 00:00:50.935
like 2016, which is what we're
gonna be using here in this show.

18
00:00:50.935 --> 00:00:55.580
Transact-SQL is how you're going to
talk to that server, so in this series,

19
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:57.360
that's one of the things that
we're going to learn is,

20
00:00:57.360 --> 00:01:01.110
if I've got a Microsoft SQL Server 2016,
How do I talk to it?

21
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:04.760
Now the cool part is that most
of this is standards based, so

22
00:01:04.760 --> 00:01:10.630
what you learn in this series can apply
to SQL 2014, SQL 2012, SQL 2000, SQL 6.

23
00:01:10.630 --> 00:01:12.470
I mean, it just goes way, way back.

24
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:16.290
These languages, they haven't changed
all that much in all these years.

25
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:19.337
Now, the way the databases optimized
their performance, the way they work.

26
00:01:19.337 --> 00:01:22.415
The volumes of data that they can handle,
have gotten much larger and

27
00:01:22.415 --> 00:01:23.840
evolved quite a bit.

28
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:26.040
But by having a standard language,

29
00:01:26.040 --> 00:01:28.020
it gives us the ability
to do something awesome.

30
00:01:28.020 --> 00:01:32.130
Which is to learn how to talk to the
database service in a consistent manner.

31
00:01:32.130 --> 00:01:34.210
And that's what this course is all about.

32
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:36.037
>> You already got me excited
about the whole thing, but

33
00:01:36.037 --> 00:01:37.850
who is this show targeted towards?

34
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:39.010
>> All right, well,

35
00:01:39.010 --> 00:01:44.110
it's really targeted to anybody who
needs to get data out of the database.

36
00:01:44.110 --> 00:01:46.218
Now, I could kinda trim
that down a little bit,

37
00:01:46.218 --> 00:01:48.410
like if you don't really
care about database.

38
00:01:48.410 --> 00:01:52.213
You just want the data, there's plenty of
third party graphic utilities you can use.

39
00:01:52.213 --> 00:01:55.395
There's things like Microsoft Access
that gives you a little Wizard that

40
00:01:55.395 --> 00:01:58.250
you can walk through, but
if you're trying to go to scale.

41
00:01:58.250 --> 00:02:01.390
If you're trying to be able to handle
any kind of high volume transactions.

42
00:02:01.390 --> 00:02:05.510
Those hand holding type programs,
they don't work.

43
00:02:05.510 --> 00:02:08.990
We actually have to get in and
talk to the database server.

44
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:12.410
Be able to get that information and
put information in, and

45
00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:13.960
that's where SQL comes in.

46
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:17.550
So if your job responsibility involves
that, this is what you want to learn.

47
00:02:17.550 --> 00:02:20.170
Now what types of jobs would do that,
developers.

48
00:02:20.170 --> 00:02:23.740
Developers often times have to store data
for their applications in a database.

49
00:02:23.740 --> 00:02:25.230
And be able to get the data back out for

50
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:28.570
their application uses,
so they need to know SQL.

51
00:02:28.570 --> 00:02:33.410
We also have DevOps, people that
are standing up their own database server,

52
00:02:33.410 --> 00:02:34.070
right?

53
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:36.000
They still need to be able to talk to it.

54
00:02:36.000 --> 00:02:37.710
We also have system administrators.

55
00:02:37.710 --> 00:02:39.857
If you're a system administrator and
you're responsible for

56
00:02:39.857 --> 00:02:40.755
standing up a SQL Server.

57
00:02:40.755 --> 00:02:43.103
Well, some people just have
to install the server and

58
00:02:43.103 --> 00:02:45.910
then they turn it over to the dev team and
that's it.

59
00:02:45.910 --> 00:02:48.730
But more often than not,
we're gonna need to be able to monitor and

60
00:02:48.730 --> 00:02:49.870
maintain that database.

61
00:02:49.870 --> 00:02:52.720
And the way we do that is
by querying against it.

62
00:02:52.720 --> 00:02:54.470
Sending it commands,
seeing how it responds,

63
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:56.220
that's how we know it's up and active.

64
00:02:56.220 --> 00:02:58.270
Just because the server's powered
on doesn't mean it's working.

65
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:01.900
We need to know,
can I actually get data out of it?

66
00:03:01.900 --> 00:03:06.080
So if you fall into any of those roles,
developer, DevOps, system administrator.

67
00:03:06.080 --> 00:03:09.930
Or just somebody who wants to learn
more about the way the databases work.

68
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.612
Learning SQL is a great way to find
out how to talk to talk to it.

69
00:03:13.612 --> 00:03:15.103
And learning Transact-SQL,

70
00:03:15.103 --> 00:03:18.185
is a great way to learn how to
talk to Microsoft's SQL Servers.

71
00:03:18.185 --> 00:03:21.070
>> Wow, that sounds fantastic, is there
a certification available for the show?

72
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:25.260
>> Absolutely this is actually
the first step in becoming like

73
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:27.100
a Microsoft Certified SQL Engineer.

74
00:03:27.100 --> 00:03:30.360
So the first certification that we
start with is called the MCSA, and

75
00:03:30.360 --> 00:03:32.470
I've got Microsoft's page pulled up here.

76
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:35.930
The MCSA for SQL Server 2016,
if you look at it.

77
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:39.630
The very first course in that journey
is right here, course number one.

78
00:03:39.630 --> 00:03:44.860
It's exam 70-761, and
that's what our show is being based on.

79
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:48.120
So, in this show we're going to cover
each of the topics that are a part of

80
00:03:48.120 --> 00:03:49.150
that exam.

81
00:03:49.150 --> 00:03:52.080
So that we can learn what we
need to know to go and pass it.

82
00:03:52.080 --> 00:03:54.986
Now, by itself, that's not enough, but

83
00:03:54.986 --> 00:03:59.763
if you complete the next course or
next exam, the 70-762 exam.

84
00:03:59.763 --> 00:04:05.620
When you pas both of those,
you get your MCSA in SQL Server 2016.

85
00:04:05.620 --> 00:04:08.860
And from there you can even move on and
there's an MCSE that you can get.

86
00:04:08.860 --> 00:04:10.810
And there's several specializations for

87
00:04:10.810 --> 00:04:13.290
big data and cloud databases,
and all of that.

88
00:04:13.290 --> 00:04:17.764
But they all start right here
with this one, with this show,

89
00:04:17.764 --> 00:04:21.560
70-761, which is for SQL Server 2016.

90
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:24.510
Be aware that there are other ones for
the previous versions,

91
00:04:24.510 --> 00:04:26.445
like SQL Server 2012 and 2014.

92
00:04:26.445 --> 00:04:31.021
They shared a different exam, 70-741,
if that's the one you're looking for.

93
00:04:31.021 --> 00:04:32.675
Well, we have a whole
separate show film for

94
00:04:32.675 --> 00:04:34.650
that because there's
a different user interface.

95
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:38.130
Things look different, so
we filmed it specifically for that.

96
00:04:38.130 --> 00:04:39.830
Here though, things look different enough,

97
00:04:39.830 --> 00:04:42.590
that we actually got the dedicated
course specifically for it.

98
00:04:42.590 --> 00:04:44.471
And that's exactly what
we're gonna be learning.

99
00:04:44.471 --> 00:04:48.130
>> A good IT pro is always learning, and
what topics are covered in this show?

100
00:04:48.130 --> 00:04:51.450
Alright, well, it really all starts kinda,
from a beginner's perspective.

101
00:04:51.450 --> 00:04:55.840
So what is Transact-SQL, what does it
look like, how do I type in the commands?

102
00:04:55.840 --> 00:04:58.280
And then,
once I know how to input commands,

103
00:04:58.280 --> 00:05:01.190
what are the commands to even use?

104
00:05:01.190 --> 00:05:04.043
And if we drill into that exam,
let me pull it up here.

105
00:05:04.043 --> 00:05:06.104
So I'm going to pull up
that 70-761 exam and

106
00:05:06.104 --> 00:05:08.590
I'll pull up the details
here from Microsoft.

107
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:10.740
They basically divide
things into three areas,

108
00:05:10.740 --> 00:05:13.640
now in the show we divided
it up into a lot more areas.

109
00:05:13.640 --> 00:05:16.460
Because this is, it's a lot to take
in just in three chunks, right?

110
00:05:16.460 --> 00:05:19.900
So I think we actually divide it into,
I can't remember, like 10 or

111
00:05:19.900 --> 00:05:21.080
11 different areas.

112
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:22.030
But when you look inside,

113
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:24.340
first off we start with Managing
data with Transact-SQL.

114
00:05:24.340 --> 00:05:26.850
Notice that that's almost half the exam.

115
00:05:26.850 --> 00:05:30.210
A large part of the exam is based,
just on managing that data.

116
00:05:30.210 --> 00:05:32.320
Actually interacting
with the database server,

117
00:05:32.320 --> 00:05:34.790
what Transact SQL is all about, right?

118
00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:38.120
And if you break that apart you'll see
it's things like using SELECT queries.

119
00:05:38.120 --> 00:05:40.414
Which are the most
common types of queries,

120
00:05:40.414 --> 00:05:43.339
that's how we request
information from the database.

121
00:05:43.339 --> 00:05:46.108
How we combine data between
tables using joins,

122
00:05:46.108 --> 00:05:48.610
how we aggregate data using functions.

123
00:05:48.610 --> 00:05:51.460
That's all interacting with the database.

124
00:05:51.460 --> 00:05:55.900
Then we get into doing advanced queries,
these are queries that not everybody uses.

125
00:05:55.900 --> 00:05:59.080
The ones up here in the first section,
everybody uses these.

126
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:01.710
You use these everyday,
just going to a website,

127
00:06:01.710 --> 00:06:03.885
coming to our website and
clicking on the course library.

128
00:06:03.885 --> 00:06:05.370
You're running these queries
in the background and

129
00:06:05.370 --> 00:06:06.210
you don't even know it, right?

130
00:06:06.210 --> 00:06:10.060
These happen everyday, the advance
queries aren't in every day things.

131
00:06:10.060 --> 00:06:11.820
These are more like an edge case or

132
00:06:11.820 --> 00:06:15.660
a corner case, where you can actually
get some great benefits by using these.

133
00:06:15.660 --> 00:06:18.510
Doing things like grouping sets,
and pivots, and unpivots.

134
00:06:18.510 --> 00:06:22.168
So you can change the data that you're
getting back from the database servers.

135
00:06:22.168 --> 00:06:24.820
So we'll get a chance to see that, that
makes up a smaller portion of the exam.

136
00:06:24.820 --> 00:06:28.070
And then the smallest portion
is right down here at the end,

137
00:06:28.070 --> 00:06:31.350
programming databases
by using Transact SQL.

138
00:06:31.350 --> 00:06:34.590
If you're given access to a SQL Server,
it has nothing on it.

139
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:38.900
It doesn't have a database, has no tables,
how do you get that set up?

140
00:06:38.900 --> 00:06:41.410
So we focus on the infrastructure side,
how do I create the database?

141
00:06:41.410 --> 00:06:44.280
How do I create the tables,
how do I deal with data types.

142
00:06:44.280 --> 00:06:47.150
And actually work with that information,
inside of those tables?

143
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:51.350
Until we run through that process of being
able to maintain the integrity of our data

144
00:06:51.350 --> 00:06:52.340
on the server.

145
00:06:52.340 --> 00:06:55.190
It's a great way to see some of
the neat tools that are a part

146
00:06:55.190 --> 00:06:56.220
of Microsoft SQL Server.

147
00:06:56.220 --> 00:06:58.875
That set it apart from other
competitors that are out there.

148
00:06:58.875 --> 00:07:00.749
So that's kind of a rundown of it,

149
00:07:00.749 --> 00:07:04.703
now do be aware that this last section
here where programing databases.

150
00:07:04.703 --> 00:07:07.830
It's not as super-crazy in depth,
that if you're not a developer,

151
00:07:07.830 --> 00:07:08.890
don't worry, right?

152
00:07:08.890 --> 00:07:11.230
It's something that everybody can tackle.

153
00:07:11.230 --> 00:07:15.073
There's actually another course,
if we look down the little list here.

154
00:07:15.073 --> 00:07:18.130
You'll see this,
Provisioning SQL Databases.

155
00:07:18.130 --> 00:07:22.730
And that goes far more in-depth,
into all the different case scenarios for

156
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:23.670
deploying a database.

157
00:07:23.670 --> 00:07:26.570
Like doing it in the cloud or
locally or with replication, and

158
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:28.300
all these other crazy solutions.

159
00:07:28.300 --> 00:07:30.970
And there is another course
that's out there, this one.

160
00:07:30.970 --> 00:07:34.970
Developing SQL Data Models, and
Implementing a SQL Data Warehouse.

161
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:40.474
Those two as well go far more in-depth,
in how to get things set up.

162
00:07:40.474 --> 00:07:43.400
So here in 70-761 we're really
focusing on the bare minimum.

163
00:07:43.400 --> 00:07:45.724
What's the minimum it takes to
get a database up and running?

164
00:07:45.724 --> 00:07:48.830
And to get a table in place and
to be able to share some data with it?

165
00:07:48.830 --> 00:07:51.200
But those are the topics that we're
gonna be covering as we move the course.

166
00:07:51.200 --> 00:07:54.610
So by the time we're done, you'll be
able to complete each of these tasks.

167
00:07:54.610 --> 00:07:57.593
>> Fantastic, well, if this sounds like
something you'd be interested in, and

168
00:07:57.593 --> 00:07:58.134
it should be.

169
00:07:58.134 --> 00:08:01.750
Then Querying Data with
Transact-SQL is for you.

170
00:08:01.750 --> 00:08:05.502
So make sure you catch every single
episode, and thanks for watching ITProTV.

171
00:08:05.502 --> 00:08:10.513
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don provides the viewers with background on Transact-SQL and the differences between it and the ANSI standard Structured Query Language (SQL). He also introduces the three categories of T-SQL statements that will be explored throughout the remainder of the series.
episodes.title: Introduction to Transact-SQL
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:06.055
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host,

2
00:00:06.055 --> 00:00:10.728
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

3
00:00:10.728 --> 00:00:13.980
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPro TV.

4
00:00:13.980 --> 00:00:16.850
Empowering the world
who engage in learning.

5
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:17.853
I'm your host Zack Memos.

6
00:00:17.853 --> 00:00:22.862
As we move into querying data with
Transact-SQL and this episode it's

7
00:00:22.862 --> 00:00:28.130
introduction to Transact-SQL and
we've ask Don Pezet to show us the way.

8
00:00:28.130 --> 00:00:30.852
Because he is such a nice fellow
he thought he'd drop in and

9
00:00:30.852 --> 00:00:31.750
help us out there.

10
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:32.380
Hey Don, how are you doing?

11
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:33.712
>> I am doing great Zack.

12
00:00:33.712 --> 00:00:36.336
Ready to dive into the world
of Transact-SQL and

13
00:00:36.336 --> 00:00:40.370
then get a chance to see a little bit
about how we talk to databases, right.

14
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:44.460
This is the language we are gonna be
using throughout this whole series, so

15
00:00:44.460 --> 00:00:45.689
we are gonna learn a lot of the ins and

16
00:00:45.689 --> 00:00:48.280
outs, the various commands that we
can use, and how we do that talk.

17
00:00:48.280 --> 00:00:51.966
But before we get that far, I thought it
would be a good idea to do an introduction

18
00:00:51.966 --> 00:00:54.617
show, to just talk about why
we even have this langauge?

19
00:00:54.617 --> 00:00:55.442
Where it came from?

20
00:00:55.442 --> 00:00:58.192
And what it looks like before
we start diving in all the crazy

21
00:00:58.192 --> 00:00:59.789
commands that make up the langauge.

22
00:00:59.789 --> 00:01:02.430
>> And so, first of all,
first and foremost, what is SQL?

23
00:01:02.430 --> 00:01:04.700
All right, so what is SQL?

24
00:01:04.700 --> 00:01:07.250
It's somewhat of a loaded question, right.

25
00:01:07.250 --> 00:01:10.290
And some of you out there in TV
land right now might be saying,

26
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:11.720
why is Zach saying SQL?

27
00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:13.152
It's S-Q-L, right?

28
00:01:13.152 --> 00:01:16.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's this whole debate over

29
00:01:16.870 --> 00:01:19.590
which one is the right pronunciation and
fortunately in the Microsoft world we

30
00:01:19.590 --> 00:01:21.900
don't really have to worry about it,
you can say it either way.

31
00:01:21.900 --> 00:01:27.160
In the Unix world they get really picky
about it but it all goes back to history.

32
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:30.080
A long time ago, we had databases,

33
00:01:30.080 --> 00:01:31.980
but they weren't nearly as
important as they are today.

34
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:35.100
Today, databases make up a part
of everything that we do.

35
00:01:35.100 --> 00:01:36.220
When you visit a website,

36
00:01:36.220 --> 00:01:39.300
the odds are a lot of its data is
being rendered from a database.

37
00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:42.060
A lot of the information that we
work with is coming from a database.

38
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:47.060
They make things possible and
they recognize very early on that, man,

39
00:01:47.060 --> 00:01:48.850
these databases are so important.

40
00:01:48.850 --> 00:01:53.280
And so many different people are coming
up with database technologies out there.

41
00:01:53.280 --> 00:01:55.000
Like IBM had their Db2.

42
00:01:55.000 --> 00:01:55.730
You had Delphi.

43
00:01:55.730 --> 00:01:57.440
You had Oracle's databases.

44
00:01:57.440 --> 00:02:00.610
You had, just a ton of various other ones.

45
00:02:00.610 --> 00:02:03.880
Microsoft SQL is actually one of their
oldest products but a lot of people don't

46
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:07.990
realize that it's been out for a long,
long time since the early 80s.

47
00:02:07.990 --> 00:02:11.040
So these technologies,
they're all different.

48
00:02:11.040 --> 00:02:14.210
And they said man if I'm a developer,
I'm a programmer, and

49
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:17.760
I wanna reach into a database and
get data out of it.

50
00:02:17.760 --> 00:02:21.230
If they are all different, now it have
different ways to talk to every one.

51
00:02:21.230 --> 00:02:27.060
Would it be nice if we have one way to
reach out and talk to those databases.

52
00:02:27.060 --> 00:02:29.380
The databases can be different,
they can be separate softwares but

53
00:02:29.380 --> 00:02:31.945
if we have one way to talk to them it
will be easier to know what to expect and

54
00:02:31.945 --> 00:02:37.030
that's where this all came from,
where SQL, came from.

55
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:42.020
Now in the original days, it actually
was called Sequel, the word, right.

56
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:43.880
And that's because what it stood for

57
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:48.895
was the Structured English Query Language,
all right?

58
00:02:48.895 --> 00:02:53.275
And so they abbreviated it as S-E-Q-U-E-L,
however you spell sequel.

59
00:02:53.275 --> 00:02:56.325
So [LAUGH] that's why they called it SQL,
right?

60
00:02:56.325 --> 00:02:59.195
But it's actually,
there were two problems with the name.

61
00:02:59.195 --> 00:03:02.745
One problem is to said English in it and
nowadays,

62
00:03:02.745 --> 00:03:04.865
we support a lot more
language than just English.

63
00:03:04.865 --> 00:03:08.360
The commands are in English, but
the data we move isn't and so,

64
00:03:08.360 --> 00:03:10.860
they'd decided to let's
just drop English apart.

65
00:03:10.860 --> 00:03:15.910
The other problem was another company
had a copyright on that name SQL and

66
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:18.050
handling data,
something about airline data.

67
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:21.250
And so, there was a copyright dispute and
they've said, you know what, forget it,

68
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:24.440
we'll just call SQL,
Structured Query Language.

69
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:27.220
It's a language that we can
use to talk to a database or

70
00:03:27.220 --> 00:03:31.330
query a database in a structure
that follows a certain format.

71
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:35.760
It is consistent across multiple
vendors and that's really the key,

72
00:03:35.760 --> 00:03:36.520
the secret here.

73
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:41.378
The secret sauce behind SQL and why it's
so successful is that pretty much every

74
00:03:41.378 --> 00:03:45.130
relational database that's
out there supports SQL.

75
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:50.000
So Microsoft SQL does,
Oracles database their 10i and so

76
00:03:50.000 --> 00:03:52.160
on, those databases all support it.

77
00:03:52.160 --> 00:03:58.700
You've post SQL, MySQL,
Maria DB, all of those use SQL.

78
00:03:58.700 --> 00:04:02.530
You can write the same query and
have it run across all of them,

79
00:04:02.530 --> 00:04:04.750
which is really, really nice.

80
00:04:04.750 --> 00:04:07.570
It let's you pick the database
product that's right for you.

81
00:04:07.570 --> 00:04:08.900
Right for your solution.

82
00:04:08.900 --> 00:04:10.610
Each one has different bells and
whistles, right.

83
00:04:10.610 --> 00:04:14.270
Microsoft SQL has a ton of
really cool bells and whistles.

84
00:04:14.270 --> 00:04:16.010
Maria DB is free.

85
00:04:16.010 --> 00:04:18.340
Sometimes free is better
than featureful right?

86
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:22.630
So you make that choice, but the language
you use to talk to it is the same and

87
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:27.420
that's really part of the power here,
and SQL is now an ISO standard right.

88
00:04:27.420 --> 00:04:30.650
So it's an industry standard that
anybody can use and follow and so

89
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:32.440
a lot of people do.

90
00:04:32.440 --> 00:04:36.610
Now as far as the terminology where
I calling it sequel versus SQL.

91
00:04:36.610 --> 00:04:39.920
Even though there was that whole
copyright mess and they changed to SQL,

92
00:04:39.920 --> 00:04:44.230
in the Microsoft world, they still
call their product Microsoft Sequel.

93
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:48.840
So you'll hear me say Sequel through most

94
00:04:48.840 --> 00:04:54.590
in the Unix world, where they're all very

95
00:04:54.590 --> 00:04:57.160
whatever the slogan of
the Open Source Movement.

96
00:04:57.160 --> 00:05:00.825
They always make sure to say SQL, because
they don't wanna end up in any kind of

00:05:00.825 --> 00:05:03.790
copyright dispute or
proprietary or whatever.

00:05:03.790 --> 00:05:07.090
So when you're operating in those spaces,

99
00:05:07.090 --> 00:05:12.010
like it's SQL but in the Microsoft
world we're allowed to say sequel,

100
00:05:12.010 --> 00:05:13.970
that's what we do oftentimes.

105
00:05:25.480 --> 00:05:27.720
>> Well SQL is a standard, right?

SQL is a standard, an ISO standard, and
it's got a large set of commands but

00:05:32.460 --> 00:05:35.360

00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:38.150
A lot of bells and whistles,

00:05:38.150 --> 00:05:40.580
Well SQL doesn't account for

00:05:40.580 --> 00:05:44.750
that because Microsoft might have

00:05:44.750 --> 00:05:47.750
So they're not gonna make those commands

support that feature anyway right?

00:05:49.310 --> 00:05:50.730
It's a proprietary feature,

so what Microsoft had to do is they

Transact-SQL is Microsoft's

going to talk about especially later

00:06:39.520 --> 00:06:43.560

We are learning about

Now, the difference is a lot of

What, what did I type the first time?

So that is Transact-SQL, right there and

And I get the same thing, it pulls the

I get that number back and it works,

00:09:35.300 --> 00:09:38.890
it's a difference between trans SQL and

00:09:38.890 --> 00:09:44.630
Now remember what I said earlier, anything

00:09:44.630 --> 00:09:48.090
So, if I wrote it that way I

Especially if you intend to work with

you can throw caution to the wind and

Their way is oftentimes easier and

But, you'll find that, for me, I usually

If you learn it the SQL way, you don't

00:10:49.080 --> 00:10:52.860
What we'll find as the series go on and

00:10:52.860 --> 00:10:55.792

00:11:02.370 --> 00:11:03.840
>> So because I'm a common man,

00:11:03.840 --> 00:11:07.240
what are some of the common

00:11:07.240 --> 00:11:09.690
>> All right, so
we've got a lot of commands.

00:11:09.690 --> 00:11:11.070
What I've just showed you here.

00:11:11.070 --> 00:11:14.670
The command is actually the very first
word that I did Select, all right?

00:11:14.670 --> 00:11:18.290
I'm telling I'm telling that I wanna

00:11:18.290 --> 00:11:22.910
The easiest way to read data from the
database and you'll find that select is

00:11:22.910 --> 00:11:26.290
probably the most commonly used
command in your environment.

215
00:11:26.290 --> 00:11:29.334
There's certainly cases that
do things differently but

216
00:11:29.334 --> 00:11:31.824
most people are reading data

00:11:31.824 --> 00:11:36.025
So that's what select does, but there's
a lot of there's a lot of other commands.

00:11:36.025 --> 00:11:39.488
Some of the other things you see

00:11:39.488 --> 00:11:42.570
where, those aren't commands in and

00:11:42.570 --> 00:11:45.410
Those are modifiers to the SELECT command.

00:11:45.410 --> 00:11:47.840
We're telling the SELECT

222
00:11:47.840 --> 00:11:51.760
right, but they're not commands in and
of themselves, right?

223
00:11:51.760 --> 00:11:53.570
Where doesn't work by itself.

00:11:53.570 --> 00:11:56.750
It has to be used as part of

00:11:56.750 --> 00:12:00.540

00:12:00.540 --> 00:12:05.740
And as we talk to the database we will

227
00:12:05.740 --> 00:12:09.990
Now all the commands are divided
up into three categories.

228
00:12:09.990 --> 00:12:12.000
These three categories
right here all right?

229
00:12:12.000 --> 00:12:15.900
There's the data manipulation
language which is how we

230
00:12:15.900 --> 00:12:19.170
reach into the database and
read and write data.

231
00:12:19.170 --> 00:12:23.270
The select command that I just ran,
that's a example of data manipulation.

232
00:12:23.270 --> 00:12:26.020
I didn't actually manipulate data,
I just retrieved it.

233
00:12:26.020 --> 00:12:27.920
Although you could say that's
a way of manipulating it,

234
00:12:27.920 --> 00:12:29.850
your getting it out of the data.

235
00:12:29.850 --> 00:12:30.380
So DML or

236
00:12:30.380 --> 00:12:34.990
the Data Manipulation Language is how we
work with the data inside the database.

237
00:12:36.880 --> 00:12:41.980
DDL, the Data Definition Language, is how
we actually work with the database itself.

238
00:12:41.980 --> 00:12:43.620
How do I make a database?

239
00:12:43.620 --> 00:12:45.090
How do I make a table?

240
00:12:45.090 --> 00:12:49.750
How do I define what kind of data
is allowed to be in the database?

241
00:12:49.750 --> 00:12:52.460
That kind of stuff is
Data Definition Language.

242
00:12:52.460 --> 00:12:55.360
So, think of that as more
of a construction worker.

243
00:12:55.360 --> 00:12:56.420
I'm gonna build the building.

244
00:12:56.420 --> 00:12:58.990
I don't know what's going in the building,
but I'm gonna build the building.

245
00:12:58.990 --> 00:13:02.660
That's what DDL does and meanwhile,
Data Manipulation Langauge is how we fill

246
00:13:02.660 --> 00:13:05.220
the building with the people
that are doing the job.

247
00:13:05.220 --> 00:13:08.960
Now the last one is DCL,
Data Control Language and

248
00:13:08.960 --> 00:13:12.870
Data Control Language is
how we secure the servers.

249
00:13:12.870 --> 00:13:15.350
How we manage permissions,
and things of that nature.

250
00:13:15.350 --> 00:13:20.010
In this series, we're probably not
gonna cover any DCL commands, but

251
00:13:20.010 --> 00:13:22.270
I want you to be aware that
that is the third language.

00:13:22.270 --> 00:13:26.660
If you go on to do,
like this is the 70-761 course,

00:13:26.660 --> 00:13:31.240
if you go on to do 70-762, or
three, five, you know those guys.

00:13:31.240 --> 00:13:33.520
Actually I don't think there is a three,

00:13:33.520 --> 00:13:37.210
[LAUGH] If you go and do those you'll see
a lot of DCL in them cuz you gotta sign

00:13:37.210 --> 00:13:40.740
permissions, right, in this one we were
more focused in working with the data, so

257
00:13:40.740 --> 00:13:44.120
we're gonna be dealing mostly with
data manipulation language and

258
00:13:44.120 --> 00:13:48.350
we'll do a little bit of DDL,
the data definition language, right.

259
00:13:48.350 --> 00:13:51.920
Though inside of them like data
manipulation there four common commands

260
00:13:51.920 --> 00:13:56.610
that we are gonna use in this series
are select, which is how we read data.

261
00:13:56.610 --> 00:14:00.060
Insert that's how we add new data.

262
00:14:00.060 --> 00:14:03.680
Update, that's how we
change existing data and

263
00:14:03.680 --> 00:14:07.610
delete, that how we remove data, and
get it out of the database, right?

264
00:14:07.610 --> 00:14:13.860
Those four commands make up the bulk
of what every database does every day.

265
00:14:13.860 --> 00:14:18.120
Remember I said that SELECT is the one
that you're really going to use the most?

266
00:14:18.120 --> 00:14:20.380
Well, if we group all
four of these together,

00:14:20.380 --> 00:14:26.190
it's like 99.9% of the queries that are

268
00:14:26.190 --> 00:14:29.670
These are what we do as we add data and
remove it.

269
00:14:29.670 --> 00:14:31.740
You don't build a database everyday but

270
00:14:31.740 --> 00:14:35.230
you use the data in it every day
possibly every second, right.

271
00:14:35.230 --> 00:14:39.403
If you're Amazon.com and you've got a huge
product database people are searching

272
00:14:39.403 --> 00:14:41.670
your database for products all the time.

273
00:14:41.670 --> 00:14:45.880
They're doing selects to find their
product and when they want to go and

274
00:14:45.880 --> 00:14:47.410
buy, they are creating an order.

275
00:14:47.410 --> 00:14:50.960
They're inserting an order and
when they change order details or

276
00:14:50.960 --> 00:14:52.920
credit card information, they're updating.

277
00:14:52.920 --> 00:14:57.530
Updating that information and, at some
point, we decide we've got old orders we

278
00:14:57.530 --> 00:15:00.010
don't need to save anymore and
we delete them and we get them out.

279
00:15:00.010 --> 00:15:03.060
That's regular, routine operations
that most databases have.

280
00:15:04.060 --> 00:15:05.560
DDL's less common, right?

281
00:15:05.560 --> 00:15:07.500
That's the one where we're
building a database.

282
00:15:07.500 --> 00:15:09.090
I create a database.

283
00:15:09.090 --> 00:15:10.840
I create a table.

284
00:15:10.840 --> 00:15:14.310
I create a data type inside of that table.

285
00:15:14.310 --> 00:15:14.860
I'm building.

286
00:15:15.960 --> 00:15:18.340
I alter when I want to change something.

287
00:15:18.340 --> 00:15:21.880
I change the table to add a new column or
something of that nature, right?

288
00:15:21.880 --> 00:15:25.670
We use the alter command for that and
then delete comes back, because instead of

289
00:15:25.670 --> 00:15:28.610
deleting data from a table,
now I might be deleting a table itself.

290
00:15:28.610 --> 00:15:30.350
Or deleting the database, right?

291
00:15:30.350 --> 00:15:32.420
The DELETE command does that.

292
00:15:32.420 --> 00:15:33.890
Actually you don't delete a database,

293
00:15:33.890 --> 00:15:36.510
there's another command I didn't put
on here called DROP, which would drop

294
00:15:36.510 --> 00:15:41.340
the database, but DELETE is how we
would delete a table, for example.

295
00:15:41.340 --> 00:15:44.580
And then lastly we get the data control
language, which again, I said we're not

296
00:15:44.580 --> 00:15:49.120
going to tackle much here in this show but
you've got GRANT, REVOKE, and DENY.

297
00:15:49.120 --> 00:15:52.540
GRANT is how you give permission for
someone to do something.

298
00:15:52.540 --> 00:15:56.090
REVOKE is how you take away
somebody's person to do something and

299
00:15:56.090 --> 00:16:00.200
DENY is how you make sure that
somebody never gets permission

300
00:16:00.200 --> 00:16:04.000
to something no matter what,
even if I go and grant them afterwards.

301
00:16:04.000 --> 00:16:06.980
If they're still denied they won't
be able to have that access.

302
00:16:06.980 --> 00:16:10.490
So those are examples of
commands that you would

303
00:16:12.060 --> 00:16:15.780
use in the Data Control Language.

304
00:16:15.780 --> 00:16:21.480
That really doesn't seem like
a lot of commands does it right?

305
00:16:21.480 --> 00:16:27.070
Between those diagrams there we've
got what is it ten commands right?

306
00:16:27.070 --> 00:16:29.220
So it sounds like a pretty easy task.

307
00:16:29.220 --> 00:16:31.920
But each command has so
many variations and so

308
00:16:31.920 --> 00:16:35.450
many different ways of using it,
especially the SELECT command,

309
00:16:35.450 --> 00:16:38.810
that you'll find it takes a long
time to master all ten of them.

310
00:16:38.810 --> 00:16:43.580
Some of them are really easy like DELETE,
DELETE's no big deal But SELECT, INSERT,

311
00:16:43.580 --> 00:16:44.790
INSERT is really tricky.

312
00:16:44.790 --> 00:16:46.780
And there's a few of
the other ones like create,

313
00:16:46.780 --> 00:16:48.330
where you have to know all
these different options.

314
00:16:48.330 --> 00:16:50.680
You guys will see that there's
actually a lot more involved in it but

315
00:16:50.680 --> 00:16:54.120
these are the commands that we're gonna
be focusing on as we move to the series.

316
00:16:54.120 --> 00:16:55.180
>> Wonderful information.

317
00:16:55.180 --> 00:16:56.070
I am so excited.

318
00:16:56.070 --> 00:16:57.190
I can't wait to find out more.

319
00:16:57.190 --> 00:16:59.890
This was the introduction
to Transact-SQL and

320
00:16:59.890 --> 00:17:02.150
Donnie your last words before we move on.

321
00:17:02.150 --> 00:17:07.650
>> Main thing here is, a lot of people
think of SQL is a programming language and

322
00:17:07.650 --> 00:17:09.370
I would disagree with that.

323
00:17:09.370 --> 00:17:11.040
We can put some logic in there, and

324
00:17:11.040 --> 00:17:15.405
you can do some things that it starts
to become sort of like programming but

325
00:17:15.405 --> 00:17:19.080
Transact-SQL and SQL itself, it's more
like learning a foreign language.

326
00:17:19.080 --> 00:17:22.310
It's just learning how to talk to
the database, to ask it a question.

327
00:17:22.310 --> 00:17:23.520
I might say hey,

328
00:17:23.520 --> 00:17:28.540
I need a list of employees whose
last name starts with s, right.

329
00:17:28.540 --> 00:17:31.510
I don't need to be a programmer, I just
need to know how to word that question

330
00:17:31.510 --> 00:17:34.580
the way the server will expect it and
then it'll give me the data that I want.

331
00:17:34.580 --> 00:17:38.070
And if I want it in a server,
I need a list of every employee whose

332
00:17:38.070 --> 00:17:42.420
last name starts with S and if you could
sort it alphabetically for me, right?

333
00:17:42.420 --> 00:17:45.240
That kind of thing,
we just need to know the way to say it and

334
00:17:45.240 --> 00:17:47.180
that's really what Transact-SQL is.

335
00:17:47.180 --> 00:17:51.380
So as you go and learn this,
I want you to be thinking of that.

336
00:17:51.380 --> 00:17:55.490
Think of what's the question I want to
ask in English, or whatever your native

337
00:17:55.490 --> 00:17:59.750
language happens to be, and then how
would I write that in Transact-SQL?

338
00:17:59.750 --> 00:18:02.010
It's just building up the idea
in your head, first of all.

339
00:18:02.010 --> 00:18:06.480
Like what do I want in English helps you
to then figure out what the command would

340
00:18:06.480 --> 00:18:09.320
be in Transact-SQL and all the different
components that you need and the pieces.

341
00:18:09.320 --> 00:18:13.070
So always bear that in mind as we go
through every episode in this series,

342
00:18:13.070 --> 00:18:16.230
that it is like learning
a foreign language.

343
00:18:16.230 --> 00:18:19.550
>> Querying Data with Transact-SQL,
great show.

344
00:18:19.550 --> 00:18:23.070
Don's doing a wonderful job and
will continue to do so is his way.

345
00:18:23.070 --> 00:18:27.530
Make sure you watch every single episode
of Querying Data with Transact-SQL and

346
00:18:27.530 --> 00:18:28.810
also, when you're in the course library,

347
00:18:28.810 --> 00:18:30.730
check out the other hundreds
of videos in there.

348
00:18:30.730 --> 00:18:34.078
They're all designed to do one thing,
help you go further and

349
00:18:34.078 --> 00:18:36.000
tell everybody you know about IT Pro TV.

350
00:18:36.000 --> 00:18:37.370
They'll be glad you did.

351
00:18:37.370 --> 00:18:38.020
Thanks for watching.

352
00:18:38.020 --> 00:18:38.970
I'm Zack Memos.

353
00:18:38.970 --> 00:18:39.685
>> And I'm Don Pizzatt.

354
00:18:39.685 --> 00:18:40.288
>> And we will see you soon.

355
00:18:40.288 --> 00:18:48.046
[MUSIC]

356
00:18:48.046 --> 00:18:50.570
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use the Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) to issue T-SQL queries against a server. He shows how to install the SSMS and get it connected to a database. He also highlights some of the benefits of using the SSMS like IntelliSense syntax highlighting and autocomplete.
episodes.title: Introduction to Transact-SQL Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.941
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.941 --> 00:00:03.975
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.975 --> 00:00:04.829
[CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:04.829 --> 00:00:11.112
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.112 --> 00:00:16.850
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to your
Querying Data with Trasact-SQL show.

6
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:18.024
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.024 --> 00:00:20.450
This is actually a part two.

8
00:00:20.450 --> 00:00:22.630
If you haven't seen the first one,
I suggest you do that.

9
00:00:22.630 --> 00:00:27.460
But we're gonna continue taking a look
at an introduction to Transact-SQL.

10
00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:30.390
And with us today, back in studios,
we have Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:30.390 --> 00:00:32.091
Thank you for joining us today, Don.

12
00:00:32.091 --> 00:00:33.470
>> Hey, thanks for having me, Cherokee.

13
00:00:33.470 --> 00:00:34.656
And if you watched part one,

14
00:00:34.656 --> 00:00:37.384
you know we learned a little bit
of the history of Transact-SQL.

15
00:00:37.384 --> 00:00:43.200
What it is, how it differs from just the
normal SQL, and some of the basics there.

16
00:00:43.200 --> 00:00:46.522
And in this episode, what I wanna do
is continue on with the basics and

17
00:00:46.522 --> 00:00:47.782
introduce you to, well,

18
00:00:47.782 --> 00:00:51.537
the way that we actually issue these
commands against the database service.

19
00:00:51.537 --> 00:00:54.669
So if we're gonna learn all these
commands, we need to know how to actually

20
00:00:54.669 --> 00:00:58.070
throw them at the server, and we'll get
a chance to see that and walk through it.

21
00:00:58.070 --> 00:00:59.027
If you already know how to do that,

22
00:00:59.027 --> 00:01:00.950
though, you're not gonna hurt my
feelings if you skip the episode.

23
00:01:00.950 --> 00:01:02.936
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're not gonna do a whole

24
00:01:02.936 --> 00:01:06.540
lot of actual SQL
language in this episode.

25
00:01:06.540 --> 00:01:10.110
It's gonna be focused more on just
the usability of that interface.

26
00:01:10.110 --> 00:01:12.992
>> All right, Don, so in all honesty,
I did skip the episode.

27
00:01:12.992 --> 00:01:14.573
>> [LAUGH]
>> I wasn't here for the last one.

28
00:01:14.573 --> 00:01:17.090
You might have to help
me out a little bit.

29
00:01:17.090 --> 00:01:20.400
So what kind of program are we gonna
be using to execute these commands?

30
00:01:20.400 --> 00:01:22.842
Is there anything I need
to set up ahead of time?

31
00:01:22.842 --> 00:01:26.456
>> All right, well, the reality is any
SQL compatible client can issue commands

32
00:01:26.456 --> 00:01:28.496
against the Microsoft SQL Server, right?

33
00:01:28.496 --> 00:01:31.130
And there are tons of
them that are out there.

34
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:34.060
But if you've gone through the effort
to get Microsoft SQL Server,

35
00:01:34.060 --> 00:01:36.270
the odds are you're going
to use their tools.

36
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:39.219
And if you are a database administrator or
a system administrator,

37
00:01:39.219 --> 00:01:42.700
the number one tool that you're gonna
use is the SQL Server Management Studio.

38
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:44.526
And sometimes,
Microsoft will abbreviate it SSMS.

39
00:01:44.526 --> 00:01:47.431
That's a lot of letters, so
I usually just say it out, but

40
00:01:47.431 --> 00:01:49.860
it's the SQL Server Management Studio.

41
00:01:49.860 --> 00:01:53.215
It is a tool that is
packaged with SQL Server.

42
00:01:53.215 --> 00:01:56.453
So if you go and
download SQL Server Enterprise Edition or

43
00:01:56.453 --> 00:02:00.837
the Standard Edition, even the Express
Edition, some of the downloads have

44
00:02:00.837 --> 00:02:04.961
a package, some don't, but
you get the SQL Server Management Studio.

45
00:02:04.961 --> 00:02:08.315
And you can take it, you install it,
you run it, connect to a server, and

46
00:02:08.315 --> 00:02:11.728
it gives you the full ability to manage
and interoperate with that server,

47
00:02:11.728 --> 00:02:14.190
especially with issuing queries and
running those.

48
00:02:14.190 --> 00:02:18.910
Now the SQL Server Management Studio, you
might wonder why it has such a long name.

49
00:02:18.910 --> 00:02:21.266
It's actually a variation of
Microsoft's Visual Studio.

50
00:02:21.266 --> 00:02:25.131
So if you're a developer,
maybe use Microsoft Visual Studio for

51
00:02:25.131 --> 00:02:28.517
doing C# development, or
Visual Basic, or whatever.

52
00:02:28.517 --> 00:02:29.881
Well, in the olden days,

53
00:02:29.881 --> 00:02:33.787
Microsoft SQL Server actually used
the standard MMC that all of our regular

54
00:02:33.787 --> 00:02:38.860
administration tools do because they were
gearing it towards system administrators.

55
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:42.699
But what they found was that more and more
often, it wasn't the system administrator

56
00:02:42.699 --> 00:02:46.540
that had to talk to the database server,
it was the developers that did.

57
00:02:46.540 --> 00:02:47.811
And so they made the decision to switch.

58
00:02:47.811 --> 00:02:51.965
And this was a long time ago, I think
in 2005, when they switched and said,

59
00:02:51.965 --> 00:02:54.693
we're gonna start using
basically Visual Studio or

60
00:02:54.693 --> 00:02:57.760
that type of interface to
interact with the server.

61
00:02:57.760 --> 00:03:01.380
And so now that's what we have, the SQL
Server Management Studio, which looks

62
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:05.320
a lot like Visual Studio and has a lot of
the same features and interface that makes

63
00:03:05.320 --> 00:03:08.990
it easier for developers to jump in and to
be able to run that and interact with it.

64
00:03:08.990 --> 00:03:13.020
Now unlike Visual Studio, it doesn't
do Visual Basic, it doesn't do C#.

65
00:03:13.020 --> 00:03:15.887
It is tuned to run SQL, and specifically,

66
00:03:15.887 --> 00:03:20.520
Transact-SQL, and to interact
with those Microsoft SQL Servers.

67
00:03:20.520 --> 00:03:23.965
So it gives you a great full development
environment to be able to work with

68
00:03:23.965 --> 00:03:25.199
the server and interact.

69
00:03:25.199 --> 00:03:27.870
So that's gonna be the number
one tool that we use.

70
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:31.500
It's also got some added benefits that
it can connect to more than one server.

71
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:33.820
So if you've got 20 SQL Servers,

72
00:03:33.820 --> 00:03:36.030
or 100, or
whatever you can connect to manage those.

73
00:03:36.030 --> 00:03:38.100
And it'll even manage the ones
you have in the cloud.

74
00:03:38.100 --> 00:03:42.288
So if you've deployed Azure SQL, for
example, you can connect and manage those.

75
00:03:42.288 --> 00:03:44.503
And even a mixture of the two.
You might have Azure SQL Servers and

76
00:03:44.503 --> 00:03:46.024
on-premise SQL Servers, and

77
00:03:46.024 --> 00:03:49.428
even the ones that are running right
on your own desktop for testing.

78
00:03:49.428 --> 00:03:52.240
And you can manage it all
from one little environment.

79
00:03:52.240 --> 00:03:53.720
So that Management Studio
is pretty powerful.

80
00:03:53.720 --> 00:03:56.680
>> So Don, where can I get
the SQL Server Management Studio?

81
00:03:56.680 --> 00:03:59.760
>> The easiest place to get it is
packaged with the install, right?

82
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:02.953
So if you're on the server and
you do the install of SQL Server,

83
00:04:02.953 --> 00:04:05.378
it's going to install
the Management Studio.

84
00:04:05.378 --> 00:04:07.880
But, actually,
that's not always true, right?

85
00:04:07.880 --> 00:04:09.740
What if I have a Core Services server?

86
00:04:09.740 --> 00:04:12.100
It's not gonna install
the management tools, right?

87
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:13.207
So if you're gonna run this,

88
00:04:13.207 --> 00:04:16.400
the idea is that you're really gonna
run it from your own workstation.

89
00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:16.980
I might have 100 servers.

90
00:04:16.980 --> 00:04:20.390
Now I might not have the Management Studio
installed on a single one of them.

91
00:04:20.390 --> 00:04:22.159
I have it installed on my laptop,
on my desktop, and

92
00:04:22.159 --> 00:04:23.790
that's where I manage things from.

93
00:04:23.790 --> 00:04:27.909
Now if I have a SQL Server DVD laying
around, I can go and grab that and

94
00:04:27.909 --> 00:04:28.565
pop it in.

95
00:04:28.565 --> 00:04:30.320
But I know my laptop has the problem.

96
00:04:30.320 --> 00:04:31.527
>> [LAUGH]
>> Most people do,

97
00:04:31.527 --> 00:04:33.864
I don't have a DVD drive anymore.

98
00:04:33.864 --> 00:04:36.547
>> I was gonna say, you have a DVD drive?

99
00:04:36.547 --> 00:04:37.452
>> [LAUGH] It's not 2010 anymore, right?

100
00:04:37.452 --> 00:04:39.290
So [LAUGH] we've moved beyond that.

101
00:04:39.290 --> 00:04:41.336
So now, we're usually gonna go and
download it, right?

102
00:04:41.336 --> 00:04:44.976
And I've even gotten to the point where
I don't use the one that comes on the CD

103
00:04:44.976 --> 00:04:47.720
anyway because it's obsolete
by the time you install it.

104
00:04:47.720 --> 00:04:50.194
So I'm normally gonna go and download it.

105
00:04:50.194 --> 00:04:53.435
And Microsoft does a great job of making
the SQL Server Management Studio available

106
00:04:53.435 --> 00:04:55.059
for download right off of their website.

107
00:04:55.059 --> 00:04:57.370
So we can always jump over and do it.

108
00:04:57.370 --> 00:04:59.840
Now, if you're on a server,
let me show you my desktop here.

109
00:04:59.840 --> 00:05:03.290
So I've got a server
pulled up here that has

110
00:05:03.290 --> 00:05:07.740
Windows Server 2016 with
SQL Server 2016 installed on it.

111
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:12.310
And because it was a GUI install,
it actually dropped the icon for

112
00:05:12.310 --> 00:05:15.380
the Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio
right there on my desktop.

113
00:05:15.380 --> 00:05:17.770
So if you've installed it locally,
you've already got it.

114
00:05:17.770 --> 00:05:19.000
You're ready to go.

115
00:05:19.000 --> 00:05:22.640
It's the Microsoft SQL Server
Management Studio, and that's it.

116
00:05:22.640 --> 00:05:26.940
But if you don't have it, then what you'll
do is you'll go to Microsoft's website.

117
00:05:26.940 --> 00:05:29.866
And here's the Microsoft site, and I'll
put this link in with the show notes so

118
00:05:29.866 --> 00:05:31.184
you don't have to scramble for it.

119
00:05:31.184 --> 00:05:36.140
But Microsoft keeps this one link
active for every version of SQL.

120
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:37.340
Cuz every time a new version comes out,

121
00:05:37.340 --> 00:05:40.160
they release a new version
of the Management Studio.

122
00:05:40.160 --> 00:05:43.320
This show, for example,
is based on SQL Server 2016.

123
00:05:43.320 --> 00:05:46.550
But the most current
one is SQL Server 2017,

124
00:05:46.550 --> 00:05:51.480
which just came out not too long ago so
we don't have a show for that yet.

125
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:54.480
But SQL Server 2016 is the one
that's being actively pushed for

126
00:05:54.480 --> 00:05:55.790
production use right now.

127
00:05:55.790 --> 00:05:59.067
But if I come here to
the SQL Server Management Studio download,

128
00:05:59.067 --> 00:06:01.629
I see where I can download
the Management Studio.

129
00:06:01.629 --> 00:06:06.160
And it's offering for me to download
SQL Server Management Studio 17.3, right?

130
00:06:06.160 --> 00:06:11.574
Now, the neat part about the Management
Studio is that it is backwards compatible,

131
00:06:11.574 --> 00:06:13.951
right, at least to a certain range.

132
00:06:13.951 --> 00:06:17.962
And it'll normally tell us that somewhere
here in the web page if I were to take

133
00:06:17.962 --> 00:06:22.096
the time and read it, it's just buried in
here somewhere, but I know this one in

134
00:06:22.096 --> 00:06:26.880
particular actually supports managing
SQL Server 2008 all the way through 2017.

135
00:06:26.880 --> 00:06:32.078
So if I've got SQL Server 2012,
2014, 2016, 2017,

136
00:06:32.078 --> 00:06:36.817

I just did it like that.

00:17:08.360 --> 00:17:11.370

00:17:13.214 --> 00:17:14.310

00:17:14.310 --> 00:17:16.900
Level 15,
that means it caused the command to fail.

00:17:16.900 --> 00:17:18.188

00:17:18.188 --> 00:17:21.630

00:17:21.630 --> 00:17:25.560
And then, incorrect syntax near,
and it's a closed parentheses.

370
00:17:25.560 --> 00:17:27.880
So I can go up here and I can find line 2.

371
00:17:27.880 --> 00:17:29.258
Line 2 is this SELECT TOP.

372
00:17:29.258 --> 00:17:31.670
I can find the closed parentheses.

373
00:17:31.670 --> 00:17:32.800
It's a little hard to see, but

374
00:17:32.800 --> 00:17:36.820
do you see the little red squiggly
that's under that closed parentheses?

375
00:17:36.820 --> 00:17:37.470
>> I do.

376
00:17:37.470 --> 00:17:40.970
>> That's helping us find
exactly where the error is.

377
00:17:40.970 --> 00:17:42.170
Now I know where the error is.

378
00:17:42.170 --> 00:17:44.730
And I can look at it and say,
well what did I do wrong here?

379
00:17:44.730 --> 00:17:46.870
And let me correct, and you know what?

380
00:17:46.870 --> 00:17:47.630
I didn't give it a value.

381
00:17:47.630 --> 00:17:49.280
Let me give it a value.

382
00:17:49.280 --> 00:17:51.310
And now the little red squiggly went away.

383
00:17:51.310 --> 00:17:55.320
It understands the syntax,
it's tuned for Transact-SQL.

384
00:17:55.320 --> 00:17:57.530
I mentioned that earlier,
here we see it in action.

385
00:17:57.530 --> 00:18:01.730
So it knows that's wrong, and it let's me
know, and kinda helps me to correct it,

386
00:18:01.730 --> 00:18:04.370
and then I can go and run and
now it executes properly.

387
00:18:04.370 --> 00:18:09.090
And I can quickly recycle code, rerun it
as I need it to get that up and going.

388
00:18:09.090 --> 00:18:12.650
So, it actually works really,
really neat like that.

389
00:18:12.650 --> 00:18:17.020
All along, on the right side here,
I've got my connection parameters.

390
00:18:17.020 --> 00:18:19.950
And it's showing me information about
the server that I'm connected to.

391
00:18:19.950 --> 00:18:21.700
Because there's various
session variables and

392
00:18:21.700 --> 00:18:23.680
things that might change
the results I get.

393
00:18:23.680 --> 00:18:26.520
Depending on who I'm logged in as,
I might get one set of

394
00:18:26.520 --> 00:18:28.910
results versus a different set
of results for somebody else.

395
00:18:28.910 --> 00:18:30.970
So I can see, who am I logged in as.

396
00:18:30.970 --> 00:18:33.150
What server version am I running,
and so on.

397
00:18:33.150 --> 00:18:36.090
I see all that information right
over here on the right side,

398
00:18:36.090 --> 00:18:37.660
inside of our connection properties.

399
00:18:37.660 --> 00:18:41.400
And this can change sometimes, depending
on what you're viewing the properties for.

400
00:18:41.400 --> 00:18:44.208
So you'll see this updated,
it's very dynamic.

401
00:18:44.208 --> 00:18:49.170
And then across the top,
we have a whole collection of buttons,

402
00:18:49.170 --> 00:18:52.606
and I'm gonna save a lot of these buttons,
cuz they deal with things that we haven't

00:18:52.606 --> 00:18:55.820
learned about yet, that we're gonna learn
about in the SQL Administration shows.

404
00:18:55.820 --> 00:18:58.670
But a couple that are really
important that I wanna highlight

00:18:58.670 --> 00:19:01.210
are all found right here
in this bottom row.

406
00:19:02.350 --> 00:19:04.600
First off,
you'll see this little button right here.

407
00:19:04.600 --> 00:19:06.350
This says, change connection.

408
00:19:06.350 --> 00:19:09.940
I can change to another server if I
wanna connect to a different server.

409
00:19:09.940 --> 00:19:12.370
Or if I wanna connect to more
than one server right down here,

410
00:19:12.370 --> 00:19:15.720
I can use this connect button, and
I can specify other servers to connect to,

411
00:19:15.720 --> 00:19:17.380
and I can be connected to more at once.

412
00:19:17.380 --> 00:19:20.620
>> So it maintains that session,
and you're not terminating that and

413
00:19:20.620 --> 00:19:22.250
then moving on to the next server,
essentially?

414
00:19:22.250 --> 00:19:22.880
>> Right.

415
00:19:22.880 --> 00:19:25.700
>> Well, technically, with SQL,
you open a connection,

416
00:19:25.700 --> 00:19:27.280
and then you stop talking to the server.

417
00:19:27.280 --> 00:19:30.600
You only talk to it when you're running
queries, but you hold your authentication

418
00:19:30.600 --> 00:19:34.400
open so it's ready to jump right back
in at a moment's notice, easy enough.

419
00:19:34.400 --> 00:19:36.830
Sometimes you can make a mistake and
leave a session running, and

420
00:19:36.830 --> 00:19:39.770
it'll stay running until
the server decides to close it.

421
00:19:39.770 --> 00:19:42.130
Next, I see the database
that I'm working on.

422
00:19:42.130 --> 00:19:45.900
Now when I ran this command over here, how
did it know which database to run it on?

423
00:19:45.900 --> 00:19:49.880
Well, this drop down box right here told
it to run against Adventure Works 2016.

424
00:19:49.880 --> 00:19:52.680
If I drop that down,
I'll see the other databases and

425
00:19:52.680 --> 00:19:55.580
I could choose to run against
from one of them instead.

426
00:19:55.580 --> 00:19:56.440
Then we got Execute.

427
00:19:56.440 --> 00:19:59.500
This is the button that
tells it to run the query.

428
00:19:59.500 --> 00:20:02.540
Now, I never hit this button,
because I'm so used to hitting F5.

00:20:02.540 --> 00:20:04.150
And notice, when I float my mouse over,

430
00:20:04.150 --> 00:20:06.095
there was that tooltip

00:20:06.095 --> 00:20:08.000
And it says, Execute, F5.

00:20:08.000 --> 00:20:10.680

00:20:10.680 --> 00:20:12.570
And that's kind of a habit

00:20:12.570 --> 00:20:14.500
that Execute button does it.

435
00:20:14.500 --> 00:20:17.540
We've got the Debug button,
which will step through the query,

436
00:20:17.540 --> 00:20:20.750
running one piece at a time to help
you find where an error is, or

437
00:20:20.750 --> 00:20:23.500
to help tweak and
trouble shoot to solve a bad query.

438
00:20:23.500 --> 00:20:25.790
You've got a Stop button.

439
00:20:25.790 --> 00:20:28.424
If you ever run a bad query that holds
a session open on the server, and

440
00:20:28.424 --> 00:20:30.220
it just keeps running and running.

441
00:20:30.220 --> 00:20:31.440
Way down at the bottom,

442
00:20:31.440 --> 00:20:34.577
you've got this little timer that shows
how long your query has been running.

443
00:20:34.577 --> 00:20:37.050
And if that time just keeps going and
going and going,

444
00:20:37.050 --> 00:20:41.080
you might need to stop the query, and so
you would use this Stop button to do that.

445
00:20:41.080 --> 00:20:43.620
It only lights up while
your query is running.

446
00:20:43.620 --> 00:20:46.910
Next to it though, is my favorite button,

447
00:20:46.910 --> 00:20:50.400
It's Parse, and
it's got a shortcut of control F5.

448
00:20:50.400 --> 00:20:52.810
If I'm typing a query,

449
00:20:52.810 --> 00:20:56.600
I don't necessarily wanna throw it at the
server to find out if it's good or not.

450
00:20:56.600 --> 00:20:59.380
So real quick,
I can just take Control F5 and

451
00:20:59.380 --> 00:21:04.300
it will run a check to make
sure the query is okay.

452
00:21:04.300 --> 00:21:06.990
And see down here,

453
00:21:06.990 --> 00:21:09.570
It didn't talk to the server at all.

454
00:21:09.570 --> 00:21:11.260
It did it all right here
in the management studio.

455
00:21:11.260 --> 00:21:14.080
So let me check your code, and
make sure you don't have any errors.

456
00:21:14.080 --> 00:21:15.690
And if you don't, then you're good to go.

00:21:15.690 --> 00:21:18.880
If I were to have injected
an error like this, and

00:21:18.880 --> 00:21:22.530
do a Ctrl F5, it's gonna run,
and it finds the error.

459
00:21:22.530 --> 00:21:24.730
But the important part is
that it found it here.

460
00:21:24.730 --> 00:21:26.210
It didn't send it to the server.

461
00:21:26.210 --> 00:21:28.420
The server wasn't involved in it.

00:21:28.420 --> 00:21:32.240
>> So, Don, someone not having

00:21:49.520 --> 00:21:50.170

00:22:26.010 --> 00:22:27.800

a lot of-
