00:27:10.331 --> 00:27:13.110
it's normally just a holder
[LAUGH] where you put these files.

592
00:27:13.110 --> 00:27:16.637
>> And would we potentially automate this
if we knew we had to run this particular

593
00:27:16.637 --> 00:27:18.039
query everyday or-
>> Yeah,

594
00:27:18.039 --> 00:27:20.770
if we go beyond the scope of this course.

595
00:27:20.770 --> 00:27:23.280
But if I normally run it every Monday,

596
00:27:23.280 --> 00:27:25.365
there's actually a command-line
interface for SQL.

597
00:27:25.365 --> 00:27:29.009
And we can just tell it, hey, every
Monday at 8 AM, use the command-line,

598
00:27:29.009 --> 00:27:32.110
run this SQL file that I feed into you,
and it'll run it and do it.

599
00:27:32.110 --> 00:27:36.473
So we can use the visual interface here to
create the query, save it as a text file,

600
00:27:36.473 --> 00:27:40.225
and then we can use the command-line
to execute it on a routine basis.

601
00:27:40.225 --> 00:27:43.340
So it's nice to have an easier
interface in developing.

602
00:27:43.340 --> 00:27:47.185
>> Yes, and talking about that easier
interface, I know we're getting close on

603
00:27:47.185 --> 00:27:50.853
time, but Don, PowerShell does offer
a lot of tools in ways that can help,

604
00:27:50.853 --> 00:27:52.561
like plug and chug for scripting.

605
00:27:52.561 --> 00:27:54.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is there something similar to that

606
00:27:54.580 --> 00:27:56.290
here within this management console?

607
00:27:56.290 --> 00:28:00.020
>> Absolutely, so I already showed you one
of them, which was a syntax correction,

608
00:28:00.020 --> 00:28:04.220
right, that if I make mistakes in here,
it helps me find them, and

609
00:28:04.220 --> 00:28:06.450
helps me correct them and
get that cleared.

610
00:28:06.450 --> 00:28:07.480
So that syntax checking,

611
00:28:07.480 --> 00:28:11.620
that little parse check mark up top or
Ctrl+F5 is really handy.

612
00:28:11.620 --> 00:28:14.075
And sometimes it'll even
do code suggestions.

613
00:28:14.075 --> 00:28:18.630
There's a feature that the Microsoft,
they patented, it's called IntelliSense.

614
00:28:18.630 --> 00:28:20.599
IntelliSense looks at what you're typing.

615
00:28:20.599 --> 00:28:23.348
And it starts to give you suggestions,
right?

616
00:28:23.348 --> 00:28:26.590
So when I'm typing that SELECT command,
well,

617
00:28:26.590 --> 00:28:28.250
there's a lot of different things
that might start with SEL.

618
00:28:28.250 --> 00:28:31.313
It doesn't necessarily know what
I'm doing, but it definitely knows

619
00:28:31.313 --> 00:28:34.030
what I'm doing is wrong right now,
so I get the red underline.

620
00:28:34.030 --> 00:28:37.630
But when I type it out,
see how it turned blue, right?

621
00:28:37.630 --> 00:28:39.479
It recognized that and
says, wait a minute,

622
00:28:39.479 --> 00:28:41.241
you're not just typing some random word.

623
00:28:41.241 --> 00:28:44.010
That's an actual command that
you're giving me, right?

624
00:28:44.010 --> 00:28:47.680
And so it knows to do that and-
>> I noticed you didn't tap through there,

625
00:28:47.680 --> 00:28:49.020
is that an option?

626
00:28:49.020 --> 00:28:51.190
>> Not on a command like that.

627
00:28:51.190 --> 00:28:52.630
It is on other things, though.

628
00:28:52.630 --> 00:28:56.140
So, for example, I wanna select
some information from a table.

629
00:28:56.140 --> 00:28:57.614
I wanna select FirstName and LastName.

630
00:28:57.614 --> 00:29:01.600
Well, it doesn't know what
table I'm working on right now.

631
00:29:01.600 --> 00:29:04.206
So it's giving me suggestions and
suggestions are all wrong, right,

632
00:29:04.206 --> 00:29:05.779
cuz it doesn't know what I'm working on.

633
00:29:05.779 --> 00:29:08.360
But when it does know, it really is handy.

634
00:29:08.360 --> 00:29:10.470
So, for example,
if I say I wanna select everything.

635
00:29:10.470 --> 00:29:13.450
I'll do a star, and I'll say FROM.

636
00:29:13.450 --> 00:29:15.570
Now it knows that I'm
about to pick a table.

637
00:29:15.570 --> 00:29:18.430
So it knows that whatever I'm
about to type is a table and

638
00:29:18.430 --> 00:29:19.890
it can give me suggestions.

639
00:29:19.890 --> 00:29:21.990
I want the Person.Person table.

640
00:29:21.990 --> 00:29:26.356
So I'll type Pe and see how it's
already suggesting Person right there?

641
00:29:26.356 --> 00:29:28.380
And it's already highlighted.

642
00:29:28.380 --> 00:29:29.853
It knows what I'm looking for.

643
00:29:29.853 --> 00:29:32.790
I can hit Tab, and it finishes it out.

644
00:29:32.790 --> 00:29:36.150
Now my table is actually called
Person.Person, so I could type a dot.

645
00:29:36.150 --> 00:29:38.406
And now it shows me all the sub-entries.

646
00:29:38.406 --> 00:29:42.740
And if I do another P,
it moves it down to Person.Password.

647
00:29:42.740 --> 00:29:44.420
That's not what I want,
I want Person.Person.

648
00:29:44.420 --> 00:29:48.412
So if I type Pe, now it's got it,
I can hit Tab again, right?

649
00:29:48.412 --> 00:29:51.346
And now that it knows what
table I'm working on,

650
00:29:51.346 --> 00:29:55.332
if I go back to this value here and
I replace it, I want FirstName.

651
00:29:55.332 --> 00:30:00.060
I can type Fir, and
it'll start to look in that table.

652
00:30:00.060 --> 00:30:01.660
And see how it found FirstName?

653
00:30:01.660 --> 00:30:03.950
It couldn't find that earlier cuz
it didn't know where to look.

654
00:30:03.950 --> 00:30:05.200
Now it knows where to look.

655
00:30:05.200 --> 00:30:09.640
IntelliSense understands where
you're at in the command.

656
00:30:09.640 --> 00:30:12.405
It changes based on what you've done.

657
00:30:12.405 --> 00:30:14.889
And it senses intelligently,
I guess where the name came from.

658
00:30:14.889 --> 00:30:18.027
>> [LAUGH]
>> What those recommendations should be,

659
00:30:18.027 --> 00:30:20.010
and that saves you a lot of time.

660
00:30:20.010 --> 00:30:24.260
I know for me, sometimes I'll be typing in
a table name and no suggestions come up.

661
00:30:24.260 --> 00:30:26.078
And I'm like,
why is this thing not working?

662
00:30:26.078 --> 00:30:26.790
It's not that it's not working.

663
00:30:26.790 --> 00:30:28.074
It means that I spelled something wrong,
or

664
00:30:28.074 --> 00:30:29.470
I'm referencing a table
that doesn't exist.

665
00:30:29.470 --> 00:30:31.366
It usually means I'm connected
to the wrong database.

666
00:30:31.366 --> 00:30:32.820
That's almost always what happens to me.

667
00:30:32.820 --> 00:30:36.053
So it's neat cuz it helps you know
when you're doing something bad if you

668
00:30:36.053 --> 00:30:38.690
don't get suggestions, but
you'll see that pop up.

669
00:30:38.690 --> 00:30:40.150
You can ignore it if you hate it.

670
00:30:40.150 --> 00:30:42.820
You can go into Tools > Options and
disable it if you hate it.

671
00:30:42.820 --> 00:30:44.020
But most people love it.

672
00:30:44.020 --> 00:30:46.208
And you can just hit Tab to
choose what it's copying.

673
00:30:46.208 --> 00:30:47.384
You can use your mouse to click on it.

674
00:30:47.384 --> 00:30:51.534
And it saves you a lot of typing and
makes you save a lot of errors.

675
00:30:51.534 --> 00:30:52.267
>> I think it looks pretty cool.

676
00:30:52.267 --> 00:30:55.025
It's almost like finding
the pieces to that puzzle, or

677
00:30:55.025 --> 00:30:56.780
at least assisting with that.

678
00:30:56.780 --> 00:30:59.315
You get your little corner pieces,
then your edge pieces.

679
00:30:59.315 --> 00:31:00.818
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And you can move forward.

680
00:31:00.818 --> 00:31:04.503
So thank you for taking the time to show
us at least how to get started here, Don,

681
00:31:04.503 --> 00:31:06.190
but I know there's more to come.

682
00:31:06.190 --> 00:31:07.990
>> Absolutely.
>> And thank you for joining us as well.

683
00:31:07.990 --> 00:31:10.755
Don, do you have any final
thoughts before we head on out?

684
00:31:10.755 --> 00:31:12.355
>> This episode was fairly lightweight,
right?

685
00:31:12.355 --> 00:31:14.785
I wanted you guys to have
experience with the user interface.

686
00:31:14.785 --> 00:31:16.895
The whole rest of the series,
we're writing queries,

687
00:31:16.895 --> 00:31:19.485
where we're actually writing SQL or
Transact-SQL.

688
00:31:19.485 --> 00:31:22.785
And you'll get a chance to see how that
works and how we write these ourselves.

689
00:31:22.785 --> 00:31:24.875
So don't worry if you didn't know
these queries that I just did.

690
00:31:24.875 --> 00:31:26.205
We're gonna learn all those later on.

691
00:31:26.205 --> 00:31:28.885
>> All right, perfect, well, for
this show, we'll go ahead and sign out.

692
00:31:28.885 --> 00:31:30.515
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

693
00:31:30.515 --> 00:31:31.255
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

694
00:31:31.255 --> 00:31:34.684
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

695
00:31:34.684 --> 00:31:40.457
[MUSIC]

696
00:31:40.457 --> 00:31:42.310
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the SELECT statement. He demonstrates how to retrieve data from a SQL database using SELECT, and then shows how to use the WHERE clause to refine the results
episodes.title: Retrieving Data with SELECT

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues demonstrating how to use the SELECT statement to retrieve data from a SQL server. He expands upon part 1 by demonstrating how to use ORDER BY, UNION and DISTINCT to further refine the results of a SELECT query.
episodes.title: Retrieving Data with SELECT Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to combine results from more than one table by using the JOIN clause. He demonstrates the basic operation of JOIN and then explains some methods to help simplify the SELECT query and make it more manageable.
episodes.title: Combining Results with JOIN

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues explaining how the JOIN clause can be used to generate results from multiple tables. He builds on part 1 by discussing other types of JOIN clauses that can be performed. He explains and demonstrates how to use INNER JOIN and three different types of OUTER JOIN.
episodes.title: Combining Results with JOIN Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.093 --> 00:00:02.244
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.244 --> 00:00:05.913
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.913 --> 00:00:08.297
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.297 --> 00:00:11.656
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.656 --> 00:00:16.690
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to your
Querying Data with Transact-SQL series.

6
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:18.453
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.453 --> 00:00:22.606
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at combining joins, and

8
00:00:22.606 --> 00:00:24.720
this is actually a Part II.

9
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:26.838
And with us today,
back in studios, we have Mr.

10
00:00:26.838 --> 00:00:29.327
Don Pezet, thank you for
joining us, Don, how are you?

11
00:00:29.327 --> 00:00:29.876
>> I'm doing great.

12
00:00:29.876 --> 00:00:32.990
And in the first episode,
we focused on inner joins, right?

13
00:00:32.990 --> 00:00:35.097
And we got a chance to see how
we can combine these tables and

14
00:00:35.097 --> 00:00:36.305
put some information together.

15
00:00:36.305 --> 00:00:37.925
And right at the end of the episode,

16
00:00:37.925 --> 00:00:40.920
we dropped in that little bombshell of,
by the way.

17
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:43.733
That's just one of actually four
different types of joins, and

18
00:00:43.733 --> 00:00:46.402
the other joins all fall into
this category of an outer join.

19
00:00:46.402 --> 00:00:50.570
And in this episode, we're going to take
a look at the outer joins, how they work.

20
00:00:50.570 --> 00:00:53.188
How we issue the commands, and
how we use them to retrieve data and

21
00:00:53.188 --> 00:00:54.628
kinda get a feel for how that works.

22
00:00:54.628 --> 00:00:56.930
That's all coming up right
here in this episode.

23
00:00:56.930 --> 00:00:59.411
>> Don, I have to ask before
we get started, though,

24
00:00:59.411 --> 00:01:02.667
what is the difference between
an inner join versus an outer join?

25
00:01:02.667 --> 00:01:05.769
>> This is actually a pretty
significant difference, and

26
00:01:05.769 --> 00:01:09.003
I didn't quite highlight it so
much in the first episode.

27
00:01:09.003 --> 00:01:12.791
But it really boils down to the results
that we're presented with, right?

28
00:01:12.791 --> 00:01:15.581
When we did the inner join,
we took two tables and

29
00:01:15.581 --> 00:01:19.204
we compared the results together
based on some kind of entity.

30
00:01:19.204 --> 00:01:20.404
And we got a result and

31
00:01:20.404 --> 00:01:23.824
set out of them based on your
data from two different tables.

32
00:01:23.824 --> 00:01:28.253
Now, what I didn't highlight was that
sometimes we don't have matches,

33
00:01:28.253 --> 00:01:30.320
things don't match up.

34
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:34.073
And in an inner join, anything that
doesn't match up just gets left out,

35
00:01:34.073 --> 00:01:36.383
doesn't get included, it gets thrown out.

36
00:01:36.383 --> 00:01:38.720
And I don't think I ever mentioned
that in the first episode, but

37
00:01:38.720 --> 00:01:40.710
we're definitely going
to see it right here.

38
00:01:40.710 --> 00:01:43.970
Because the whole point of an outer
join is to come back in and say,

39
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:46.357
I actually want that
stuff that didn't match.

40
00:01:46.357 --> 00:01:49.600
I need to know about it,
it's important for some reason, right?

41
00:01:49.600 --> 00:01:52.741
And there's several scenarios
where that gets involved.

42
00:01:52.741 --> 00:01:56.008
But if we take a look,
I'll bring up the query that we did,

43
00:01:56.008 --> 00:01:59.780
I've got on my screen here the query
that we did in the last show.

44
00:01:59.780 --> 00:02:03.790
>> Okay.
>> This is a straight up inner join.

45
00:02:03.790 --> 00:02:06.824
Now, through the whole episode,
I just typed join like that, but

46
00:02:06.824 --> 00:02:10.469
there's actually an implied, when you
do join, it's an implied inner join.

47
00:02:10.469 --> 00:02:15.240
And you can type it yourself if you want.

48
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:18.720
But what we were doing was we
were getting the first name and

49
00:02:18.720 --> 00:02:20.577
last name of all of our people.

50
00:02:20.577 --> 00:02:24.751
And matching it up to a job title and
a hired date from a human resources table,

51
00:02:24.751 --> 00:02:26.615
those were the two tables.

52
00:02:26.615 --> 00:02:30.086
Person.Person, that had every
contact that we knew about, and

53
00:02:30.086 --> 00:02:33.633
then HumanResources.Employee,
that had all of our employees.

54
00:02:33.633 --> 00:02:37.360
And when we matched it up,
we got this result down here.

55
00:02:37.360 --> 00:02:40.880
Where we could see each of these people,
like Ken Sanchez, who's the CEO,

56
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:42.535
Chief Executive Officer, right?

57
00:02:42.535 --> 00:02:46.800
Now here's the thing, it did a great job,
it created the table that I want.

58
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:51.236
I see these employees, I see their job
title, that data came from two tables, and

59
00:02:51.236 --> 00:02:52.404
that's wonderful.

60
00:02:52.404 --> 00:02:54.620
But if I look at the result, right?

61
00:02:54.620 --> 00:02:58.596
Buried down here under my head,
I can see they return 290 rows,

62
00:02:58.596 --> 00:03:00.880
I've got 290 employees, right?

63
00:03:00.880 --> 00:03:08.760
But that first table, Person.Person,
it has a lot more than 290 entries in it.

64
00:03:08.760 --> 00:03:12.818
In fact,
if we change our query a little bit here,

65
00:03:12.818 --> 00:03:19.309
let me just pull up that table if I do
a SELECT star FROM Person.Person, right?

66
00:03:19.309 --> 00:03:22.401
Or actually I guess we could try and
keep it a little more fair and just do,

67
00:03:22.401 --> 00:03:25.508
first name, comma, last name,
which is what we're working with.

68
00:03:25.508 --> 00:03:28.015
>> That's good, because I don't
remember the number either, I mean,

69
00:03:28.015 --> 00:03:29.766
it was several thousand,
if I can recall [LAUGH].

70
00:03:29.766 --> 00:03:33.229
>> Yeah, and if we just run that,
and create Person.Person, right, so

71
00:03:33.229 --> 00:03:36.470
here it comes back with the data
that we got from that table.

72
00:03:36.470 --> 00:03:41.600
And if I look down at my row count now,
19,972,

73
00:03:41.600 --> 00:03:46.050
well, we only got 290 results on our join.

74
00:03:46.050 --> 00:03:50.190
And the reason we only got 290 results
is because it was an INNER JOIN.

75
00:03:50.190 --> 00:03:54.771
An INNER JOIN says, look, Person.Person
has over 19,000 people in it.

76
00:03:54.771 --> 00:03:59.890
But only 290 of them matched
up to HumanResources.Employee.

77
00:03:59.890 --> 00:04:03.655
And so that's what it then went on
to display for us in our table, and

78
00:04:03.655 --> 00:04:07.507
why we only got 290 results,
that's the way an inner join works.

79
00:04:07.507 --> 00:04:10.710
Now, if that's what you want, great.

80
00:04:10.710 --> 00:04:14.147
And in a lot of cases, it is what we want,
so an inner join is straightforward,

81
00:04:14.147 --> 00:04:15.359
you do it, and that's it.

82
00:04:15.359 --> 00:04:19.995
But if I need to get the other records
as well, the ones that didn't match.

83
00:04:19.995 --> 00:04:23.775
An inner join is not what I need, and
that's where an outer join comes in.

84
00:04:23.775 --> 00:04:26.440
>> Well, Don, I feel like you
have some surprises for us,

85
00:04:26.440 --> 00:04:28.960
just like the surprise with
the inner versus outer.

86
00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:31.662
I see here on the notes that there
are different types of outer joins,

87
00:04:31.662 --> 00:04:33.255
do you want to kind of elaborate on that?

88
00:04:33.255 --> 00:04:33.755
>> Yeah, yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

89
00:04:33.755 --> 00:04:35.853
>> So on an inner join, there's just one,

90
00:04:35.853 --> 00:04:40.360
and that's the default join, so that's it,
we've learned all we need to know on that

91
00:04:40.360 --> 00:04:43.433
one, right?
But on an outer join, there's actually

92
00:04:43.433 --> 00:04:45.938
three different types of outer joins.
And

93
00:04:45.938 --> 00:04:51.260
that's because of the way that the records
may or may not match up, right?

94
00:04:51.260 --> 00:04:53.795
When we run the query,
where is the data getting lost?

95
00:04:53.795 --> 00:04:56.254
And so, that's where,
when we use an outer join,

96
00:04:56.254 --> 00:04:59.620
we actually have to make
a little more of a choice, right?

97
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:02.478
For an inner join, I can just type,
inner join, for an outer join,

98
00:05:02.478 --> 00:05:03.898
I can't just type, outer join.

99
00:05:03.898 --> 00:05:07.251
If I do that, I should have
tested this before the show, but

100
00:05:07.251 --> 00:05:08.680
I'm gonna run it [LAUGH].

101
00:05:08.680 --> 00:05:12.110
And I'll give it an error, actually its
underlying JOIN there as an error, right?

102
00:05:12.110 --> 00:05:16.910
And that's because it knows I need to
tell it which of the three types of outer

103
00:05:16.910 --> 00:05:18.740
joins that I want to do.

104
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:22.642
So the three types,
there is a left outer join,

105
00:05:22.642 --> 00:05:26.163
a right outer join, and a full outer join.

106
00:05:26.163 --> 00:05:30.627
And what they're doing is basically
allowing us to pick the values that we

107
00:05:30.627 --> 00:05:31.780
want to preserve.

108
00:05:31.780 --> 00:05:34.749
The values that don't necessarily
have a full match up and

109
00:05:34.749 --> 00:05:36.392
all the exact records and so on.

110
00:05:36.392 --> 00:05:38.705
Now to explain the difference
between the three,

111
00:05:38.705 --> 00:05:41.800
it's kind of hard when you're just
looking at raw data like this.

112
00:05:41.800 --> 00:05:44.280
So I actually worked up a little picture,
and

113
00:05:44.280 --> 00:05:46.902
you guys know my artistic
ability is not great.

114
00:05:46.902 --> 00:05:49.514
>> [LAUGH]
>> But basically, when we do a join,

115
00:05:49.514 --> 00:05:52.274
we've got two tables,
right, Table 1 and Table 2.

116
00:05:52.274 --> 00:05:57.013
In the example I showed you guys a minute
ago, Table 1 was Person.Person, and

117
00:05:57.013 --> 00:05:59.150
it had all the people we know about.

118
00:05:59.150 --> 00:06:01.920
And Table 2 was the-
>> Human resources.

119
00:06:01.920 --> 00:06:06.193
>> Right, HumanResources.Employee, and
that had just our employees' information.

120
00:06:06.193 --> 00:06:10.474
>> So there's a lot of data in
Table 1 that isn't in Table 2,

121
00:06:10.474 --> 00:06:14.860
that doesn't match up, but
there's overlap, right?

122
00:06:14.860 --> 00:06:19.197
If you remember back to first grade,
red and blue make purple, or Ziploc bags,

123
00:06:19.197 --> 00:06:19.732
I guess.

124
00:06:19.732 --> 00:06:23.286
And I can see I've got this
purple area right here,

125
00:06:23.286 --> 00:06:25.945
that's the overlap between the two.

126
00:06:25.945 --> 00:06:29.226
So, I might have 19,972 rows in Table 1,
but

127
00:06:29.226 --> 00:06:32.371
only 290 of them overlap with Table 2,
okay?

128
00:06:32.371 --> 00:06:37.418
When we do an inner join,
our result is just the overlap,

129
00:06:37.418 --> 00:06:41.000
just that part in the middle, okay?

130
00:06:41.000 --> 00:06:44.408
Now, no matter what join we run,
if it's an inner join or

131
00:06:44.408 --> 00:06:48.467
any of the three outer joins,
you will always get this purple part.

132
00:06:48.467 --> 00:06:49.975
You always get the overlap.

133
00:06:49.975 --> 00:06:51.216
>> Okay.

134
00:06:51.216 --> 00:06:53.523
>> Where the outer join comes in,
though, is when we say,

135
00:06:53.523 --> 00:06:55.070
we want more than that, right?

136
00:06:55.070 --> 00:06:58.717
If you just want the overlap,
inner join, done, easy, right?

137
00:06:58.717 --> 00:07:02.870
But if you want the stuff that
gets left out, we've got choices.

138
00:07:02.870 --> 00:07:06.203
And the choice always comes down
to where we want the unmatched

139
00:07:06.203 --> 00:07:07.879
records to come from, right?

140
00:07:07.879 --> 00:07:12.496
Now, when you do a join like this,
they don't like to call it Table 1 and

141
00:07:12.496 --> 00:07:17.000
Table 2, instead they call it
a left table and a right table.

142
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:20.752
Table 1 is my left table, and
Table 2 is my right table.

143
00:07:20.752 --> 00:07:23.812
Now, on a diagram like this, it makes
sense, you look at it, and you're like,

144
00:07:23.812 --> 00:07:26.250
all right, Table 1 is on the left,
and Table 2 is on the right.

145
00:07:26.250 --> 00:07:29.865
>> But is Person.Person, or
HumanResources.Employee on the left or

146
00:07:29.865 --> 00:07:30.496
the right?

147
00:07:30.496 --> 00:07:32.330
>> Right, so
that's where it gets a little tricky.

148
00:07:32.330 --> 00:07:37.698
And if we go back and look at our query,
the way it works is the FROM table,

149
00:07:37.698 --> 00:07:40.790
the first one, that's your left table.

150
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:45.780
And then the JOIN table, the next one,
that's your right table, all right?

151
00:07:45.780 --> 00:07:48.437
And if you can't remember that,
down here is where it's actually defined.

152
00:07:48.437 --> 00:07:51.901
When you say that you're doing
the join ON, right here,

153
00:07:51.901 --> 00:07:56.156
I've got one table on the left And
then equal in one table on the right,

154
00:07:56.156 --> 00:07:59.430
that was actually establishing
that relationship.

155
00:07:59.430 --> 00:08:03.340
And if I were to flip that around,
that would flip who is left and right.

156
00:08:03.340 --> 00:08:06.940
So, it usually is done this way
though where the from is left and

157
00:08:06.940 --> 00:08:08.320
the join is the right.

158
00:08:08.320 --> 00:08:11.920
But again, when in doubt look for the
equal sign and whoever's to the left is

159
00:08:11.920 --> 00:08:14.280
the left table, whoever is on
the right is the right table.

160
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:18.960
And so when we do that join,
this is what's kind of coming into play.

161
00:08:18.960 --> 00:08:20.760
Now on an inner join,
we don't care who's left or

162
00:08:20.760 --> 00:08:24.830
right cuz we just get the overlap,
but on the outer join we do

163
00:08:24.830 --> 00:08:28.660
because on an outer join I might wanna
do what's called a full outer join.

164
00:08:28.660 --> 00:08:33.490
A full outer join as I say I want
every row that doesn't match.

165
00:08:33.490 --> 00:08:39.130
I don't care if it's a person who's not
an employee, I wanna get their data.

166
00:08:39.130 --> 00:08:43.478
And so it will show me the overlap,
it'll combine that data, but

167
00:08:43.478 --> 00:08:49.271
it'll also show me the contacts that don't
have a higher date and a job title, right?

168
00:08:49.271 --> 00:08:52.560
>> Yes.
>> I'll see those, my regular people.

169
00:08:52.560 --> 00:08:56.650
But I'll also see any entries in
human resources that employ where I

170
00:08:56.650 --> 00:08:59.820
have a higher date and a job title,
but it's not mapped to a person.

171
00:08:59.820 --> 00:09:03.860
Now, usually we have database integrity
that prevents that from happening.

172
00:09:03.860 --> 00:09:08.170
So there really is no scenario where I
should have an entry in human resources

173
00:09:08.170 --> 00:09:11.220
for somebody who's not also in person,
that shouldn't happen.

174
00:09:11.220 --> 00:09:13.160
So maybe I'm doing error checking.

175
00:09:13.160 --> 00:09:14.150
I'm looking to see maybe it didn't happen.

176
00:09:14.150 --> 00:09:15.790
Maybe somebody screwed up, right?

177
00:09:15.790 --> 00:09:21.070
But typically, I'm not gonna need
the unmatched ones from Table 2.

178
00:09:21.070 --> 00:09:22.890
But I will have unmatched ones in Table 1.

179
00:09:22.890 --> 00:09:25.380
We need to understand our data
to figure out what we want.

180
00:09:25.380 --> 00:09:27.400
If I do a full outer join,

181
00:09:27.400 --> 00:09:32.390
I'm usually getting stuff that isn't
what I really want, all right.

182
00:09:32.390 --> 00:09:34.620
And so
full outer joins are pretty uncommon.

183
00:09:34.620 --> 00:09:40.300
Instead, we're normally gonna be doing
a left outer join or a right outer join.

184
00:09:40.300 --> 00:09:43.750
And in a left outer join,
you're still getting the purple,

185
00:09:43.750 --> 00:09:47.790
you're getting the overlap material in the
middle, but you're getting the unmatched

186
00:09:47.790 --> 00:09:52.930
rows from the left table,
not the unmatched rows in the right table.

187
00:09:52.930 --> 00:09:56.660
Using my employee example, a left
outer join would be more appropriate.

188
00:09:56.660 --> 00:09:59.918
If I just wanna see employees,
I do an Inner Join.

189
00:09:59.918 --> 00:10:04.500
If I wanna see employees and regular
contacts, but I want the employees to have

190
00:10:04.500 --> 00:10:08.960
their job title and hire date,
then a left outer join makes more sense.

191
00:10:08.960 --> 00:10:11.850
The unmatched records and
the matched records from Table 1.

192
00:10:11.850 --> 00:10:13.640
The overlap is the purple.

193
00:10:13.640 --> 00:10:17.040
And then no unmatched
records from Table 2.

194
00:10:17.040 --> 00:10:19.070
>> All right Don, so
I'm left with a question here, and

195
00:10:19.070 --> 00:10:22.340
we talked about the inner joins when
we said we can combine more than two

196
00:10:22.340 --> 00:10:25.460
tables to go ahead and perform that query.

197
00:10:25.460 --> 00:10:30.030
So if I could see maybe that
happening full outer join, but

198
00:10:30.030 --> 00:10:32.880
when you have a left or right outer join.

199
00:10:32.880 --> 00:10:35.640
I mean can you not have
more than two tables?

200
00:10:35.640 --> 00:10:36.510
>> You can.

201
00:10:36.510 --> 00:10:38.470
It just starts to get really complex,
right?

202
00:10:38.470 --> 00:10:40.450
>> Okay.
>> So I have an example of that.

203
00:10:40.450 --> 00:10:43.460
I wanna show you guys a little bit
later after we've kinda solidify this.

204
00:10:43.460 --> 00:10:48.100
Because when you start combining more than
one table, more than two tables, sorry.

205
00:10:48.100 --> 00:10:50.690
Doing a simple join between
two tables is easy.

206
00:10:50.690 --> 00:10:53.840
But then, when you do a third join, or
a fourth join, cuz you can do many,

207
00:10:53.840 --> 00:10:55.890
many, many, it gets really complex.

208
00:10:55.890 --> 00:11:00.020
So you need to make sure you that you
have a good understanding of each join.

209
00:11:00.020 --> 00:11:03.760
And in a later episode, we're gonna talk

210
00:11:03.760 --> 00:11:05.830
>> Okay.
>> And a derived table is where the table

00:11:05.830 --> 00:11:07.330
doesn't even necessarily exist.

00:11:07.330 --> 00:11:09.390
We run some kinda calculations.

213
00:11:09.390 --> 00:11:11.380
And it creates a temporary table.

214
00:11:11.380 --> 00:11:14.240
And we can do joins against
those temporary tables, right?

215
00:11:14.240 --> 00:11:16.380
And that's when it really gets complex.

216
00:11:16.380 --> 00:11:19.900
So as this series goes on,
we're goanna kick out the stops.

We're gonna use this chance

But for right now,

00:11:25.605 --> 00:11:28.111
You're join two tables, make sure we got
a good understanding on foundation one.

220
00:11:28.111 --> 00:11:30.834
>> Baby steps.
>> And I promise you before we're done

221
00:11:30.834 --> 00:11:35.350
with the join episodes, I will show

00:11:35.350 --> 00:11:38.470
But we're gonna see that even more when
we get to derive tables cuz you almost

223
00:11:38.470 --> 00:11:40.770
always do joins on derive tables.

224
00:11:40.770 --> 00:11:43.220
It's not a guarantee,
but typically you will.

00:11:43.220 --> 00:11:45.220
So we'll get a chance to see that.

00:11:45.220 --> 00:11:48.520
All right, now, the last one I talked
about was the left outer join, right?

227
00:11:48.520 --> 00:11:53.340
And, in my scenario, where I've got the
person not person, and the employee table,

228
00:11:53.340 --> 00:11:55.480
that make sense,
that I would do a left outer join.

229
00:11:55.480 --> 00:11:57.690
Sometimes it's the other way around,
though.

00:11:57.690 --> 00:12:00.610
Sometimes I might have a list

00:12:00.610 --> 00:12:02.200
And a list of orders on the right side.

00:12:02.200 --> 00:12:05.950
And I might have orders on the right

00:12:05.950 --> 00:12:08.040
Or orders that haven't

00:12:08.040 --> 00:12:10.660
You see this with sales leads a lot,

00:12:10.660 --> 00:12:14.120
I get a sales lead and it hasn't been

00:12:14.120 --> 00:12:18.020
It exists, it's in that right table,

237
00:12:18.020 --> 00:12:21.730
And then the next scenario will change

00:12:21.730 --> 00:12:25.280
like what I'm showing you on my screen now

00:12:25.280 --> 00:12:27.680
I might want the unmatch
ones in the right.

240
00:12:27.680 --> 00:12:31.060
So on the left,
I might have my sales people.

00:12:31.060 --> 00:12:35.660
And it's a pretty, finite number, I'm

00:12:35.660 --> 00:12:40.730
And then every sale or every lead over

00:12:40.730 --> 00:12:44.020
The overlap, those are gonna be

00:12:44.020 --> 00:12:46.060
That's good, they've already

00:12:46.060 --> 00:12:50.860
What's left out over here are things that

00:12:50.860 --> 00:12:53.650
And a right outer join would show me both.

247
00:12:53.650 --> 00:12:55.590
Now, one thing I want to throw out here.

00:12:55.590 --> 00:13:00.850
If I'm just looking for sales that

00:13:00.850 --> 00:13:03.040
I don't need a join for that, right?

00:13:03.040 --> 00:13:06.480
Because they'll have
an entry in that table

00:13:06.480 --> 00:13:08.720
that indicates who the salesperson is.

00:13:08.720 --> 00:13:11.381
And if it's empty that's a null value,
I don't need a join,

00:13:11.381 --> 00:13:12.926
I can just query that table and say.

00:13:12.926 --> 00:13:13.448
>> Do a search.

255
00:13:13.448 --> 00:13:17.572
>> Yeah, show me any value or any row
that doesn't have a sales through and

00:13:17.572 --> 00:13:18.750
you're done.

00:13:18.750 --> 00:13:21.620
So if you're just trying to find

00:13:21.620 --> 00:13:23.930
>> So
why would we use those unmatched records?

259
00:13:23.930 --> 00:13:27.100
>> When you want both,
when I want the matched records and

00:13:27.100 --> 00:13:30.410

I wanna see a whole of my leads, right?

261
00:13:30.410 --> 00:13:36.170
And an example there would be,
where I'm trying to find out

262
00:13:36.170 --> 00:13:41.290
who's the person with the most leads, and

263
00:13:41.290 --> 00:13:43.710
So that I can then assign records to
the person that has the least, and

264
00:13:43.710 --> 00:13:47.110
I can do it all in one table and we can
get it all kinda calculated in one place.

265
00:13:47.110 --> 00:13:49.610
It's not a one-size-fits-all scenario.

266
00:13:49.610 --> 00:13:54.100
You've gotta look at it, and determine
is this actually what I wanna do.

267
00:13:54.100 --> 00:13:56.550
And I'll be honest with you,
outer joins for

268
00:13:56.550 --> 00:13:59.540
me I can usually find some other way
to get the information that I want.

269
00:13:59.540 --> 00:14:03.540
It's nice to have the tool because again
the server's doing the work for us.

270
00:14:03.540 --> 00:14:08.040
And it's also nice to know about the tool
because a lot of people don't realize with

00:14:08.040 --> 00:14:11.000

getting all of your records.

272
00:14:11.000 --> 00:14:12.680
That there's things that
are being left behind,

273
00:14:12.680 --> 00:14:16.330
and there's that potential that you get
bad records that sit there for years and

274
00:14:16.330 --> 00:14:19.390
you never know about it because
the inner joins have been hiding it.

275
00:14:19.390 --> 00:14:21.755
And if you don't look at the underlying
tables, you won't see it.

276
00:14:21.755 --> 00:14:23.500
Outter joins make sure we get
some of that information.

277
00:14:23.500 --> 00:14:26.170
So just to recap real quick,

00:14:26.170 --> 00:14:28.325
Let me run through these
diagrams one more time.

00:14:28.325 --> 00:14:31.130
>> Okay.

280
00:14:31.130 --> 00:14:36.000
which gets all the matches and
any unmatched record from the right table.

281
00:14:36.000 --> 00:14:38.490
A left outer join,
which is all the matches and

282
00:14:38.490 --> 00:14:41.070
all the unmatched records
from the left table.

283
00:14:41.070 --> 00:14:45.650
And a full outer join which gets
all the unmatched records from

284
00:14:45.650 --> 00:14:50.305
both tables as well as the overlap,
this gives me the full set of data.

285
00:14:50.305 --> 00:14:55.100
They're all joins, they're just
including a lot more than an inner join.

>> All right so

I do have examples

We already saw,

00:15:12.480 --> 00:15:17.120
that when I did that inner join here,

I don't have to type inner, I can just

00:15:20.630 --> 00:15:23.200
but if I want to type it out

00:15:24.880 --> 00:15:28.970
When I do that,

And looking at all these different people,

And changing them,

In this case, the table on the left,

with a bad territory number,

555
00:28:43.390 --> 00:28:46.090
there's nothing extra in the left
table that this will add in.

556
00:28:46.090 --> 00:28:47.920
So we shouldn't see a difference.

557
00:28:47.920 --> 00:28:48.982
I'm using my technical word of shouldn't.

558
00:28:48.982 --> 00:28:50.229
>> [LAUGH] yeah [LAUGH].
>> That way, if it does,

559
00:28:50.229 --> 00:28:51.400
it's not my fault.

560
00:28:51.400 --> 00:28:55.060
But when I run it, we should get
the same basic information back.

561
00:28:55.060 --> 00:28:58.210
And as I look at it here, so
I'm now doing a FULL OUTER JOIN.

562
00:28:58.210 --> 00:28:59.520
And [CROSSTALK] as I look at my entries.

563
00:28:59.520 --> 00:29:00.205
>> I don't see the nulls,
unless they put them at the bottom.

564
00:29:00.205 --> 00:29:05.020
>> You know, it looks like it did,
so let's go over here and yeah.

565
00:29:05.020 --> 00:29:05.520
>> Okay.
>> I must have-

566
00:29:05.520 --> 00:29:06.267
>> Sort it.

567
00:29:06.267 --> 00:29:07.827
>> Sometimes you hit an index,

568
00:29:07.827 --> 00:29:11.142
and I talked about indexes
a little bit in the first episode,

569
00:29:11.142 --> 00:29:15.630
where if there's an index created on
the table, it puts it in a certain order.

570
00:29:15.630 --> 00:29:19.310
Sometimes SQL will look at it and say,
well, it would be faster to use the index.

571
00:29:19.310 --> 00:29:22.760
And the index happens to already be
alphabetized or sorted or whatever.

572
00:29:22.760 --> 00:29:26.080
Other times, it'll look at it and
it'll say, there's no index, so

573
00:29:26.080 --> 00:29:29.311
I just gotta go and look at the table and
you get a table or something.

574
00:29:29.311 --> 00:29:32.615
It might have been that or it might also
just be the fact that we're pulling from

575
00:29:32.615 --> 00:29:36.045
two different tables and there's nulls
in each, so how does it organize those.

576
00:29:36.045 --> 00:29:37.275
And so it lumps them down at the bottom,
but they are there.

577
00:29:37.275 --> 00:29:39.532
>> [CROSSTALK] Does the yellow
have any tie in there?

578
00:29:39.532 --> 00:29:43.830
I think you might have mentioned that
before for the actual sorting there.

579
00:29:43.830 --> 00:29:46.544
>> So null is special, and
that's why it's yellow.

580
00:29:46.544 --> 00:29:47.997
>> Okay [LAUGH].
>> Null, technically,

581
00:29:47.997 --> 00:29:49.325
is absolutely nothing.

582
00:29:49.325 --> 00:29:52.160
>> Right.
>> So how do you sort absolutely nothing?

583
00:29:52.160 --> 00:29:53.050
It doesn't come before.

584
00:29:53.050 --> 00:29:53.710
It doesn't come after.

585
00:29:53.710 --> 00:29:55.060
It really can't be sorted, right?

586
00:29:55.060 --> 00:29:58.696
And so it shows it yellow here, just it's
kind of like a warning to let us know.

587
00:29:58.696 --> 00:29:59.580
>> Okay.

588
00:29:59.580 --> 00:30:01.720
>> I'm gonna write NULL in there, but

589
00:30:01.720 --> 00:30:06.240
it's not actually the letters NULL,
it's actually nothing.

590
00:30:06.240 --> 00:30:09.120
I could create a territory and
call it NULL, right,

591
00:30:09.120 --> 00:30:12.172
and then it will show up as white

592
00:30:12.172 --> 00:30:14.545
>> Okay.
>> N-U-L-L, so that's why it's yellow,

593
00:30:14.545 --> 00:30:17.118
is to give me that
differentiation to know that,

594
00:30:17.118 --> 00:30:19.900
this is actually empty
versus just making it empty.

595
00:30:19.900 --> 00:30:24.546
Because they can't make it truly empty
cuz then we wouldn't be able to tell it

596
00:30:24.546 --> 00:30:25.521
apart-
>> Have that in.

597
00:30:25.521 --> 00:30:26.627
>> in space.
>> Okay.

598
00:30:26.627 --> 00:30:29.617
>> Like I could have a solid, just have

599
00:30:29.617 --> 00:30:30.270
when it isn't.

600
00:30:30.270 --> 00:30:33.255
So it's really,
null is kind of a special thing.

601
00:30:33.255 --> 00:30:37.570
We're gonna talk about it in some of
the other episodes too, because it's

602
00:30:37.570 --> 00:30:42.850
really the absence of any data and that
is a lot different than just being blank.

603
00:30:42.850 --> 00:30:43.730
>> Okay.

604
00:30:43.730 --> 00:30:46.730
>> But right there we get a chance
to see that right outer join and

605
00:30:46.730 --> 00:30:48.330
how that one functions.

606
00:30:48.330 --> 00:30:50.830
At the end of the day, a right outer join,

607
00:30:50.830 --> 00:30:55.470
a left outer join, a full outer join,
they function the same way.

608
00:30:55.470 --> 00:30:56.661
You're just making a choice.

609
00:30:56.661 --> 00:31:01.315
You're making a choice between,
do I want all of the unmatching rows?

610
00:31:01.315 --> 00:31:02.746
Or just the unmatching rows from the left?

611
00:31:02.746 --> 00:31:06.262
Or just the unmatching rows from
the right and that's it, and

612
00:31:06.262 --> 00:31:10.060
it's based on your needs which
one of these you're gonna choose.

613
00:31:10.060 --> 00:31:12.130
So if you don't need any one of them
at all, in which case you'll say,

614
00:31:12.130 --> 00:31:15.320
forget it I'm sticking with an INNER JOIN,
I just get the matches that's got the data

615
00:31:15.320 --> 00:31:19.450
that I wanted, and you'll find that often
times that's exactly what you want.

616
00:31:19.450 --> 00:31:21.690

I mean this is like confession time, Don.

>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

You asked about doing

00:31:41.154 --> 00:31:43.570

>> I'll make an executive decision here.

00:31:43.570 --> 00:31:45.970
We'll do a part three and
in part three, I wanna show you, guys,

00:31:45.970 --> 00:31:48.680
doing multiple joins.

630
00:31:48.680 --> 00:31:50.260
And I also wanna show you,

this is where we really kick

632
00:31:53.570 --> 00:31:54.348
>> [LAUGH] Nested joins okay.
>> Nested joins, yup.

633
00:31:54.348 --> 00:31:58.772
Where you have a join where one of
the tables you're pulling from is

635
00:32:01.310 --> 00:32:01.810
It's really-
>> Good.

636
00:32:01.810 --> 00:32:04.794
[LAUGH] >> It's kind of like Inception,

00:32:04.794 --> 00:32:05.473
You know,

638
00:32:05.473 --> 00:32:06.914
the dream in a dream?
>> [LAUGH]

00:32:06.914 --> 00:32:09.514
>> But we'll get a chance to see that.

00:32:09.514 --> 00:32:12.840
Those, again, are far less used, and

00:32:12.840 --> 00:32:14.520
multiple joins,
that's actually pretty common.

642
00:32:14.520 --> 00:32:16.950
But nested joins are less common, and

00:32:16.950 --> 00:32:20.660

00:32:20.660 --> 00:32:23.700
That derived tables usually

00:32:23.700 --> 00:32:26.142
But it is something you incur, so

646
00:32:26.142 --> 00:32:27.370

00:32:27.370 --> 00:32:28.270

00:32:28.270 --> 00:32:32.911

episodes.description: In this episode, Don wraps up discussing how to use the JOIN clause to combine results from multiple tables. He builds on part 1 and part 2 by explaining how multiple JOIN clauses can be nested together and that you can even perform a JOIN between a table and itself.
episodes.title: Combining Results with JOIN Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to add data to a table in SQL by using the INSERT statement. He demonstrates adding a single record, and explains a few methods for adding multiple records at the same time.
episodes.title: Adding Data with INSERT

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to modify data in a SQL database table by using the UPDATE statement. He demonstrates modifying a single record, and explains a few methods for modifying multiple records at the same time. He ends the show by explaining a common mistake that can lead to data loss.
episodes.title: Changing Data with UPDATE

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to remove data from a SQL database table by using the DELETE statement. First, he demonstrates deleting a single value by using the UPDATE statement. Next, he demonstrates deleting a single record, and explains a few methods for deleting multiple records at the same time. He ends the show by explaining a common mistake that can lead to data loss.
episodes.title: Removing Data with DELETE

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the OUTPUT clause. He demonstrates how to use the OUTPUT clause to get better result feedback from SQL server, and he also demonstrates how the OUTPUT clause can be used for backup and auditing purposes.
episodes.title: Recording Changes with OUTPUT

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to SQL functions. He begins by demonstrating some simple functions and explains how to use more advanced functions that require input parameters.
episodes.title: Querying Data with Functions

00:24:36.597 --> 00:24:38.599
If it's an XML, if it's a query

635
00:24:38.599 --> 00:24:40.902
on another relational database server,

636
00:24:40.902 --> 00:24:43.726
if it's a row on another Microsoft SQL server,

637
00:24:43.726 --> 00:24:47.781
if it's a JSON file or just a straight up ODBC data source,

638
00:24:47.781 --> 00:24:51.698
which means Oracle, MySQL, MariaDB, PostgreSQL,

639
00:24:53.343 --> 00:24:54.712
all those other guys that are out there

640
00:24:54.712 --> 00:24:56.509
that you can connect to using OPENDATASOURCE,

641
00:24:56.509 --> 00:24:59.551
even Microsoft Access, you can connect to that

642
00:24:59.551 --> 00:25:00.792
and pull in data.

643
00:25:00.792 --> 00:25:02.666
That's really powerful stuff you can do

644
00:25:02.666 --> 00:25:04.320
right here with a function.

645
00:25:04.320 --> 00:25:07.672
You'd be surprised the things that you can do,

646
00:25:07.672 --> 00:25:09.184
but you can go even further when

647
00:25:09.184 --> 00:25:11.143
you create a custom function, so I wanted to mention that

648
00:25:11.143 --> 00:25:12.117
here in this episode.

649
00:25:12.117 --> 00:25:13.792
We're not gonna do it here, but we'll see it

650
00:25:13.792 --> 00:25:15.175
later on in the series.

651
00:25:15.175 --> 00:25:17.331
Let's focus on the ones that are built in to the system

652
00:25:17.331 --> 00:25:18.631
before we start getting in there

653
00:25:18.631 --> 00:25:19.912
and really kind of cranking in

654
00:25:19.912 --> 00:25:21.567
and starting to customize things.

655
00:25:21.567 --> 00:25:23.671
<v ->Well Don, I guess that leaves us with</v>

656
00:25:23.671 --> 00:25:26.013
one good question is, we've talked about

657
00:25:26.013 --> 00:25:28.893
the functions that are there, that are created

658
00:25:28.893 --> 00:25:30.602
and available for us, then we have the ones

659
00:25:30.602 --> 00:25:32.008
that we can't create.

660
00:25:32.008 --> 00:25:33.175
Do they have to be one or the other,

661
00:25:33.175 --> 00:25:34.653
can you combine the two as well?

662
00:25:34.653 --> 00:25:37.154
<v ->Yeah, you can do a lot.</v>

663
00:25:37.154 --> 00:25:38.305
(laughing)

664
00:25:38.305 --> 00:25:39.208
And the sky's the limit.

665
00:25:39.208 --> 00:25:40.754
It really, it sounds kind of cheesy,

666
00:25:40.754 --> 00:25:42.952
but you're really only limited by your own knowledge.

667
00:25:42.952 --> 00:25:46.696
Functions, by definition, can do anything you can think of.

668
00:25:46.696 --> 00:25:49.072
You can write the code for it.

669
00:25:49.072 --> 00:25:50.455
There's times when a stored procedure

670
00:25:50.455 --> 00:25:52.183
works a little better, but the function,

671
00:25:52.183 --> 00:25:54.483
it can do a ton of magic.

672
00:25:54.483 --> 00:25:55.946
The trick is just knowing what's available,

673
00:25:55.946 --> 00:25:57.405
what's there, knowing that documentation,

674
00:25:57.405 --> 00:25:58.861
that's a big part of it.

675
00:25:58.861 --> 00:26:00.084
Now, what I've shown you so far

676
00:26:00.084 --> 00:26:01.293
was basically an introduction.

677
00:26:01.293 --> 00:26:02.983
We saw how to use a function,

678
00:26:02.983 --> 00:26:04.423
we saw how to feed it some input,

679
00:26:04.423 --> 00:26:07.144
and we saw some data come back, we rounded a number.

680
00:26:07.144 --> 00:26:08.402
Very exciting.

681
00:26:08.402 --> 00:26:11.623
You can do that across entire tables,

682
00:26:11.623 --> 00:26:13.461
and you can even do it in other areas

683
00:26:13.461 --> 00:26:15.799
where you want more specialized data to come back,

684
00:26:15.799 --> 00:26:16.984
and I want to talk about that,

685
00:26:16.984 --> 00:26:18.584
but I know I'm running a little bit low on time.

686
00:26:18.584 --> 00:26:19.503
<v Daniel>Just a little bit.</v>

687
00:26:19.503 --> 00:26:21.395
<v ->Let's do this, let's break in to part two,</v>

688
00:26:21.395 --> 00:26:24.005
and in part two, I want to start talking about

689
00:26:24.005 --> 00:26:27.155
the different ways that functions --

690
00:26:27.155 --> 00:26:28.215
<v Daniel>Function (laughing).</v>

691
00:26:28.215 --> 00:26:30.591
<v ->Function, all right, it's kind of a bit redundant there.</v>

692
00:26:30.591 --> 00:26:33.217
There are actually different types.

693
00:26:33.217 --> 00:26:35.866
When I look on Microsoft's site and I see mathematical,

694
00:26:35.866 --> 00:26:37.882
that's kind of a category of functions,

695
00:26:37.882 --> 00:26:39.188
and there's all these different

696
00:26:39.188 --> 00:26:40.633
mathematical functions available,

697
00:26:40.633 --> 00:26:43.153
but they work in different ways.

698
00:26:43.153 --> 00:26:45.063
Some of them work one way,

699
00:26:45.063 --> 00:26:46.287
others work a slightly different way,

700
00:26:46.287 --> 00:26:47.387
and it's important to understand

701
00:26:47.387 --> 00:26:48.971
what type of data we're getting back,

702
00:26:48.971 --> 00:26:50.195
'cause that's going to influence

703
00:26:50.195 --> 00:26:51.289
the way that we're able to use these.

704
00:26:51.289 --> 00:26:52.604
I want to spend some time on that,

705
00:26:52.604 --> 00:26:54.116
and we'll have to do that in part two.

706
00:26:54.116 --> 00:26:55.177
<v ->All right, not a problem,</v>

707
00:26:55.177 --> 00:26:56.761
we'll definitely break out into that part two.

708
00:26:56.761 --> 00:26:58.220
Definitely join us back there.

709
00:26:58.220 --> 00:26:59.749
Don, thanks for getting us this far

710
00:26:59.749 --> 00:27:02.251
and when it comes to functions inside of T-SQL

711
00:27:02.251 --> 00:27:04.595
looking forward to seeing how that culminates

712
00:27:04.595 --> 00:27:07.292
in some of the more advanced functionality in part two.

713
00:27:07.292 --> 00:27:08.444
Join us for that.

714
00:27:08.444 --> 00:27:09.615
As for this episode, though,

715
00:27:09.615 --> 00:27:11.179 line:15% 
we're going to go ahead and call it a day.

716
00:27:11.179 --> 00:27:13.859 line:15% 
Signing off for ITPro.TV, I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

717
00:27:13.859 --> 00:27:15.028 line:15% 
<v ->And I'm Don Pezet.</v>

718
00:27:15.028 --> 00:27:17.549 line:15% 
<v ->We'll see you next time.</v>

719
00:27:17.549 --> 00:27:20.216 line:15% 
(intense music)

720
00:27:23.527 --> 00:27:27.444
<v Announcer>Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.`</v>

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues exploring functions in Transact-SQL. He explains some of the variations found between functions. Examples include scalar vs table-valued functions as well as deterministic vs non-deterministic functions
episodes.title: Querying Data with Functions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to combine multiple results together in order to meet the needs of your organization. He shows how to use the GROUP BY and HAVING clauses to aggregate results into a smaller data set.
episodes.title: Aggregating Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues working with functions in Transact-SQL. This time, he focuses on performing arithmetic by making use of the numerous matehmatical functions included with T-SQL.
episodes.title: Performing Arithmetic

episodes.description: In this episode, Don examins how Transact-SQL handles dates. He demontrates multiple ways to retrieve the current date and time from a SQL server. He then demonstrates a series of functions that can be used to modify the date to support your queries.
episodes.title: Working with Dates

episodes.description: In this episode, Don wraps up the series on functions by examining some of the system functions built into Microsoft SQL server. He explains how user and session data can be retrieved and then demonstrates how to combine that data with the OUTPUT clause to create a better logging and auditing solution.
episodes.title: System Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to SQL data types. He explains what data types do and then walks the viewers through several of the default data types found in Microsoft SQL Server. He ends the show by demonstrating how data types can support and interfere with your queries.
episodes.title: Data Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues discussing SQL data types. He demonstrates how data types can effect your queries. At the end of the show, he discusses the IDENTITY special modifier that can significantly impact how data types are applied.
episodes.title: Data Types Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses how you can create custom data types to meet the needs of your organization. He explains how programatic data types can be developed with the Microsoft .NET Framework and he also shows how custom data types can be easily deployed via aliases in Transact-SQL.
episodes.title: Custom Data Types

episodes.description: a
episodes.title: Converting Data Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the challenges of working with multiple data types. He then demonstrates how to use CAST and CONVERT to alter the data type of query results to meet our needs.
episodes.title: Converting Data Types Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how NULL values can impact our queries. He then demonstrates using CASE, ISNULL and COALESCE to ensure we get the results we need.
episodes.title: Conditions and Nulls
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.354
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.354 --> 00:00:02.415
I'm your host Don.

3
00:00:02.415 --> 00:00:06.528
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.528 --> 00:00:08.263
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.263 --> 00:00:11.480
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.480 --> 00:00:12.022
>> Hello and

7
00:00:12.022 --> 00:00:16.210
thank you for choosing ITProTV
helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:16.210 --> 00:00:20.700
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on with querying data with Transact-SQL.

9
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:23.230
In this episode, conditions and NULLs.

10
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:25.375
Aha, that's interesting topics.

11
00:00:25.375 --> 00:00:27.650
[LAUGH] And if I'm getting talking
with Don Pezet about that.

12
00:00:27.650 --> 00:00:29.210
Don great to have you here, thanks.

13
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:29.729
>> Great to be back Zack.

14
00:00:29.729 --> 00:00:32.420
Like you said we are gonna talk about
conditions and NULLs during this episode.

15
00:00:32.420 --> 00:00:35.486
And I know those are two terms that
we haven't really worked with so

16
00:00:35.486 --> 00:00:39.266
far that I've thrown together, if you've
been watching the episodes in order,

17
00:00:39.266 --> 00:00:42.150
we've spent the last few
talking about datatypes.

18
00:00:42.150 --> 00:00:45.340
And there's some special
scenarios that can occur

19
00:00:45.340 --> 00:00:47.910
that kind of goes along with data
types that I wanted to cover,

20
00:00:47.910 --> 00:00:50.610
but didn't quite fit into
any of those episodes.

21
00:00:50.610 --> 00:00:55.280
So this one is gonna be a little more
like in TV when they do the recap episode

22
00:00:55.280 --> 00:00:58.810
where we'll throw together a couple
of topics that just didn't quite fit.

23
00:00:58.810 --> 00:01:02.200
We're gonna talk about conditions
applied with the CASE command.

24
00:01:02.200 --> 00:01:06.446
We're gonna talk about testing for
nulls using is NULL and is not NULL.

25
00:01:06.446 --> 00:01:08.890
And we're gonna talk a little
bit about the coalesce command.

26
00:01:08.890 --> 00:01:13.294
All three help us to deal with situations
where you have null values, and how you

27
00:01:13.294 --> 00:01:17.897
can handle that, because it doesn't matter
what data type you've got assigned,

28
00:01:17.897 --> 00:01:19.757
if a value is NULL, it's empty.

29
00:01:19.757 --> 00:01:21.302
And we've got to know how to handle and

30
00:01:21.302 --> 00:01:23.290
work with that, so
it doesn't break our query.

31
00:01:23.290 --> 00:01:25.960
So we're gonna see all that
right here in this episode.

32
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:28.800
>> So Dylan, what kind of
conditions can we implement in SQL?

33
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:33.340
>> All right, so conditions,
if you think about the word conditions,

34
00:01:33.340 --> 00:01:34.510
it can mean a lot of things.

35
00:01:34.510 --> 00:01:38.970
Like you can give somebody an ultimatum,
that you clean your room or

36
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:40.135
you're grounded for six months.

37
00:01:40.135 --> 00:01:42.226
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so that's the conditions that you

38
00:01:42.226 --> 00:01:44.170
give them, like terms of surrender.

39
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:49.241
But a condition can also be used for
other things to say like,

40
00:01:49.241 --> 00:01:55.120
if a certain test comes back with one
result then we make one decision.

41
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:57.630
If a test comes back with a different
result we make a different decision.

42
00:01:57.630 --> 00:01:59.520
And we can do the same
thing with our data.

43
00:01:59.520 --> 00:02:03.840
We can say, hey if there's a value present
we're going to take one action, and

44
00:02:03.840 --> 00:02:06.650
if it's NULL or if it's empty,
we'll take some other action, or

45
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:08.860
we'll put a fake value in there.

46
00:02:08.860 --> 00:02:12.840
Maybe it's, you've got an orders table,
and in the orders table,

47
00:02:12.840 --> 00:02:16.300
when somebody buys something,
there's a dollar value associated with it.

48
00:02:16.300 --> 00:02:18.445
Well, maybe the order was voided,
so it never went through, so

49
00:02:18.445 --> 00:02:20.573
there is no dollar value associated
with it, it's just NULL.

50
00:02:20.573 --> 00:02:23.570
Well in a report,
that's gonna screw things up.

51
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:28.450
So instead, I might create a condition
that says, if I find an order

52
00:02:28.450 --> 00:02:33.080
that has a NULL value assigned for
its dollar amount, make it a zero instead.

53
00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:36.490
And now I give it this criteria of,
well make it a zero, and

54
00:02:36.490 --> 00:02:37.630
a zero won't break my report.

55
00:02:37.630 --> 00:02:40.340
Now I see, yeah, there was a $0
transaction because it was a void.

56
00:02:40.340 --> 00:02:42.000
It makes sense.

57
00:02:42.000 --> 00:02:46.810
So that's what conditions are all about
is defining how to change data from

58
00:02:46.810 --> 00:02:49.660
one particular value to another
under certain circumstances.

59
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:53.770
It's an incredibly useful
thing in other areas as well.

60
00:02:53.770 --> 00:02:56.308
The command that we use
is actually called CASE.

61
00:02:56.308 --> 00:02:56.839
>> Mm-hm.

62
00:02:56.839 --> 00:03:02.034
>> So think about just in case.

63
00:03:02.034 --> 00:03:06.590
So in case this happens to be one thing,
I'm gonna do this other.

64
00:03:06.590 --> 00:03:10.040
So we're kind of planning contingencies
with how the data comes through.

65
00:03:10.040 --> 00:03:11.302
And we can use it for
a lot of really cool things.

66
00:03:11.302 --> 00:03:16.345
Maybe I want to have a database
that indexes all the movies.

67
00:03:16.345 --> 00:03:21.266
So I've got all these movies indexed and
in each line, each row I've got the movie

68
00:03:21.266 --> 00:03:24.990
title, the director, the actors,
and the year it came out.

69
00:03:26.200 --> 00:03:30.250
Well, in the movie world,
they have these, they call them the ages.

70
00:03:30.250 --> 00:03:32.110
Like the age of the silver screen, and

71
00:03:32.110 --> 00:03:37.360
then you have your classic movies which
all came out mostly in the 20s to 40s.

72
00:03:37.360 --> 00:03:38.300
>> Like genres.

73
00:03:38.300 --> 00:03:38.850
>> Yeah.

74
00:03:38.850 --> 00:03:39.795
>> Yeah.

75
00:03:39.795 --> 00:03:42.200
>> And I might not store that
in the database to say like,

76
00:03:42.200 --> 00:03:45.600
this movie came out in 1925, and
so it's considered a classic.

77
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:50.640
This other movie came out in 1997, it's
not considered a classic, it's modern.

78
00:03:50.640 --> 00:03:55.180
So, I could use a condition to say,
when I retrieve this data,

79
00:03:55.180 --> 00:04:00.500
don't show me that the movie was made in
1920, show me that the movie is classic.

80
00:04:00.500 --> 00:04:06.635
And I can set that up to say,
if the year is between 1910 and

81
00:04:06.635 --> 00:04:09.370
1940, show that it's a classic.

82
00:04:09.370 --> 00:04:16.440
If it's between 1941 and 1980, show it
as a vintage, or something like that.

83
00:04:16.440 --> 00:04:18.560
And then if it's 1980 or
newer, show it as modern.

84
00:04:18.560 --> 00:04:20.400
And so I'm changing the value.

85
00:04:20.400 --> 00:04:25.180
In the database, I actually have a number
stored but I don't want that in my report.

86
00:04:25.180 --> 00:04:27.450
I want to know which of these
criterias it falls under.

87
00:04:27.450 --> 00:04:30.210
Or you might do it like low risk,
moderate, high risk or

88
00:04:30.210 --> 00:04:31.840
however it is you want to classify things.

89
00:04:31.840 --> 00:04:34.280
That's what the CASE command lets us do.

90
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:39.280
And if you got NULLs you can say,
if it's NULL put it like this and

91
00:04:39.280 --> 00:04:40.770
have it say, unknown.

92
00:04:40.770 --> 00:04:43.065
Or have it say zero, or
have a say whatever you want.

93
00:04:43.065 --> 00:04:47.250
So you can test and check for that,
and now you've got a value provided.

94
00:04:47.250 --> 00:04:50.030
That's gonna help ensure that
when you run your queries,

95
00:04:50.030 --> 00:04:52.035
if you come across a NULL value,
it won't break your query.

96
00:04:52.035 --> 00:04:53.045
It doesn't mess things up.

97
00:04:53.045 --> 00:04:56.830
Especially if you're grouping by a column,
then any NULL value in there will get

98
00:04:56.830 --> 00:05:00.350
grouped together based on this NULL,
based on this absence of something.

99
00:05:00.350 --> 00:05:01.928
It's not normally something
you want to group by.

100
00:05:01.928 --> 00:05:05.340
Well here, we can change it to a different
value and it makes a little more sense.

101
00:05:06.700 --> 00:05:10.030
>> Can you give us an example
of how CASE is gonna be used?

102
00:05:10.030 --> 00:05:12.410
>> Yeah, sure,
the CASE command is kind of a weird one.

103
00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:15.050
So the way the syntax works for
it is strange.

104
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:16.370
Let me show you how it works.

105
00:05:16.370 --> 00:05:18.020
I'm gonna pull some data out of a table.

106
00:05:18.020 --> 00:05:21.850
And I'm not gonna use the CASE
command right here in the beginning.

107
00:05:21.850 --> 00:05:23.940
I'm just gonna do a straight
up SELECT statement.

108
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:28.060
I'm gonna SELECT the ProductID and

109
00:05:28.060 --> 00:05:31.970
the name from a table.

110
00:05:31.970 --> 00:05:36.500
So I'm pulling just these two columns,
and I'm gonna pull them from

111
00:05:36.500 --> 00:05:41.340
the Production.Product table.

112
00:05:41.340 --> 00:05:44.140
So that's what I'm gonna query, and
I'm gonna get some information back.

113
00:05:44.140 --> 00:05:48.090
So I'm seeing a list of my products and
their ProductID.

114
00:05:48.090 --> 00:05:52.513
And if I look around in there, you know,
this is just standard information here,

115
00:05:52.513 --> 00:05:56.758
they each have their ProductIDs, and
I shouldn't have any NULL values in here.

116
00:05:56.758 --> 00:06:00.570
When you create a table like this,
it's gotta have some critical things.

117
00:06:00.570 --> 00:06:02.180
A ProductID is pretty critical.

118
00:06:02.180 --> 00:06:05.750
So that's more than likely an identity
column, or at least a unique column,

119
00:06:05.750 --> 00:06:08.050
to ensure I don't have two
products with the same ID.

120
00:06:08.050 --> 00:06:10.080
So I don't expect to find any NULLs.

121
00:06:10.080 --> 00:06:11.210
There's 500 rows though, and

122
00:06:11.210 --> 00:06:13.188
I don't expect to stand here and
look at each one either.

123
00:06:13.188 --> 00:06:13.840
>> [LAUGH] No.

124
00:06:13.840 --> 00:06:15.460
>> But
odds are there's not gonna be any NULLs.

125
00:06:15.460 --> 00:06:17.360
I'll bring in some columns
with NULLs in a moment.

126
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:20.238
But right now as I look
at these ProductIDs,

127
00:06:20.238 --> 00:06:24.590
each ProductID is incrementing
by a certain number.

128
00:06:24.590 --> 00:06:28.840
And maybe there's categories
associated with these numbers.

129
00:06:28.840 --> 00:06:33.900
So for example, this sample database that
