it, representing it on the screen.

356
00:18:36.390 --> 00:18:40.030
All important ways to make sure
that null doesn't break our query,

357
00:18:40.030 --> 00:18:42.440
and that we are getting
the information that we want.

358
00:18:42.440 --> 00:18:46.360
>> Well, are there any other special
ways that we can handle null values?

359
00:18:46.360 --> 00:18:48.470
>> Yeah, there's a few,

360
00:18:48.470 --> 00:18:53.830
this scenerio works really well when we're
dealing with column data, with tuples.

361
00:18:53.830 --> 00:18:57.510
So I'm really just checking for null in
products of category ID, and that's it.

362
00:18:58.550 --> 00:19:01.388
It gets a little more tricky when
you're going horizontally like this,

363
00:19:01.388 --> 00:19:03.075
when you're actually checking a record.

364
00:19:03.075 --> 00:19:06.998
So, for example,
I might wanna pull record 864, and

365
00:19:06.998 --> 00:19:12.258
I know that a couple of columns here
might be null, they might be populated.

366
00:19:12.258 --> 00:19:16.632
So maybe I have a table structured,
let me do a new query so

367
00:19:16.632 --> 00:19:19.285
this doesn't get too confusing.

368
00:19:19.285 --> 00:19:24.155
Maybe I'll get a table structured
where I have some kind of product ID,

369
00:19:24.155 --> 00:19:27.930
and it's followed by a name for
the product.

370
00:19:27.930 --> 00:19:32.680
And then I have things like small,
medium, large,

371
00:19:32.680 --> 00:19:38.400
I'm thinking clothing here,
extra large, 2XL, and 3XL.

372
00:19:38.400 --> 00:19:44.220
And when I put in a new
shirt into my system,

373
00:19:44.220 --> 00:19:46.540
I come and I populate it,
I give it an ID, I give it a name.

374
00:19:46.540 --> 00:19:49.187
So this is going to be a shirt, right.

375
00:19:49.187 --> 00:19:52.044
And then maybe these are binary bits,
so 0 or 1.

376
00:19:52.044 --> 00:19:56.609
If they're available in small, I may get
a 1, if they're not available in small,

377
00:19:56.609 --> 00:19:57.396
I make it a 0.

378
00:19:57.396 --> 00:20:00.722
Or maybe I don't even bother
with the binary thing,

379
00:20:00.722 --> 00:20:04.359
I just say if there's a value in here,
I have it in small.

380
00:20:04.359 --> 00:20:08.250
If it's null,
then I don't have it in small, right?

381
00:20:08.250 --> 00:20:09.893
Maybe we're using null for that purpose.

382
00:20:09.893 --> 00:20:15.717
And so, I might have, like where
it's null for the first two sizes,

383
00:20:15.717 --> 00:20:21.654
and then we say maybe even a quantity
number, like I have 15 or 16.

384
00:20:21.654 --> 00:20:28.596
I have no small, no medium, 16 large,
30 extra large, and so on, right?

385
00:20:28.596 --> 00:20:33.310
So, I'm identifying based on whether
there's a number in that field.

386
00:20:33.310 --> 00:20:36.670
Now, normally I would do this with a 0,
I don't have any small, I put a 0.

387
00:20:36.670 --> 00:20:39.740
But if the shirt's never
been available in a small,

388
00:20:39.740 --> 00:20:43.260
then putting a 0 there might make it seem
like I could order it if I needed it.

389
00:20:43.260 --> 00:20:44.943
I might want it to be null to
indicate I can't even order it,

390
00:20:44.943 --> 00:20:45.729
it's just not available.

391
00:20:45.729 --> 00:20:51.218
Well, when you query horizontally
like this, if I wanna say,

392
00:20:51.218 --> 00:20:56.826
for shirt number one what's
the smallest size I can get, okay?

393
00:20:56.826 --> 00:20:59.849
What I'm really looking for here is,

394
00:20:59.849 --> 00:21:03.820
which of these is the first
one that's not empty?

395
00:21:03.820 --> 00:21:06.560
Which is the first one that's not null?

396
00:21:06.560 --> 00:21:08.579
And so you can do that,
you can tell it to search and

397
00:21:08.579 --> 00:21:10.184
find the first value that's not null.

398
00:21:10.184 --> 00:21:15.409
I did shirt sizes here,
a real world example of how I've used this

399
00:21:15.409 --> 00:21:20.547
is dealing with like people,
usually payroll, with payroll.

400
00:21:20.547 --> 00:21:23.927
If I am tracking an employee's pay and
it's arranged horizontally, which I hate,

401
00:21:23.927 --> 00:21:25.750
I usually try to go
vertically on this stuff.

402
00:21:25.750 --> 00:21:29.290
Where each month they've got a salary
amount, or an hourly amount, or

403
00:21:29.290 --> 00:21:33.302
maybe you're tracking bonuses,
commissions, and they've done monthly, so

404
00:21:33.302 --> 00:21:35.310
each call represents a month.

405
00:21:35.310 --> 00:21:40.000
Well, if somebody's hired in May and
I'm tracking for the entire year of 2017,

406
00:21:40.000 --> 00:21:44.240
then January, February, March,
and April are all gonna be null.

407
00:21:44.240 --> 00:21:46.960
They weren't working here,
those are empty, they had no sales.

408
00:21:46.960 --> 00:21:47.910
So I might say,

409
00:21:47.910 --> 00:21:52.670
I need to start with the first one that
actually has a value that's not null.

410
00:21:52.670 --> 00:21:55.940
And I could do a test on each individual
one, but if there's 1,000 of them,

411
00:21:55.940 --> 00:21:57.670
that's a lot of tests.

412
00:21:57.670 --> 00:22:00.650
So there's actually a built in command
that we can use to do this, and

413
00:22:00.650 --> 00:22:03.140
it's kind of an edge case,
it's not something everyone's gonna use.

414
00:22:03.140 --> 00:22:07.310
But the command is called coalesce, and
what coalesce does is it says get me this

415
00:22:07.310 --> 00:22:12.410
data, but
skip to the first value that's not null.

416
00:22:12.410 --> 00:22:14.620
Give me just that first
value that's not null.

417
00:22:14.620 --> 00:22:17.470
The sample database that
Microsoft has here doesn't

418
00:22:17.470 --> 00:22:21.780
have a great example built into it, but I
can show you one its just not necessarily

419
00:22:23.570 --> 00:22:25.840
exactly like we'd use it in real life.

420
00:22:25.840 --> 00:22:33.880
So if I wanna find something, let me pull
up a little table that we've got here.

421
00:22:33.880 --> 00:22:39.471
I'm gonna pull the [Name],
and Class, Color,

422
00:22:39.471 --> 00:22:45.585
and ProductNumber From the production,

423
00:22:45.585 --> 00:22:50.326
whoops, from the production.product
table is where I'm gonna pull this from.

424
00:22:50.326 --> 00:22:54.456
And that table contains all
the information about our products in this

425
00:22:54.456 --> 00:22:55.158
database.

426
00:22:55.158 --> 00:22:58.310
So when I query that,
it's gonna pull it up.

427
00:22:58.310 --> 00:23:01.910
And look right here in the beginning,
I've got this adjustable race bike.

428
00:23:01.910 --> 00:23:04.685
And it doesn't have a class,
it doesn't have a color, but

429
00:23:04.685 --> 00:23:05.700
it does have a product number.

430
00:23:07.060 --> 00:23:09.780
So I'm might wanna query against this and

431
00:23:09.780 --> 00:23:13.430
say, give me the first
value that's not null.

432
00:23:13.430 --> 00:23:17.160
Well, it would skip null, it would
skip null, and it would get AR-5381.

433
00:23:17.160 --> 00:23:21.480
Assuming that I was just
grabbing these three columns.

434
00:23:21.480 --> 00:23:23.330
As it stands, they've all got a name and

435
00:23:23.330 --> 00:23:25.600
that's first, and so
that might be a problem.

436
00:23:25.600 --> 00:23:28.820
And I can solve that pretty easily
just by moving Name to the end, and

437
00:23:28.820 --> 00:23:30.100
now the NULL's be upfront.

438
00:23:30.100 --> 00:23:34.860
But we can actually correct that in
the command as well, so I'll correct it.

439
00:23:34.860 --> 00:23:36.930
But this is an example here
where I've got NULLs and

440
00:23:36.930 --> 00:23:38.830
I might want to just jump over to it.

441
00:23:38.830 --> 00:23:42.389
LL Crankarm, whatever that is,
it has a Class and a Color, so

442
00:23:42.389 --> 00:23:46.420
it would return an L,
yeah we can imagine what that does.

443
00:23:46.420 --> 00:23:50.130
So if I wanna see that where I grab
just the first non null value,

444
00:23:50.130 --> 00:23:52.589
I can add just a little
more to this query.

445
00:23:52.589 --> 00:23:56.925
And I'm going to tell it to COALESCE,

446
00:23:56.925 --> 00:24:02.488
that's C-O-A-L-E-S-C-E, COALESCE.

447
00:24:02.488 --> 00:24:06.260
And then in parenthesis I'm going
to tell the columns to check.

448
00:24:06.260 --> 00:24:08.230
Remember I said I could
move name to the end.

449
00:24:08.230 --> 00:24:12.490
But instead of moving name to the end I
can just only coalesce on these three

450
00:24:12.490 --> 00:24:13.520
columns here.

451
00:24:13.520 --> 00:24:15.510
That's far easier, and
that's how you'll normally do it.

452
00:24:15.510 --> 00:24:18.767
So that's why I didn't change my actual
>> Can you coalesce an entire table?

453
00:24:18.767 --> 00:24:20.360
>> Yeah, absolutely.

454
00:24:20.360 --> 00:24:23.250
Technically I'm doing it right here
because I haven't done any where

455
00:24:23.250 --> 00:24:24.330
clause to limit this.

456
00:24:24.330 --> 00:24:28.390
But you can do a where clause to get
just a piece versus the whole thing.

457
00:24:28.390 --> 00:24:31.390
And there is a performance improvement for
doing that so you might want to.

458
00:24:31.390 --> 00:24:33.148
I'm going to hit the whole table here.

459
00:24:33.148 --> 00:24:33.917
>> Awesome.
>> And so

460
00:24:33.917 --> 00:24:37.625
when I coalesce I'm going to tell
it though that I just want to

461
00:24:37.625 --> 00:24:40.840
pay attention to class,
color and product number.

462
00:24:41.860 --> 00:24:44.930
I don't want to pay attention
to the other columns.

463
00:24:44.930 --> 00:24:47.310
If these were the short sizes,
this is where I would say,

464
00:24:47.310 --> 00:24:51.740
I want to pay attention to the small,
medium, large, extra large, and that's it.

465
00:24:51.740 --> 00:24:54.050
Don't pay attention to any other column.

466
00:24:54.050 --> 00:24:56.400
So I'm telling them to coalesce that.

467
00:24:56.400 --> 00:25:01.420
And normally what I would do is if I was
just interested in the first non-null

468
00:25:01.420 --> 00:25:04.560
value, I wouldn't return
all these columns.

469
00:25:04.560 --> 00:25:08.320
All I would do is return
the one coalesce column,

470
00:25:08.320 --> 00:25:09.980
because it's gonna have
the information that I want.

471
00:25:09.980 --> 00:25:11.250
What's the smallest
shirt size that I have?

472
00:25:11.250 --> 00:25:12.120
That's all I care about.

473
00:25:12.120 --> 00:25:13.920
I don't care about
the other ones being null.

474
00:25:13.920 --> 00:25:17.527
But just for the example here,
I'm gonna leave those in place.

475
00:25:17.527 --> 00:25:18.755
So we're gonna get class, color and

476
00:25:18.755 --> 00:25:21.410
product number just so
we can see that it found the right one.

477
00:25:21.410 --> 00:25:25.209
And I'm gonna pull coalesce in
of those three columns as, and

478
00:25:25.209 --> 00:25:30.480
I'll just call it coalesced, so we can
remember what we did that caused this.

479
00:25:30.480 --> 00:25:32.760
And so I'll see that column
that's been coalesced.

480
00:25:32.760 --> 00:25:36.290
And then we're just pulling that from
the table so this is going to search

481
00:25:36.290 --> 00:25:39.290
on the first non-null and
return it in this final column.

482
00:25:39.290 --> 00:25:42.650
So when I run it, we'll see a new
column appear over here and

483
00:25:42.650 --> 00:25:46.060
it should just contain the first
value that's not null.

484
00:25:46.060 --> 00:25:48.620
So I'll run that there's my extra column.

485
00:25:48.620 --> 00:25:52.000
And for these first five sure enough
I can see a skipped class and

486
00:25:52.000 --> 00:25:54.200
color and it grabbed product number.

487
00:25:54.200 --> 00:25:55.150
So these all have product numbers.

488
00:25:55.150 --> 00:25:59.050
But when I use it, the next one,
the LL Crank arm, it had a class.

489
00:25:59.050 --> 00:26:01.370
That was the first
non-null that returned it-

490
00:26:01.370 --> 00:26:03.410
>> That must be crank arm again.

491
00:26:03.410 --> 00:26:06.400
>> Yeah, and so this scenario,

492
00:26:06.400 --> 00:26:09.660
what I was trying to say a moment ago
is that it's not exactly real world.

493
00:26:09.660 --> 00:26:13.960
Like when is a time that I would
say if it doesn't have a color,

494
00:26:13.960 --> 00:26:17.080
give me the product number,
it doesn't really make sense.

495
00:26:17.080 --> 00:26:19.490
But if these were shirt sizes,
right, I don't have small,

496
00:26:19.490 --> 00:26:21.250
I don't have medium, but I've got large.

497
00:26:21.250 --> 00:26:25.230
Okay, tell me that I've got
the large available and that's it.

498
00:26:25.230 --> 00:26:29.047
And again,
typically we'd leave these columns off.

499
00:26:29.047 --> 00:26:31.740
I don't need to see those columns,
cuz they're null, they don't exist.

500
00:26:31.740 --> 00:26:33.680
Why return them to me, right?

501
00:26:33.680 --> 00:26:36.470
Instead, just give me the ones
that I actually have.

502
00:26:36.470 --> 00:26:39.760
And now it would return and I would
see large, or extra large, or small.

503
00:26:39.760 --> 00:26:43.150
Now we're into the smallest shirt
that was available in that size or

504
00:26:43.150 --> 00:26:47.110
the first pay period for that employee.

505
00:26:47.110 --> 00:26:49.760
I would see that first
value that wasn't null.

506
00:26:49.760 --> 00:26:52.092
That's what coalesce does.

507
00:26:52.092 --> 00:26:55.830
Now, normally, when a database is designed
properly, everything's done vertically.

508
00:26:55.830 --> 00:26:58.390
And Case is perfect for that.

509
00:26:58.390 --> 00:26:59.100
Case can handle it.

510
00:26:59.100 --> 00:26:59.630
No problem.

511
00:26:59.630 --> 00:27:01.730
It can grab the value,
and you're in business.

512
00:27:01.730 --> 00:27:03.550
Order by and all that can really help.

513
00:27:03.550 --> 00:27:06.510
And that's what you're going
to use 99% of the time.

514
00:27:06.510 --> 00:27:09.860
And the main reason is with horizontal
data, there's kind of a limit.

515
00:27:09.860 --> 00:27:13.370
There's only so many column you can
have before the table goes nuts.

516
00:27:13.370 --> 00:27:17.250
And so if you're doing pay periods,
and the person works for you for

517
00:27:17.250 --> 00:27:19.400
20 years, that's a lot of columns.

518
00:27:19.400 --> 00:27:20.040
>> A lot of them.

519
00:27:20.040 --> 00:27:20.910
>> It should be vertical.

520
00:27:20.910 --> 00:27:24.980
And by doing that way where each period
is a row, it's far easier to work with.

521
00:27:24.980 --> 00:27:29.720
Unfortunately, in real life when you don't
get to design every database you work on,

522
00:27:29.720 --> 00:27:32.740
and oftentimes they're designed by people
who don't have a lot of experience.

523
00:27:32.740 --> 00:27:36.540
And so you may encounter these databases
that are just not structured right.

524
00:27:36.540 --> 00:27:37.950
And that's where coalesce becomes reliant.

525
00:27:38.965 --> 00:27:40.610
>> Another great episode,
conditions and knowles.

526
00:27:40.610 --> 00:27:41.590
Thank you, Don.

527
00:27:41.590 --> 00:27:44.430
And before we leave,
what else would you like to say?

528
00:27:44.430 --> 00:27:47.430
>> With all of these tools,
feel free to use them or not use them.

529
00:27:47.430 --> 00:27:50.800
You may not have a real world case
scenario for some of these commands, but

530
00:27:50.800 --> 00:27:51.540
many of you will.

531
00:27:51.540 --> 00:27:53.690
And you'll encounter
times when the data and

532
00:27:53.690 --> 00:27:56.240
the database is just not
the way you want it.

533
00:27:56.240 --> 00:27:58.560
We don't have to change
the data in the database.

534
00:27:58.560 --> 00:28:00.620
We can just change our
query to account for

535
00:28:00.620 --> 00:28:03.960
it, especially null values where
we don't expect null values to be.

536
00:28:03.960 --> 00:28:07.210
Data that's represented as a number,
we want it to be something else.

537
00:28:07.210 --> 00:28:09.420
In a previous episode we talked
about converting data types.

538
00:28:09.420 --> 00:28:11.202
I can convert the data type but

539
00:28:11.202 --> 00:28:15.764
Case, I can totally change the value
to something completely different and

540
00:28:15.764 --> 00:28:19.483
those are very powerful ways to
make the data match our needs.

541
00:28:19.483 --> 00:28:22.790
But we've got to figure out which one
is right for us, kind of like a puzzle.

542
00:28:22.790 --> 00:28:27.710
So when you approach a problem, I've given
you the tools now to solve those problems,

543
00:28:27.710 --> 00:28:30.430
you just got to figure out the right tool,
do I need a screwdriver, or

544
00:28:30.430 --> 00:28:31.760
do I need the wrench for this one?

545
00:28:31.760 --> 00:28:35.240
Do I need coalesce, or can I use case,
which one's going to match up for

546
00:28:35.240 --> 00:28:37.160
what I want to do, and
then get it put in place.

547
00:28:37.160 --> 00:28:40.670
And you might find that there's more than
one way to solve it, and at that point,

548
00:28:40.670 --> 00:28:44.010
if I have two ways to solve it,
I usually look at performance.

549
00:28:44.010 --> 00:28:48.200
I pull up that query execution plan,
CTRL+M in your query analyzer and

550
00:28:48.200 --> 00:28:49.290
I do it both ways.

551
00:28:49.290 --> 00:28:50.280
I see which one ran faster.

552
00:28:50.280 --> 00:28:52.530
The one that runs faster,
that's the one I'll go with and

553
00:28:52.530 --> 00:28:54.720
that is kind of a good
tie breaker usually.

554
00:28:54.720 --> 00:28:55.320
>> Awesome, Don.

555
00:28:55.320 --> 00:28:56.170
Thanks again.

556
00:28:56.170 --> 00:29:00.190
And querying data with TransX SQL, watch
every episode you'll be glad you did.

557
00:29:00.190 --> 00:29:01.580
When you're in the course library.

558
00:29:01.580 --> 00:29:05.420
There's hundreds of other videos and
they are there to help you go further.

559
00:29:05.420 --> 00:29:08.330
And tell everybody you know about
ITPro.TV, it is binge worthy.

560
00:29:08.330 --> 00:29:10.070
Thank you for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

561
00:29:10.070 --> 00:29:10.830
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

562
00:29:10.830 --> 00:29:11.849
>> We will see you soon.

563
00:29:11.849 --> 00:29:19.083
[MUSIC]

564
00:29:19.083 --> 00:29:22.198
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don revisits the topic of functions. This time around, he demonstrates how to create custom functions that can directly support your business need. He wraps up by demonstrating how to create and use scalar and table-valued functions.
episodes.title: User Defined Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains what a stored function is in Microsoft SQL. He demonstrates several built-in stored procedures and then shows how to create and execute custom stored procedures to support your business needs.
episodes.title: Stored Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how SQL Views function. He walks the viewers through several scenarios where views can be very useful and then demonstrates how to create and use views in Transact-SQL.
episodes.title: Creating Views

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to transactions. He explains how transactions function and demonstrates how they can protect your data in the event of a failed query. He wraps up the episode with an example of how transactions can be used for troubleshooting and auditing.
episodes.title: Transactions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to transactions. He explains how transactions function and demonstrates how they can protect your data in the event of a failed query. He wraps up the episode with an example of how transactions can be used for troubleshooting and auditing.
episodes.title: Transactions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the importance of catching and reporting errors in your SQL scripts. He demonstrates how to use TRY/CATCH blocks, RAISERROR and THROW to collect and report error information. He ends the episode by updating an existing query to provide proper error handling.
episodes.title: Error Handling

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the importance of catching and reporting errors in your SQL scripts. He demonstrates how to use TRY/CATCH blocks, RAISERROR and THROW to collect and report error information. He ends the episode by updating an existing query to provide proper error handling.
episodes.title: Error Handling Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use subqueries to make complex queries more efficient. He explains how query execution plans are calculated and then shows how to measure whether or not a subquery can provide a performance improvement over a complex query.
episodes.title: Subqueries
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:02.923
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.923 --> 00:00:06.275
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.275 --> 00:00:07.962
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.962 --> 00:00:12.646
>> You're watching ITPro TV.
>> Hello,

5
00:00:12.646 --> 00:00:15.674
welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro TV.

6
00:00:15.674 --> 00:00:17.956
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and

7
00:00:17.956 --> 00:00:22.230
today we're doing querying
data with SQL or Transact-SQL.

8
00:00:22.230 --> 00:00:23.850
With me today is Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:25.650
How you doing Don?
>> I'm doing great, Mike,

10
00:00:25.650 --> 00:00:27.660
ready to dive right
back into Transact-SQL.

11
00:00:27.660 --> 00:00:30.430
And in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at a really neat thing that's

12
00:00:30.430 --> 00:00:32.150
called a subquery.

13
00:00:32.150 --> 00:00:36.950
And this is where we take one query and we
stick it inside of another query, right?

14
00:00:36.950 --> 00:00:40.660
Which we've kind of already seen
when we did nested joins, right?

15
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:43.028
A nested join is technically a subquery.

16
00:00:43.028 --> 00:00:46.652
But in this scenario we're gonna see some
slightly different uses for subqueries and

17
00:00:46.652 --> 00:00:48.120
how we can take advantage of that.

18
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:50.228
To really get the data
set that we want and

19
00:00:50.228 --> 00:00:52.584
to find ways to do things
more efficiently and

20
00:00:52.584 --> 00:00:56.682
better than we might have been able to
do through other, more complex things.

21
00:00:56.682 --> 00:00:58.882
Like if you watch that
nested join episode,

22
00:00:58.882 --> 00:01:01.030
some of that syntax got pretty cluttered.

23
00:01:01.030 --> 00:01:03.920
There was a lot of SQL written
on my screen for that.

24
00:01:03.920 --> 00:01:07.582
We'll see here that it's actually not so
hard when we take advantage of subqueries.

25
00:01:07.582 --> 00:01:08.610
>> Sounds good, Don,

26
00:01:08.610 --> 00:01:11.470
I guess you kinda answered my question or
sort of.

27
00:01:11.470 --> 00:01:14.580
Why would we want to use
these subqueries then?

28
00:01:14.580 --> 00:01:16.040
>> There's a couple of motivations,right?

29
00:01:16.040 --> 00:01:18.650
So I mentioned being easier right,
that's one reason.

30
00:01:18.650 --> 00:01:21.480
And it's not always easier, sometimes
subqueries are a little bit harder.

31
00:01:21.480 --> 00:01:25.270
But the main reason why we
want to learn about subqueries

32
00:01:25.270 --> 00:01:29.000
is that they can be far more
efficient than a regular query.

33
00:01:29.000 --> 00:01:32.680
In fact, a lot of what I'm gonna show you
here in this episode you could write as

34
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:34.680
a single query if you wanted.

35
00:01:34.680 --> 00:01:38.260
But, if you do,
you may be getting poor performance,right?

36
00:01:38.260 --> 00:01:43.460
Sometimes what you have are a lot of
executions that are a part of a query.

37
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:46.100
When you run a query,
it's not just doing one simple thing.

38
00:01:46.100 --> 00:01:48.690
It's usually doing four or five different
things, and sticking them all together and

39
00:01:48.690 --> 00:01:50.220
giving you that information.

40
00:01:50.220 --> 00:01:51.850
When you write it as one query,

41
00:01:51.850 --> 00:01:56.500
the server has to figure out how to deal
with that and treat it as one solid piece.

42
00:01:56.500 --> 00:02:01.130
But if we use subqueries, now things
get broken up into smaller pieces, and

43
00:02:01.130 --> 00:02:02.920
that gives the server more options.

44
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:06.990
The server can figure out more creative
and official ways to run that query and

45
00:02:06.990 --> 00:02:09.600
put the data together and
present it back to you.

46
00:02:09.600 --> 00:02:12.090
And so, while sometimes it might a little
bit harder to write it this way.

47
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:16.180
The optimization benefit what we're really
after, and that's kind of the key thing.

48
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:19.250
Remember that, sub queries are optional,

49
00:02:19.250 --> 00:02:22.490
so you could just it stop
button right now in this video.

50
00:02:22.490 --> 00:02:24.320
He said they're optional,
I'm gonna move on.

51
00:02:24.320 --> 00:02:27.240
Hey, everything we do here you can
achieve with the normal query.

52
00:02:27.240 --> 00:02:31.060
But know this, in a test environment
sure they're optional, but

53
00:02:31.060 --> 00:02:35.710
in production, these types of subqueries
are really, really important, right.

54
00:02:35.710 --> 00:02:38.265
If I told you that you
had a query that runs in

55
00:02:38.265 --> 00:02:41.208
one-tenth of a second and then
>> That's

56
00:02:41.208 --> 00:02:42.250
impressive.
>> It's fast.

57
00:02:42.250 --> 00:02:43.165
>> I like it.

58
00:02:43.165 --> 00:02:44.173
>> And then I said well,

59
00:02:44.173 --> 00:02:46.973
if I wrote that as a single query and
didn't use a subquery,

60
00:02:46.973 --> 00:02:50.030
it would take two-tenths of a second,
one-fifth of a second.

61
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:55.980
One fifth of a second, that's still not a
big deal, if I'm just running it one time.

62
00:02:55.980 --> 00:02:59.810
But what if it's running
a thousand times per second?

63
00:02:59.810 --> 00:03:03.972
Look at a database like Amazon's database
that is just being clobbered by tons of

64
00:03:03.972 --> 00:03:05.387
access all over the world.

65
00:03:05.387 --> 00:03:08.507
That, if we can get
an extra tenth of a second,

66
00:03:08.507 --> 00:03:11.360
makes a big, big difference.
>> Starts making

67
00:03:11.360 --> 00:03:13.714
an impact in our performance.
>> Absolutely and

68
00:03:13.714 --> 00:03:16.000
that's stuff that's hard to see in tests,
right?

69
00:03:16.000 --> 00:03:19.715
And that's where I see subqueries
get kinda thrown by the wayside.

70
00:03:19.715 --> 00:03:22.610
Cuz lot of people will say, all right, I
need to write a query that does something.

71
00:03:22.610 --> 00:03:25.130
Let me just figure out a way to do it.

72
00:03:25.130 --> 00:03:26.990
And so they experiment around,
they try different ways, and

73
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:30.570
they find some particular solution and
they get it working, and

74
00:03:30.570 --> 00:03:31.860
it's all just one big single query.

75
00:03:31.860 --> 00:03:34.310
And then they just stop and that's it.

76
00:03:34.310 --> 00:03:38.030
But if they come back and try to
optimize it, they may find that, wow,

77
00:03:38.030 --> 00:03:40.790
if I break that up into
these little pieces.

78
00:03:40.790 --> 00:03:42.690
I can actually get it to run faster,
right?

79
00:03:42.690 --> 00:03:44.230
It's all part of query optimization,

80
00:03:44.230 --> 00:03:48.416
making things run better, more efficiently
and getting that data the way we want it.

81
00:03:48.416 --> 00:03:51.310
That's really the true
power behind a subquery.

82
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:52.340
>> Now Don,

83
00:03:52.340 --> 00:03:55.040
you said that subqueries
are more efficient and

84
00:03:55.040 --> 00:03:57.570
some of our queries can be expensive.

85
00:03:57.570 --> 00:03:58.760
What do you mean by expensive?

86
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:02.010
There's no place for
me to put my debit card in, so

87
00:04:02.010 --> 00:04:03.660
what do we mean by that?
>> All right,

88
00:04:03.660 --> 00:04:05.910
I've used that word expensive
a few times in this shows, right.

89
00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:08.370
That we have expensive queries and
cheap queries.

90
00:04:08.370 --> 00:04:12.000
Every query that runs has a cost, and that
cost is not measured in dollars, right.

91
00:04:12.000 --> 00:04:16.310
It's measured in CPU time, it's
measured in the memory they consume, or

92
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:17.860
the disk IO, right.

93
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:20.750
And usually disk I/O and
CPU time are the two we care about, but

94
00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:22.910
memory is certainly important as well.

95
00:04:22.910 --> 00:04:27.720
So if I write a really
super mega complex query,

96
00:04:27.720 --> 00:04:30.340
that's not gonna be able to take advantage
of a lot of things that are cached.

97
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:33.190
Because the query is complex,
it's unique, right?

98
00:04:33.190 --> 00:04:36.078
So it's going to need RAM to
store values in temporary,

99
00:04:36.078 --> 00:04:39.466
it's going to need disk I/O to read and
gather the information.

100
00:04:39.466 --> 00:04:44.710
It's going to need CPU time to sort out
that calculation, and get things done.

101
00:04:44.710 --> 00:04:48.910
If I have smaller, simpler queries,
well they may be able to leverage cache

102
00:04:48.910 --> 00:04:51.650
results better, or
built in indexes better.

103
00:04:51.650 --> 00:04:55.894
They may be able to use what's already
in RAM and not have to hit the disc for

104
00:04:55.894 --> 00:04:56.797
pulling data.

105
00:04:56.797 --> 00:04:59.743
Or consume CPU time for correlating
information to a certain order,

106
00:04:59.743 --> 00:05:02.160
because the data might
already be in that order.

107
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:04.410
Those are inexpensive quarries.

108
00:05:04.410 --> 00:05:07.550
We need to be looking not just at
whether our query works, I mean,

109
00:05:07.550 --> 00:05:09.130
that's certainly nice, right?

110
00:05:09.130 --> 00:05:12.840
I have to achieve task A by tomorrow.

111
00:05:12.840 --> 00:05:14.600
I'm not so
worried about cost at that point,

112
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:16.400
whatever it takes I just
need it working by tomorrow.

113
00:05:16.400 --> 00:05:18.580
Tomorrow I can come back and
optimize it later.

114
00:05:18.580 --> 00:05:20.200
But when we're optimizing,

115
00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:23.860
that's when we need to say like
how can I reduce CPU time?

116
00:05:23.860 --> 00:05:26.840
How can I reduce the memory we consume?

117
00:05:26.840 --> 00:05:28.970
All of that stuff is
kind of a part of that.

118
00:05:28.970 --> 00:05:31.730
And it's easy to lose sight
of with queries, right?

119
00:05:31.730 --> 00:05:35.010
Mostly because,
when you're in the query analyzer,

120
00:05:35.010 --> 00:05:39.790
and I run a simple query, here, I'll run
a simple query just to kinda show you.

121
00:05:39.790 --> 00:05:42.450
So let me do a join, right?

122
00:05:42.450 --> 00:05:47.240
I'm gonna pull a list of all of my sales
people, and what bonus they got last year.

123
00:05:47.240 --> 00:05:49.610
So I'll do a select statement.

124
00:05:49.610 --> 00:05:55.840
And I'm going to pull from
the person.person table,

125
00:05:55.840 --> 00:05:59.430
which I'll just do an alias and call it P.

126
00:05:59.430 --> 00:06:02.585
You guys remember from earlier
episodes that person.person is a list

127
00:06:02.585 --> 00:06:04.995
of all the contacts our
company is aware of.

128
00:06:04.995 --> 00:06:08.145
We've got humanresources.employ,
those are our employees.

129
00:06:08.145 --> 00:06:10.195
I just want sales people, right?

130
00:06:10.195 --> 00:06:11.785
So, we actually have a separate table for
that,

131
00:06:11.785 --> 00:06:14.055
that's why I'm gonna do
an interjoin on this one.

132
00:06:14.055 --> 00:06:22.470
So, I will do a join against
sales.salesperson as sp.

133
00:06:22.470 --> 00:06:27.450
And those two are link together
by the business entity ID.

134
00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:30.930
So let me tie those together real quick.

135
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:33.630
And once I've got that done,
I'm gonna come up here and

136
00:06:33.630 --> 00:06:35.129
shorten what I'm asking for.

137
00:06:35.129 --> 00:06:40.693
Cuz I really just want to get,
let's see I need their

138
00:06:40.693 --> 00:06:47.640
first name I want their last name and
I want their bonus, right?

139
00:06:47.640 --> 00:06:49.550
That's what this whole thing is about,
right?

140
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:51.330
So there's a simple query.

141
00:06:51.330 --> 00:06:53.570
I say simple, it's a little more complex
than a normal simple statement, but

142
00:06:53.570 --> 00:06:54.770
it is a simple join.

143
00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:59.082
I can make this easier, I suppose,
like inner join is the default,

144
00:06:59.082 --> 00:07:01.664
I can leave that out and
do it [INAUDIBLE].

145
00:07:01.664 --> 00:07:04.110
So, when I run this query,
it's gonna reach out.

146
00:07:04.110 --> 00:07:06.360
It's getting data from
two different tables and

147
00:07:06.360 --> 00:07:08.010
it's gotta to put them together.

148
00:07:08.010 --> 00:07:12.006
It's gotta say, hey, person.person,
that has, I forget how many,

149
00:07:12.006 --> 00:07:14.443
it's like over 5,000 contacts in it.

150
00:07:14.443 --> 00:07:16.590
But I've only got 17 sales people.

151
00:07:16.590 --> 00:07:20.960
So, it's gonna go to sales.salesperson
to find these 17 sales people.

152
00:07:20.960 --> 00:07:23.910
And then it's gotta get their first
name and last name out of person.person.

153
00:07:23.910 --> 00:07:27.080
So it's looking at two different tables or
relating the data and

154
00:07:27.080 --> 00:07:29.460
then putting it together
into a resultant set.

155
00:07:29.460 --> 00:07:33.740
And when I run that the query analyzer
gives the information I want.

156
00:07:33.740 --> 00:07:37.810
And it just gives me one simple
metric down at bottom right.

157
00:07:37.810 --> 00:07:40.940
If I zoom in actually my
head's gonna cover part of it,

158
00:07:40.940 --> 00:07:43.150
is where I can see the query time.

159
00:07:43.150 --> 00:07:45.090
And the query time here
isn't even useful for

160
00:07:45.090 --> 00:07:47.040
me because what does it say?
>> Zero.

161
00:07:47.040 --> 00:07:48.050
>> Zero, right?

162
00:07:48.050 --> 00:07:49.520
And it didn't take zero seconds?

163
00:07:49.520 --> 00:07:51.950
The server didn't already
know this information.

164
00:07:51.950 --> 00:07:54.560
What happened is it took less
than a tenth of a second, or

165
00:07:54.560 --> 00:07:56.632
actually less than
a hundredth of a second.

166
00:07:56.632 --> 00:07:59.494
So it might have taken .009 seconds,

167
00:07:59.494 --> 00:08:03.023
well that won't show up on the at counter,
right?

168
00:08:03.023 --> 00:08:07.462
So the one metric they give me is really
only useful When I'm running a big query,

169
00:08:07.462 --> 00:08:11.077
one that's got to get a lot of data and
can register on that timer.

170
00:08:11.077 --> 00:08:13.030
Otherwise it's always going to be 0.

171
00:08:13.030 --> 00:08:17.142
But this query did have a cost,
it might have been a very small cost, but

172
00:08:17.142 --> 00:08:20.103
it did have one, and
we don't see that by default.

173
00:08:20.103 --> 00:08:23.499
And in other episodes, I've shown
you guys the query execution plan.

174
00:08:23.499 --> 00:08:27.534
And when you're optimizing a query, this
is really important, up top is an icon,

175
00:08:27.534 --> 00:08:29.448
it's three little boxes with arrows.

176
00:08:29.448 --> 00:08:31.108
And I can never remember which icon it is,

177
00:08:31.108 --> 00:08:32.963
because there's several
that look the same.

178
00:08:32.963 --> 00:08:35.619
It's Control M on the keyboard,
is what I always hit.

179
00:08:35.619 --> 00:08:38.422
And if you hit Control M,
that's going to tell you,

180
00:08:38.422 --> 00:08:40.538
see how that icon just boxed itself in?

181
00:08:40.538 --> 00:08:45.455
That's going to tell it to show me the
query execution plan when a query runs.

182
00:08:45.455 --> 00:08:50.778
And if I rerun that query, I get the same
results, it still tells me it's 0 seconds.

183
00:08:50.778 --> 00:08:53.741
But I get a nice new little
tab that shows up right here,

184
00:08:53.741 --> 00:08:55.427
where it says Execution Plan.

185
00:08:55.427 --> 00:08:58.808
And if I click on that,
it will show me what that query did,

186
00:08:58.808 --> 00:09:01.782
remember, I said we were
pulling from two tables?

187
00:09:01.782 --> 00:09:05.366
Well, here's where it's doing
a clustering index scan of one table,

188
00:09:05.366 --> 00:09:06.626
the salesperson table.

189
00:09:06.626 --> 00:09:11.236
And here's an index scan of
the person table, person.person, and

190
00:09:11.236 --> 00:09:12.834
sales.salesperson.

191
00:09:12.834 --> 00:09:17.280
And it's reaching out to them, and
I can see that 71% of my time,

192
00:09:17.280 --> 00:09:20.331
the cost was spent in
the clustered indexing.

193
00:09:20.331 --> 00:09:22.154
And I shouldn't say time,

194
00:09:22.154 --> 00:09:26.762
because remember that cost is CPU
utilization, memory, and so on.

195
00:09:26.762 --> 00:09:29.849
That two-thirds, more than two-thirds,

196
00:09:29.849 --> 00:09:33.269
of my query was spent
looking at person.person.

197
00:09:33.269 --> 00:09:36.889
Well, I've only got 17 salespeople.

198
00:09:36.889 --> 00:09:40.978
It had to peruse that database,
that table.

199
00:09:40.978 --> 00:09:44.278
Through thousands of records
that weren't salespeople,

200
00:09:44.278 --> 00:09:46.393
and that's why that cost was so high.

201
00:09:46.393 --> 00:09:50.431
The overall query itself, if I go up here,
I can see was pretty small.

202
00:09:50.431 --> 00:09:55.261
And it says my estimated subtree cost
here was 0.011, now that's not time,

203
00:09:55.261 --> 00:09:56.599
that's not seconds.

204
00:09:56.599 --> 00:10:00.187
That's just what that cost is,
and that's very small,

205
00:10:00.187 --> 00:10:03.114
the estimated operator cost, 0%, right?

206
00:10:03.114 --> 00:10:07.121
Cached plan size, 24k,
this is a very small, simple query.

207
00:10:07.121 --> 00:10:10.195
But, if I look at this, I can say, man,

208
00:10:10.195 --> 00:10:15.637
that's probably not the most efficient
way to do this, or maybe it is.

209
00:10:15.637 --> 00:10:17.413
If these indexes didn't exist,

210
00:10:17.413 --> 00:10:21.099
there may have been something far
more expensive to go in and do that.

211
00:10:21.099 --> 00:10:24.579
So when we write queries,
even if the query that we write works,

212
00:10:24.579 --> 00:10:27.291
this query works and
gives me exactly what I want.

213
00:10:27.291 --> 00:10:29.601
We still need to evaluate those
queries and say, all right.

214
00:10:29.601 --> 00:10:33.505
Is there something expensive in here
that I could figure a way around and

215
00:10:33.505 --> 00:10:37.370
make it better and make it more efficient?
>> Now are there certain types of

216
00:10:37.370 --> 00:10:40.103
operations then that are just
known to be expensive?

217
00:10:40.103 --> 00:10:41.049
>> Yeah, yeah, absolutely.

218
00:10:41.049 --> 00:10:47.238
I'm not using any of the obvious ones
here, so the obvious ones are sorts.

219
00:10:47.238 --> 00:10:51.305
If you see a sorts statement,
sorts can almost always be optimized.

220
00:10:51.305 --> 00:10:54.441
In fact, if you're just sorting for
the sake of sorting,

221
00:10:54.441 --> 00:10:55.979
that's usually a bad idea.

222
00:10:55.979 --> 00:10:59.360
You could have the client sort the data,
once they receive the result of the query,

223
00:10:59.360 --> 00:11:00.343
they can sort it there.

224
00:11:00.343 --> 00:11:02.446
And that takes a ton of

227

00:11:13.399 --> 00:11:15.185

00:11:15.185 --> 00:11:17.963
I could store it already

230
00:11:17.963 --> 00:11:20.564
So now the server doesn't have
to perform this order operation,

00:11:20.564 --> 00:11:21.851

whole table into RAM, and that's not so

246
00:11:59.856 --> 00:12:02.951
Well, your regular tables are optimized.

00:12:02.951 --> 00:12:05.338
People, database administrators at least,

00:12:05.338 --> 00:12:07.796
they think about how to
optimize these tables.

00:12:07.796 --> 00:12:10.459
And so they store them on hard
drive arrays that are optimized for

00:12:10.459 --> 00:12:11.803
the performance that you need.

251
00:12:11.803 --> 00:12:13.971
And on systems that have those resources.

252
00:12:13.971 --> 00:12:18.170
Temporary tables, on the other hand,
they're just stored in a default location.

253
00:12:18.170 --> 00:12:21.740
By default, they're actually on the same
partition as your operating system,

00:12:21.740 --> 00:12:23.059

00:12:28.785 --> 00:12:33.022
