It does when we compare them, right?

451
00:22:51.080 --> 00:22:52.810
Let's compare these and see.

452
00:22:52.810 --> 00:22:55.210
I'm gonna run them both in a batch.

453
00:22:55.210 --> 00:22:58.790
And so when I run them both together,
there's the results side by side, right?

454
00:22:58.790 --> 00:23:01.220
My unoptimized query and
my optimized query.

455
00:23:01.220 --> 00:23:03.010
I'm gonna make this window
a little bit bigger.

456
00:23:04.250 --> 00:23:04.870
Okay?

457
00:23:04.870 --> 00:23:08.510
So I can see the result inserted there.

458
00:23:08.510 --> 00:23:10.330
When I look at the execution plan,

459
00:23:10.330 --> 00:23:13.180
here's what I'm gonna see in
my big differences, okay?

460
00:23:13.180 --> 00:23:15.760
The first one here,
is my older query, right?

461
00:23:15.760 --> 00:23:17.940
The one that I keep saying is bad.

462
00:23:17.940 --> 00:23:21.750
Well, that's not a guarantee it is bad,
I just keep saying that, right?

463
00:23:21.750 --> 00:23:25.080
And when I look at it,
it's only got five steps.

464
00:23:25.080 --> 00:23:27.060
Right?
So that doesn't seem bad.

465
00:23:27.060 --> 00:23:28.750
Look at my other query down here.

466
00:23:28.750 --> 00:23:32.030
In fact, I think my head's covering
just a little bit of this.

467
00:23:32.030 --> 00:23:37.690
But it has, let's see, three,
four, five, six, six steps.

468
00:23:37.690 --> 00:23:40.370
I've introduced one more step.
>> Gotta be worse,

469
00:23:40.370 --> 00:23:42.253
then.
>> You would think, right?

470
00:23:42.253 --> 00:23:44.740
But, remember how bad I said sorts were?

471
00:23:44.740 --> 00:23:45.660
Look at a lot of these steps.

472
00:23:45.660 --> 00:23:48.280
Most of these steps are not
that big of a deal.

473
00:23:48.280 --> 00:23:51.845
In fact, let me zoom in
because this is kind of crazy.

474
00:23:51.845 --> 00:23:54.070
[LAUGH] So we've got these
nested loops that we're doing.

475
00:23:54.070 --> 00:23:57.208
And we had nested loops up here,
too, so that's not anything special,

476
00:23:57.208 --> 00:23:59.792
except here I've got two
different nested loops, right?

477
00:23:59.792 --> 00:24:01.996
The nested loop up here had a 0% cost.

478
00:24:01.996 --> 00:24:02.970
It was practically free.

479
00:24:02.970 --> 00:24:04.011
My frist one does, too.

480
00:24:04.011 --> 00:24:06.493
My second one has a 1% cost, so.

481
00:24:06.493 --> 00:24:09.424
Again, it starts to seem like
I'm making things worse, right?

482
00:24:09.424 --> 00:24:11.590
I've got a stream aggregate where
we're putting data together.

483
00:24:11.590 --> 00:24:12.670
That was free.

484
00:24:12.670 --> 00:24:16.842
My clustered index scans
of the two tables at 33%.

485
00:24:16.842 --> 00:24:21.180
That's different than what we saw up here,
28% and 17%, right?

486
00:24:21.180 --> 00:24:23.694
So, it looks like I made it worse.

487
00:24:23.694 --> 00:24:29.532
And then down here towards the bottom,
which somehow I will scroll down to see.

488
00:24:29.532 --> 00:24:33.790
We've got this last little
step that's hiding from me.

489
00:24:33.790 --> 00:24:37.240
Here, another clustered
index seek of Person.Person.

490
00:24:37.240 --> 00:24:40.470
We're actually reaching out to
the SalesPerson table twice, once for

491
00:24:40.470 --> 00:24:42.610
the sub-query and once for
the parent query.

492
00:24:42.610 --> 00:24:45.980
So I've introduced a whole third lookup.

493
00:24:45.980 --> 00:24:47.770
That sounds bad, right?

494
00:24:47.770 --> 00:24:50.660
And as humans, we're visual people,
we look at things visually like this.

495
00:24:50.660 --> 00:24:52.960
But we have to remember
these are all percentages.

496
00:24:52.960 --> 00:24:58.320
And percentages only mean something if you
know what they're a percentage of, right?

497
00:24:58.320 --> 00:25:02.004
If I look at the sub-tree values
here from my original query,

498
00:25:02.004 --> 00:25:06.900
the estimated sub-tree cost was 0.019,
right?

499
00:25:06.900 --> 00:25:08.050
So when I talk about a percentage,

500
00:25:08.050 --> 00:25:10.196
I'm talking about percentage
of that number, right?

501
00:25:10.196 --> 00:25:17.500
So 20% of 0.019 is not that much, right,
but its out of this total number.

502
00:25:17.500 --> 00:25:24.236
When I look at my new query,
its sub-tree cost 0.009, right?

503
00:25:24.236 --> 00:25:26.480
Less than half.

504
00:25:26.480 --> 00:25:30.180
Less than half the estimated
sub-tree cost of the other query.

505
00:25:30.180 --> 00:25:33.113
Remember I said by eliminating that sort
we should be able to make a query run

506
00:25:33.113 --> 00:25:34.150
twice as fast?

507
00:25:34.150 --> 00:25:35.309
We did, all right?

508
00:25:35.309 --> 00:25:38.890
It's running twice as fast
as that other operator.

509
00:25:38.890 --> 00:25:46.960
And that's a big deal, that's a big chunk
of time and CPU and memory that we save.

510
00:25:46.960 --> 00:25:48.470
In this case, mostly the CPU.

511
00:25:48.470 --> 00:25:53.350
That it was able to do it a lot faster
cuz it's not having to sort 20,000 rows.

512
00:25:53.350 --> 00:25:56.440
It just finds it, generates it,
and sticks it out right here.

513
00:25:56.440 --> 00:26:01.643
So, that is a great way to grab
that data and much more efficient.

514
00:26:01.643 --> 00:26:03.835
Now, how would I have known that?

515
00:26:03.835 --> 00:26:04.795
I might not have, right?

516
00:26:04.795 --> 00:26:07.335
If I wrote the original query and
it worked and I was happy with it,

517
00:26:07.335 --> 00:26:09.015
I might have just left it, right?

518
00:26:09.015 --> 00:26:10.365
But if I start looking at my server and

519
00:26:10.365 --> 00:26:12.295
trying to find ways to
improve performance,

520
00:26:12.295 --> 00:26:15.875
that's when we break down that query,
we find spots where we might be able

521
00:26:15.875 --> 00:26:18.690
to break it into a subquery
that's far more simple.

522
00:26:18.690 --> 00:26:20.420
And then we check performance and
we see where we get it.

523
00:26:20.420 --> 00:26:23.510
So here,
the subquery made a huge difference.

524
00:26:23.510 --> 00:26:26.210
I can get twice the power
out of my servers now,

525
00:26:26.210 --> 00:26:28.030
assuming this is the only
query I ever run.

526
00:26:28.030 --> 00:26:30.880
This is a little specialized,
so maybe not the best example.

527
00:26:30.880 --> 00:26:34.540
But you can get a lot more performance out
of your servers if you optimize this way.

528
00:26:34.540 --> 00:26:37.010
And that's what subqueries let you do.
>> Fantastic, Don.

529
00:26:37.010 --> 00:26:40.036
All right, great look at subqueries, or
at least a first look at subqueries.

530
00:26:40.036 --> 00:26:42.920
I know we got a little more that
you wanna talk about with these.

531
00:26:42.920 --> 00:26:45.220
Unfortunately, we are out of time for
this particular episode.

532
00:26:45.220 --> 00:26:48.436
So we're gonna have to come back and do
a part two, if that's okay with you, Don.

533
00:26:48.436 --> 00:26:49.760
>> Absolutely, definitely come back.

534
00:26:49.760 --> 00:26:52.870
What I just showed you right there
was the simplest form of a subquery.

535
00:26:52.870 --> 00:26:54.360
I want to go a little more advanced and

536
00:26:54.360 --> 00:26:56.210
show you guys some more
complex subqueries.

537
00:26:56.210 --> 00:26:59.534
And I also want to show you
how subqueries can be misused.

538
00:26:59.534 --> 00:27:01.070
I just made them look really good, right?

539
00:27:01.070 --> 00:27:02.501
It works twice as fast!

540
00:27:02.501 --> 00:27:04.820
But they can actually be
twice as bad sometimes.

541
00:27:04.820 --> 00:27:06.345
And so
I want to show you guys how to spot that,

542
00:27:06.345 --> 00:27:08.370
and we'll do all that in part two.
>> Fantastic.

543
00:27:08.370 --> 00:27:09.640
All right, well,
hpe to see everybody there.

544
00:27:09.640 --> 00:27:11.170
I hope you enjoyed watching this one.

545
00:27:11.170 --> 00:27:13.990
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

546
00:27:13.990 --> 00:27:14.580
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

547
00:27:14.580 --> 00:27:19.843
>> We'll see you next time.

548
00:27:19.843 --> 00:27:22.831
[MUSIC]

549
00:27:22.831 --> 00:27:25.648
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use subqueries to make complex queries more efficient. He explains how query execution plans are calculated and then shows how to measure whether or not a subquery can provide a performance improvement over a complex query.
episodes.title: Subqueries Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:01.933
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.933 --> 00:00:06.853
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.853 --> 00:00:09.209
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:09.209 --> 00:00:12.929
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Hello,

5
00:00:12.929 --> 00:00:17.378
welcome to another exciting episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:17.378 --> 00:00:22.060
In this episode, we're gonna be taking a
look at query and data with transact SQL.

7
00:00:22.060 --> 00:00:25.170
This is actually a part two, so if you
missed part one, make sure you go back and

8
00:00:25.170 --> 00:00:26.370
check that one out.

9
00:00:26.370 --> 00:00:28.738
Here to continue on with
our subqueries is Mr.

10
00:00:28.738 --> 00:00:30.895
Don Pezet, how are you doing, Don?
>> Hi,

11
00:00:30.895 --> 00:00:34.139
I am ready to do a substandard
job presenting subqueries.

12
00:00:34.139 --> 00:00:36.536
[LAUGH] So in the last episode,
if you watched part one,

13
00:00:36.536 --> 00:00:38.160
we got a chance to see subqueries.

14
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:41.840
And I showed how we can leverage them
to make our queries far more efficient.

15
00:00:41.840 --> 00:00:46.047
So we went through an example of
where we were pulling up which of our

16
00:00:46.047 --> 00:00:48.387
salespeople got the biggest bonus.

17
00:00:48.387 --> 00:00:51.980
And I wrote it as a normal query,
a single query statement, originally.

18
00:00:51.980 --> 00:00:55.949
And then we broke it into pieces as
a subquery, and saw that by doing it that

19
00:00:55.949 --> 00:01:00.318
way, by doing it as two steps, we were
actually able to double our performance.

20
00:01:00.318 --> 00:01:04.796
We were able to decrease the cost
of that query by over 50%.

21
00:01:04.796 --> 00:01:07.722
Which is really an amazing gain, and
really helped to highlight how important

22
00:01:07.722 --> 00:01:10.580
subqueries are, and how we should know
about them as an optimization tool.

23
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:14.240
And we're gonna kinda continue
going with that here in part two.

24
00:01:14.240 --> 00:01:15.832
>> Fantastic, yeah it was really neat,

25
00:01:15.832 --> 00:01:18.416
the way we could, as you were saying,
if running at one time,

26
00:01:18.416 --> 00:01:20.189
it didn't seem like we gained that much.

27
00:01:20.189 --> 00:01:21.825
But we can use our imagination and

28
00:01:21.825 --> 00:01:25.112
think about a large customer running
those queries over and over.

29
00:01:25.112 --> 00:01:29.210
That part where we save,
we cut it in half, that's a huge gain.

30
00:01:29.210 --> 00:01:34.724
So is that example that you showed us
representative of most subqueries then?

31
00:01:34.724 --> 00:01:37.924
>> For those of you taking the exam,

32
00:01:37.924 --> 00:01:40.331
yes, in real life, no.

33
00:01:40.331 --> 00:01:42.680
So what I showed you right there
was pretty straightforward.

34
00:01:42.680 --> 00:01:44.660
And in fact,
let me bring it back up on the screen.

35
00:01:44.660 --> 00:01:48.360
So the query I started with in the last
episode was this guy right here.

36
00:01:48.360 --> 00:01:53.350
And it had a top operation and an order by
operation, to help find the biggest value

37
00:01:53.350 --> 00:01:57.590
in a articular set of data,
which was pretty inefficient.

38
00:01:57.590 --> 00:02:02.535
And I rewrote that by using a simple
query, this guy, the select max bonus from

39
00:02:02.535 --> 00:02:07.440
sales.salesperson, to reduce
the amount of results that I got.

40
00:02:07.440 --> 00:02:11.020
Now, in this example,
the subquery I used was super,

41
00:02:11.020 --> 00:02:15.240
super simple, it's returning one value.

42
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:20.010
That's called a scalar query,
when I run that, I get a single result.

43
00:02:20.010 --> 00:02:22.160
And it doesn't matter
how many times I run it,

44
00:02:22.160 --> 00:02:26.760
or in what context I use it,
it's always returning one result.

45
00:02:26.760 --> 00:02:30.912
But a subquery doesnt have to be that
way, a subquery could return a table, and

46
00:02:30.912 --> 00:02:32.825
they call it a table-valued query.

47
00:02:32.825 --> 00:02:34.970
If you watched the functions episode,
these are familiar terms.

48
00:02:34.970 --> 00:02:36.325
Cuz we had scalar functions and

49
00:02:36.325 --> 00:02:39.300
table-valued functions,
same thing with subqueries, right?

50
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:43.790
Now, with a table-valued subquery,
what you'll find is

51
00:02:43.790 --> 00:02:47.340
that they don't usually have the same
return on investment, right?

52
00:02:47.340 --> 00:02:50.350
That by taking the time
to write this subquery,

53
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:52.900
I doubled my capacity to run this query.

54
00:02:52.900 --> 00:02:55.020
That was a pretty good
return on investment,

55
00:02:55.020 --> 00:02:59.065
right, but when you start dealing with
table value, it's not always as great.

56
00:02:59.065 --> 00:03:02.776
So I wanna show you guys an example
of a table value subquery.

57
00:03:02.776 --> 00:03:04.869
And I also wanna show you an example
of how sometimes it doesn't make

58
00:03:04.869 --> 00:03:05.615
a difference, right?

59
00:03:05.615 --> 00:03:07.405
So let me come in here,

60
00:03:07.405 --> 00:03:11.600
and I'm gonna write this query,
well, I'll write a new query.

61
00:03:11.600 --> 00:03:18.251
Let's pull up a list of our customers,
or our salespeople, right?

62
00:03:18.251 --> 00:03:20.930
Remember, I said there
were 17 salespeople.

63
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:22.833
And I've got this table,

64
00:03:22.833 --> 00:03:27.920
if I do select * from sales.salesperson,
that table right there.

65
00:03:27.920 --> 00:03:34.086
I can query against it, I get 17 rows
back, each one is a salesperson.

66
00:03:34.086 --> 00:03:37.667
And it's all right here, that's great,
but it doesn't have their first name and

67
00:03:37.667 --> 00:03:38.445
their last name.

68
00:03:38.445 --> 00:03:41.500
So I wanna connect to get their first
name and last name, and bring it back.

69
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:44.551
First name and last name are in that
person.person table that has almost

70
00:03:44.551 --> 00:03:47.000
20,000 rows, it's a big table, right.

71
00:03:47.000 --> 00:03:51.678
So when I put these together I can
get that as a subquery if I want, or

72
00:03:51.678 --> 00:03:54.400
there's other creative
ways on how to do this.

73
00:03:54.400 --> 00:03:59.170
So here, I wanna pull the information,
I'm gonna say that I wanna select, and

74
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:01.710
I need to pull from more than
one location on this one.

75
00:04:01.710 --> 00:04:07.420
So I wanna pull from person.person,

76
00:04:07.420 --> 00:04:09.830
because I want to get the first name and
last name.

77
00:04:09.830 --> 00:04:13.426
So I'm gonna come in here and
tell it, I want first name and

78
00:04:13.426 --> 00:04:19.150
last name from person.person, right?

79
00:04:19.150 --> 00:04:23.540
But I don't want everybody from
person.person, I just want my salespeople.

80
00:04:23.540 --> 00:04:27.810
So I'm gonna add a where BusinessEntityID,

81
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:29.570
that's the identifier for
each of my people.

82
00:04:29.570 --> 00:04:32.975
See here in the sales.salesperson table,
I've got the BusinessEntityID for

83
00:04:32.975 --> 00:04:34.780
each of these salespeople.

84
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:39.092
So I'm gonna say,
I wanna pull from person.person where

85
00:04:39.092 --> 00:04:44.640
the BusinessEntityID is in, and
then I'm gonna run a table valued query.

86
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:53.602
I'm going to say select BusinessEntityID
from sales.salesperson,

87
00:04:53.602 --> 00:04:58.988
which if I spell it
wrong is not gonna work.

88
00:04:58.988 --> 00:05:01.379
Intellisense to save the day there,
and then I'll close that off.

89
00:05:01.379 --> 00:05:02.934
>> So now we've got our inner query,

90
00:05:02.934 --> 00:05:06.419
instead of returning a single value,
it's actually gonna return a table for

91
00:05:06.419 --> 00:05:08.063
all of those salespeople.
>> Right,

92
00:05:08.063 --> 00:05:10.840
yeah, and you can even highlight and
just run that piece.

93
00:05:10.840 --> 00:05:14.655
If I just run that piece there it is,
I get a list,

94
00:05:14.655 --> 00:05:18.205
these BusinessEntityIDs are salespeople.

95
00:05:18.205 --> 00:05:22.931
And it's gonna pull first name and
last name from person.person only

96
00:05:22.931 --> 00:05:27.680
if their BusinessEntityID is in
this resultant set right here.

97
00:05:27.680 --> 00:05:31.250
This is useful because if I add new
business entity IDs in the future,

98
00:05:31.250 --> 00:05:34.710
then this query will automatically pick
them up, the data stays current, and

99
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:36.170
we get that information.

100
00:05:36.170 --> 00:05:39.690
So it's gonna reach out, and
it's gonna grab that data, and

101
00:05:39.690 --> 00:05:43.780
when I run that,
here I get my first name and my last name.

102
00:05:43.780 --> 00:05:47.616
I guess I probably should have
added business entity ID to it, but

103
00:05:47.616 --> 00:05:50.428
whatever, and
I can see that I got 17 people.

104
00:05:50.428 --> 00:05:54.219
I got a first name and a last name,
which are not stored in sales.salesperson,

105
00:05:54.219 --> 00:05:56.500
those are stored in person.person.

106
00:05:56.500 --> 00:06:01.640
And I was able to leverage a resultant set
of data from a completely separate table

107
00:06:01.640 --> 00:06:03.510
that gave me that information.

108
00:06:03.510 --> 00:06:08.820
So there's a table valued subquery that's
different than a scalar sub query.

109
00:06:08.820 --> 00:06:12.722
It's not just one piece of information,
it's a whole collection of data, and

110
00:06:12.722 --> 00:06:15.732
I can then go and use that.
>> It kinda looks like something we've

111
00:06:15.732 --> 00:06:19.022
done before, Don, where we used
a join to get those similar results.

112
00:06:19.022 --> 00:06:19.796
>> Yeah, and

113
00:06:19.796 --> 00:06:22.811
we certainly could have used a join here.

114
00:06:22.811 --> 00:06:26.575
Joins can be a little bit more complex,
because you've got inner joins and outer

115
00:06:26.575 --> 00:06:30.350
joins, and left, right, and full outer
joins, and which one matches up here?

116
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:34.798
If I do a join between person.person and
sales.salesperson, well,

117
00:06:34.798 --> 00:06:38.144
there's only 17 entries
in sales.salesperson.

118
00:06:38.144 --> 00:06:44.452
So what happened to the other 19,982 or
whatever, 83 records?

119
00:06:44.452 --> 00:06:47.167
Well, depending on which type of join
I do, it might leave them out, or

120
00:06:47.167 --> 00:06:48.410
it might include them.

121
00:06:48.410 --> 00:06:50.390
So it might be a little more
complex to do a join, but

122
00:06:50.390 --> 00:06:52.470
it can achieve the same exact thing.

123
00:06:52.470 --> 00:06:56.370
In fact, here, let me rewrite
this as a join, and you'll see.

124
00:06:56.370 --> 00:07:02.820
I could have said select, and here I'm
going to have to pull a first name and

125
00:07:02.820 --> 00:07:08.200
last name, which are going to
come from the person.person.

126
00:07:08.200 --> 00:07:11.290
Since I'm dealing with two tables,
I've gotta do an alias, so

127
00:07:11.290 --> 00:07:13.085
I can keep all this straight.

128
00:07:13.085 --> 00:07:17.640
It's gonna come from person.person,
I didn't have to do aliases in the first

129
00:07:17.640 --> 00:07:21.030
query because it's two separate queries,
right?

130
00:07:21.030 --> 00:07:23.910
So it knows in the first select statement,
I'm getting first name and

131
00:07:23.910 --> 00:07:26.120
last name from person.person.

132
00:07:26.120 --> 00:07:28.732
And the subquery knows I'm
getting BusinessEntityID from

133
00:07:28.732 --> 00:07:29.940
the sales.salesperson.

134
00:07:31.040 --> 00:07:35.636
But in a join, it doesn't know which of
the two tables I'm getting first name and

135
00:07:35.636 --> 00:07:36.595
last name from.

136
00:07:36.595 --> 00:07:39.870
So I have to tell it, that's why
I'm doing the alias for p there,

137
00:07:39.870 --> 00:07:41.730
so it knows which table to pull from.

138
00:07:41.730 --> 00:07:45.100
A little more complex, but
the end result will be the same.

139
00:07:45.100 --> 00:07:49.992
I'm gonna do a join on sales.salesperson,
and

140
00:07:49.992 --> 00:07:53.342
I'll give that one an alias of s.

141
00:07:53.342 --> 00:08:02.016
And I'll link these together based
on p.businessentityid equaling s.

142
00:08:02.016 --> 00:08:03.970
Business entity ID.

143
00:08:03.970 --> 00:08:05.636
Like that, okay?

144
00:08:05.636 --> 00:08:08.210
Now, I'm doing an inner join.

145
00:08:08.210 --> 00:08:12.640
And that means that if it doesn't find a
match, if it's like a null on one side or

146
00:08:12.640 --> 00:08:14.440
the other, it's just gonna leave it out.

147
00:08:14.440 --> 00:08:15.460
And so it's gonna get excluded.

148
00:08:15.460 --> 00:08:19.010
And that's what I want, as opposed
to doing an outer join on this one.

149
00:08:19.010 --> 00:08:21.670
And if you watched our join episodes,
you remember that.

150
00:08:21.670 --> 00:08:24.942
Now, when I run it,
I get the information back.

151
00:08:24.942 --> 00:08:28.682
And as I look, I've got 17 entries.

152
00:08:28.682 --> 00:08:29.980
I've got the same data, right?

153
00:08:29.980 --> 00:08:34.840
This is effectively the same result in
set whether I do it as a subquery or

154
00:08:34.840 --> 00:08:37.790
whether I do it as a parent query here.

155
00:08:37.790 --> 00:08:42.950
In this scenario they both run,
they both get me the same information.

156
00:08:42.950 --> 00:08:48.380
So you might ask yourself-
>> Which one is better performance or?

157
00:08:48.380 --> 00:08:49.330
>> Yeah, exactly.

158
00:08:49.330 --> 00:08:51.610
Which one do I wanna do?

159
00:08:51.610 --> 00:08:56.630
In the last episode, in part one, I showed
you an overwhelming example of where you

160
00:08:56.630 --> 00:08:58.990
absolutely want to do it as a subquery.

161
00:08:58.990 --> 00:09:01.430
Well, I picked this one on purpose.

162
00:09:01.430 --> 00:09:05.070
Because this one is kind of interesting,
right?

163
00:09:05.070 --> 00:09:08.060
I'm running a select
statement against one table.

164
00:09:08.060 --> 00:09:11.850
But my results are coming
out of a second table.

165
00:09:11.850 --> 00:09:14.550
When I do the join, it's the same.

166
00:09:14.550 --> 00:09:16.920
My results are coming out of one table.

167
00:09:16.920 --> 00:09:20.051
And the join is tying in a second one just
to figure where there's a null value and

168
00:09:20.051 --> 00:09:21.240
where there isn't, right?

169
00:09:22.410 --> 00:09:27.380
When the server goes to execute this,
even though my top query is broken into

170
00:09:27.380 --> 00:09:30.360
two pieces, there's really only
one way it can get that data.

171
00:09:30.360 --> 00:09:34.520
And it's the same way it's gonna get
the data with the join down here.

172
00:09:34.520 --> 00:09:36.640
If I run them both in batch, right, so

173
00:09:36.640 --> 00:09:39.830
they're both gonna run,
I'm gonna get the same result in set.

174
00:09:39.830 --> 00:09:42.650
Well, it's not exactly the same, right?

175
00:09:42.650 --> 00:09:46.260
In the first query,
notice how Stephen Jang is first?

176
00:09:46.260 --> 00:09:48.280
And then Michael Blythe the second?

177
00:09:48.280 --> 00:09:52.410
In the second query, Syed Abbas is
first and David Campbell is second.

178
00:09:52.410 --> 00:09:54.180
They're in a different order, right?

179
00:09:54.180 --> 00:09:57.640
It did actually retrieve the information
a little bit differently.

180
00:09:57.640 --> 00:10:00.880
But the end result is that
they both got 17 rows.

181
00:10:00.880 --> 00:10:05.890
And while in the first query,
might be number six.

182
00:10:05.890 --> 00:10:09.420
In the second query is still in there.

183
00:10:09.420 --> 00:10:11.520
If I can get my mouse right on it.

184
00:10:11.520 --> 00:10:12.646
Fine little line.

185
00:10:12.646 --> 00:10:14.370
There he is, he's number four, right?

186
00:10:14.370 --> 00:10:15.865
So instead of number six,
he's number four.

187
00:10:15.865 --> 00:10:16.800
That doesn't matter to me.

188
00:10:16.800 --> 00:10:18.520
I didn't do a sort operation or anything.

189
00:10:18.520 --> 00:10:20.090
I just needed those people back.

190
00:10:20.090 --> 00:10:21.500
I didn't care what order.

191
00:10:21.500 --> 00:10:26.200
And even if I did a sort operation,
they would both have to do the sort and

192
00:10:26.200 --> 00:10:26.800
provide it to me.

193
00:10:26.800 --> 00:10:28.810
So that's not going to make an impact.

194
00:10:28.810 --> 00:10:32.630
If I look at the execution plans, though,
this is where it gets really interesting.

195
00:10:32.630 --> 00:10:34.440
Look at these two execution plans.

196
00:10:34.440 --> 00:10:38.880
I might need to hide my, well,
I guess I can sort of get in here.

197
00:10:40.240 --> 00:10:45.220
If you take a look at the execution plans,
you might notice something interesting.

198
00:10:45.220 --> 00:10:46.730
>> My eyes aren't that good, Don, but

199
00:10:46.730 --> 00:10:49.740
they look identical.
>> They look identical because they

200
00:10:49.740 --> 00:10:50.710
are identical.

201
00:10:50.710 --> 00:10:56.440
In this case, the sub-query in the JOIN,
it follows the same execution plan.

202
00:10:56.440 --> 00:10:58.990
So, which one is the better option here?

203
00:11:00.050 --> 00:11:01.960
There isn't a better option,
they're the same.

204
00:11:01.960 --> 00:11:05.841
If I look at the sub-tree cost on the
first one, which is not showing up for me.

205
00:11:05.841 --> 00:11:07.965
There we go.
It's 0.011.

206
00:11:07.965 --> 00:11:11.507
If I look at the sub-tree cost
in the second one, 0.011.

207
00:11:11.507 --> 00:11:14.400
And if I went out to full
decimals it's identical, right?

208
00:11:14.400 --> 00:11:16.540
These are the same query, right?

209
00:11:16.540 --> 00:11:19.820
The results are the same,
although maybe a slightly different order,

210
00:11:19.820 --> 00:11:21.910
the results are the same,
the execution plan is the same.

211
00:11:21.910 --> 00:11:25.650
The only thing that's different is how I
wrote it, and that's because when you send

212
00:11:25.650 --> 00:11:30.690
a query to the SQL server,
it has it's own query optimization engine.

213
00:11:30.690 --> 00:11:35.830
IT compiles and optimizes the query
to run it as fast as possible.

214
00:11:35.830 --> 00:11:39.870
And usually, breaking into a subquery
gives it a little more flexibility.

215
00:11:39.870 --> 00:11:41.620
In this case, it didn't make a difference.

216
00:11:41.620 --> 00:11:43.970
Now, it doesn't mean it
will always be like that.

217
00:11:43.970 --> 00:11:47.480
I might go and create some kind of
index later on that facilitates it,

218
00:11:47.480 --> 00:11:49.350
and all of a sudden,
the subquery is better, right?

219
00:11:49.350 --> 00:11:52.790
But this is why it's important to check,
because sometimes

220
00:11:52.790 --> 00:11:56.310
whether you write it one way or another
doesn't necessarily make a difference.

221
00:11:56.310 --> 00:11:58.410
And when I'm faced with
that kind of a decision,

222
00:11:58.410 --> 00:12:01.260
I usually pick whichever one is easier,
right?

223
00:12:01.260 --> 00:12:03.420
Because the easier it is to write a query,

224
00:12:03.420 --> 00:12:05.780
the less likely you are to make a mistake,
right?

225
00:12:05.780 --> 00:12:09.230
So faced with an example like this where
they are both equal, I would look at it

226
00:12:09.230 --> 00:12:13.910
and say, well, if I counted letter for
letter, they're probably the same.

227
00:12:13.910 --> 00:12:17.497
The JOIN is a little more straightforward,
I think.

228
00:12:17.497 --> 00:12:20.602
Because you're selecting right here,
you've got your JOIN statement,

229
00:12:20.602 --> 00:12:21.647
it's super cut and dry.

230
00:12:21.647 --> 00:12:24.927
This one up here, you've got a subquery,
it's got an N statement, so

231
00:12:24.927 --> 00:12:26.200
an extra operator.

232
00:12:26.200 --> 00:12:28.990
I would probably go with a JOIN
in this case over the subquery.

233
00:12:28.990 --> 00:12:32.840
But I couldn't get fired for making one
choice one way or another on this one.

234
00:12:32.840 --> 00:12:33.390
>> It's interesting,

235
00:12:33.390 --> 00:12:36.580
because I was just sitting here
thinking I like the subquery

236
00:12:36.580 --> 00:12:39.080
because it's a little more readable
to me when I'm looking at it.

237
00:12:39.080 --> 00:12:41.430
>> Yeah, there's no aliases.

238
00:12:41.430 --> 00:12:42.740
It would be purely up to you.

239
00:12:42.740 --> 00:12:46.340
So this query is a lot different than
the example from the last episode in that,

240
00:12:46.340 --> 00:12:47.228
one, it's not scalar.

241
00:12:47.228 --> 00:12:49.730
The subquery's returning a table,
table value.

242
00:12:49.730 --> 00:12:52.260
And two, it didn't help us, right?

243
00:12:52.260 --> 00:12:54.790
It's the same as writing a regular query.

244
00:12:54.790 --> 00:12:56.590
So something we always need
to be on the look out for

245
00:12:56.590 --> 00:12:58.781
when we're working with these.
>> All right, Don, so

246
00:12:58.781 --> 00:13:00.690
we have seen where a subquery can benefit.

247
00:13:00.690 --> 00:13:04.985
We've cut that first one execution
cost in half, which is fantastic.

248
00:13:04.985 --> 00:13:08.605
We've seen where a sub-query
really didn't help us at all,

249
00:13:08.605 --> 00:13:10.843
it was almost the same as doing a JOIN.

250
00:13:10.843 --> 00:13:13.930
It came down to which
syntax do we like better.

251
00:13:13.930 --> 00:13:16.660
Are there any times when
a subquery's actually worse

252
00:13:16.660 --> 00:13:19.950
than writing a normal query, or
a join, or doing something like that?

253
00:13:19.950 --> 00:13:20.990
>> Yeah, yeah, there can be.

254
00:13:20.990 --> 00:13:24.100
I would like to say that there aren't,
but there are cases.

255
00:13:24.100 --> 00:13:26.570
And again, it's why we need to
evaluate this, and why it was so

256
00:13:26.570 --> 00:13:27.830
important to me that we did a part two.

257
00:13:27.830 --> 00:13:29.690
Because if you just watched part one,

258
00:13:29.690 --> 00:13:32.770
it was Don told me that
subqueries are the bee's knees,

259
00:13:32.770 --> 00:13:34.660
I'm going to do it everywhere, right?
>> I can cut everything in half.

260
00:13:34.660 --> 00:13:38.144
Yeah, why wouldn't I?
>> If you're not doing subqueries,

261
00:13:38.144 --> 00:13:39.352
your service stinks.

262
00:13:39.352 --> 00:13:41.370
And that might be true.

263
00:13:41.370 --> 00:13:43.410
But it isn't always, so
we need to be on the watch.

264
00:13:43.410 --> 00:13:45.450
And I want to show you
guys another example.

265
00:13:45.450 --> 00:13:47.390
We saw table value.

266
00:13:47.390 --> 00:13:49.260
We also saw scalar.

267
00:13:49.260 --> 00:13:53.259
There's a third type of subquery that
you'll hear people mention every now and

268
00:13:53.259 --> 00:13:55.953
then that's called a correlated subquery,
right?

269
00:13:55.953 --> 00:13:58.687
In every example I've shown so far,

270
00:13:58.687 --> 00:14:04.175
the result of the subquery was
provided to the parent query, right?

271
00:14:04.175 --> 00:14:06.085
Sometimes they call them inner and
outer queries.

272
00:14:06.085 --> 00:14:08.555
I don't like that terminology cuz
it gets confusing with inner and

273
00:14:08.555 --> 00:14:09.815
outer JOINs, right?

274
00:14:09.815 --> 00:14:14.945
But technically, inner and
outer JOINs are subqueries in a sense.

275
00:14:14.945 --> 00:14:16.922
But your inner query would
be the subquery, and

276
00:14:16.922 --> 00:14:18.515
your outer query would be the parent.

277
00:14:19.660 --> 00:14:23.370
Normally, the inner query, or
the subquery, is handing it's results to

278
00:14:23.370 --> 00:14:26.990
the outer query, or the parent, and
the parent takes action based on it.

279
00:14:26.990 --> 00:14:28.780
With a correlated subquery,

280
00:14:28.780 --> 00:14:34.060
though, the parent query might actually
be feeding data to the subquery.

281
00:14:34.060 --> 00:14:36.030
And the subquery might be
feeding data back, right?

282
00:14:36.030 --> 00:14:38.280
They're correlated to work together.

283
00:14:38.280 --> 00:14:42.880
In every example I've shown so far,
I could highlight the subquery and

284
00:14:42.880 --> 00:14:45.820
run it by itself, and
it would run independently.

285
00:14:45.820 --> 00:14:49.350
In a correlated subquery,
it can't run independently.

286
00:14:49.350 --> 00:14:53.490
There's something in that subquery
that comes from the parent.

287
00:14:53.490 --> 00:14:56.317
And if you run the subquery by itself,
it's missing that piece and

288
00:14:56.317 --> 00:14:57.336
it's broken, right?

289
00:14:57.336 --> 00:15:00.760
So the two are fully dependent,
versus the queries I've been writing.

290
00:15:00.760 --> 00:15:05.240
Now, because they're dependent,
what can the server do?

291
00:15:05.240 --> 00:15:09.940
I said that subqueries really benefit
because the server has more pieces

292
00:15:09.940 --> 00:15:14.040
that it can break apart and
optimize differently if it wants to.

293
00:15:14.040 --> 00:15:16.830
If I write a single query, it just has
to work with that as a single block,

294
00:15:16.830 --> 00:15:19.370
it has less options available to it,
right?

295
00:15:19.370 --> 00:15:23.640
If I do a correlated subquery, I'm taking
away some of those options, right?

296
00:15:23.640 --> 00:15:25.470
They do have to work together.

297
00:15:25.470 --> 00:15:28.930
Now, there are a few,
I've seen some textbook

298
00:15:28.930 --> 00:15:33.560
case examples of how you can use this for
great good, right?

299
00:15:33.560 --> 00:15:36.340
For the forces of good and fighting evil.

300
00:15:36.340 --> 00:15:39.350
But I was telling Mike before the show,
and I'll be honest with you,

301
00:15:39.350 --> 00:15:40.045
if you're out there.

302
00:15:40.045 --> 00:15:43.990
I've worked with hundreds,
maybe thousands, of queries at this point

303
00:15:43.990 --> 00:15:48.323
in production environments, and I have
never once seen a correlated query that

304
00:15:48.323 --> 00:15:52.421
resulted in better performance than
just writing a single query, right?

305
00:15:52.421 --> 00:15:57.601
So it is a type of subquery that is
either commonly misunderstood or

306
00:15:57.601 --> 00:16:00.107
misused or just not a great one.

307
00:16:00.107 --> 00:16:02.996
So I wanna show you guys an example
of that so you can spot it and

308
00:16:02.996 --> 00:16:04.970
recognize what's going on.

309
00:16:04.970 --> 00:16:09.060
So I've got a query here, and

310
00:16:09.060 --> 00:16:11.530
the way I would normally write
this is a little more complex.

311
00:16:11.530 --> 00:16:16.020
I tried to format it so we can kind
of make sense of what was going on.

312
00:16:16.020 --> 00:16:19.370
If we look at it,
I've got a big select statement here.

313
00:16:19.370 --> 00:16:23.530
I'm pulling the customerID
as my first column, and

314
00:16:23.530 --> 00:16:27.560
then I'm pulling some calculated
value as my second column.

315
00:16:27.560 --> 00:16:30.866
And I'm pulling that from
the sales.salescustomer database, and

316
00:16:30.866 --> 00:16:34.172
giving it an a list of c, and
I'm ordering it by total sales, right?

317
00:16:34.172 --> 00:16:39.070
That subquery is a join, right, so
it's actually a little more complex,

318
00:16:39.070 --> 00:16:43.680
I'm pulling a calculated value,
the UnitPrice times the OrderQty.

319
00:16:43.680 --> 00:16:46.760
What I'm trying to do here is,

320
00:16:46.760 --> 00:16:52.540
I'm trying to figure out which customer
spent the most money with me, right?

321
00:16:52.540 --> 00:16:56.130
So I need the CustomerID, so
I can tell who the customer is, and

322
00:16:56.130 --> 00:16:58.380
then I need to find out
how much money they spent.

323
00:16:58.380 --> 00:17:01.670
But the problem is,
we don't store that anywhere.

324
00:17:01.670 --> 00:17:06.110
I have my order history, or
my SalesOrderDetail table.

325
00:17:06.110 --> 00:17:08.488
And that has how much each order costs,
but

326
00:17:08.488 --> 00:17:11.078
it doesn't have a CustomerID
attached to it.

327
00:17:11.078 --> 00:17:16.434
If I were to look at that table,
it has the, well, here, I can show you.

328
00:17:16.434 --> 00:17:20.410
If I do a SELECT * FROM SalesOrderDetail,
so

329
00:17:20.410 --> 00:17:24.504
I'm just gonna pull that
little block there.

330
00:17:24.504 --> 00:17:27.341
All right,
when I look at SalesOrderDetail,

331
00:17:27.341 --> 00:17:32.145
I have a SalesOrderID number and a
SalesOrderDetailID and tracking number and

332
00:17:32.145 --> 00:17:36.604
so on, all the way over to this UnitPrice,
and there's OrderQty here.

333
00:17:36.604 --> 00:17:39.186
So if the unit price was $2024,

334
00:17:39.186 --> 00:17:44.280
that has to be multiplied by 3 here
cuz there's an order quantity of 3.

335
00:17:44.280 --> 00:17:47.750
So that's why I'm multiplying
UnitPrice times OrderQty,

336
00:17:47.750 --> 00:17:49.280
to find out how much they actually spent.

337
00:17:49.280 --> 00:17:52.648
I'm not even storing a total value, when
I say I, this is a sample database from

338
00:17:52.648 --> 00:17:55.935
Microsoft, they chose not to store
that total value, for whatever reason.

339
00:17:55.935 --> 00:18:01.276
So I have to calculate it, right,
well, then that's just one order.

340
00:18:01.276 --> 00:18:05.634
A customer might have spent money on 10,
20, 100 different orders.

341
00:18:05.634 --> 00:18:07.539
>> Hopefully [LAUGH].

342
00:18:07.539 --> 00:18:08.179
>> Hopefully, so

343
00:18:08.179 --> 00:18:10.900
I'm gonna correlate all these
with who the customer was.

344
00:18:10.900 --> 00:18:12.770
And that's why I'm doing a join here, and

345
00:18:12.770 --> 00:18:16.810
I'm doing the join on
Sales.SalesOrderHeader.

346
00:18:16.810 --> 00:18:21.878
Because that table, if I were to
pull from it, if I do a SELECT

347
00:18:21.878 --> 00:18:27.362
* FROM Sales.SalesOrderHeader,

348
00:18:27.362 --> 00:18:30.620
like that, and we come and pull it up.

349
00:18:30.620 --> 00:18:34.295
It's got the SalesOrderID that
we just saw, got the OrderDate,

350
00:18:34.295 --> 00:18:35.960
the DueDate, ShipDate.

351
00:18:35.960 --> 00:18:40.299

another way I could've done this?

00:30:25.860 --> 00:30:27.110
Could I have broken it into subqueries?

575
00:30:27.110 --> 00:30:27.870
Would it have been better?

576
00:30:27.870 --> 00:30:29.640
Let me try, right?

577
00:30:29.640 --> 00:30:30.960
When you're working your deadline, sure.

578
00:30:30.960 --> 00:30:33.430
You just just have to get
something done as well as you can.

579
00:30:33.430 --> 00:30:38.360
But once you're past that point,
I'm saying something silly here which is,

580
00:30:38.360 --> 00:30:39.270
when you're bored,
>> [LAUGH]

581
00:30:39.270 --> 00:30:39.950
>> You're sitting at your

582
00:30:39.950 --> 00:30:41.280
desk with nothing to do, right?

583
00:30:41.280 --> 00:30:43.941
Cuz that happens to us.
>> That happens all the time, yeah.

584
00:30:43.941 --> 00:30:46.160
[LAUGH]
>> So if that happens, though, or

585
00:30:46.160 --> 00:30:49.061
set aside some time and say,
all right, once a month,

586
00:30:49.061 --> 00:30:52.450
I'm going to look at the ten
most expensive quarries.

587
00:30:52.450 --> 00:30:53.840
Whoever is the database administrator for

588
00:30:53.840 --> 00:30:56.800
your server, they can actually
pull an expensive query report.

589
00:30:56.800 --> 00:30:58.630
That's actually what it's called.

590
00:30:58.630 --> 00:31:02.195
And they can show you which queries
consume the most resources on the server,

591
00:31:02.195 --> 00:31:02.890
right?

592
00:31:02.890 --> 00:31:04.970
Or which ones run the most frequently.

593
00:31:04.970 --> 00:31:06.380
They can show that to you.

594
00:31:06.380 --> 00:31:07.870
And you can take it and
look at those tens.

595
00:31:07.870 --> 00:31:11.480
Look at the top ten and
say can I make any of those better?

596
00:31:11.480 --> 00:31:12.630
And experiment around with it.

597
00:31:12.630 --> 00:31:14.000
Try them three, four, different ways.

598
00:31:14.000 --> 00:31:16.590
Cuz you'll find there's many
different ways to get the same data.

599
00:31:16.590 --> 00:31:18.990
Maybe breaking them into
subqueries solves the problem.

600
00:31:18.990 --> 00:31:21.250
Maybe taking away a subquery
solves the problem.

601
00:31:21.250 --> 00:31:24.812
Maybe doing a group by versus
a join with a statement.

602
00:31:24.812 --> 00:31:26.420
There's different ways to achieve it.

603
00:31:26.420 --> 00:31:27.790
Some might be better than others.

604
00:31:27.790 --> 00:31:31.470
And unfortunately, I can't tell you,
yeah, this one way is better,

605
00:31:31.470 --> 00:31:32.720
do it this way, right?

606
00:31:32.720 --> 00:31:35.270
Because it also varies
based on your data set.

607
00:31:35.270 --> 00:31:41.220
If you have 20 rows, one query might
work really well versus another.

608
00:31:41.220 --> 00:31:43.870
But if you have 10,000 rows,
or 10 million rows,

609
00:31:43.870 --> 00:31:46.540
the bad query from before might actually
be the better query now, right?

610
00:31:46.540 --> 00:31:49.900
The more data you have, or
let's say it's the same set of data.

611
00:31:49.900 --> 00:31:55.444
If you have normalized data
that has a lot of duplicates,

612
00:31:55.444 --> 00:31:58.571
then that query might run fast.

613
00:31:58.571 --> 00:32:03.567
But if somebody has denormalized data,
that's a mess, well,

614
00:32:03.567 --> 00:32:05.790
it might not run so well.

615
00:32:05.790 --> 00:32:09.310
So, you've gotta try it against
your own data and see, and

616
00:32:09.310 --> 00:32:10.980
determine which one works best.

617
00:32:10.980 --> 00:32:12.350
And it may even change over time.

618
00:32:12.350 --> 00:32:16.110
The way you've written a query
today might be the best way.

619
00:32:16.110 --> 00:32:19.500
But, three years from now when your
data base has grown and fragmented and

620
00:32:19.500 --> 00:32:21.950
changed, it may not be
the best way anymore.

621
00:32:21.950 --> 00:32:25.320
And so, that's all the challenge
that a database administrator has.

622
00:32:25.320 --> 00:32:28.598
And as somebody writing transact SQLs,
the challenge hat you have,

623
00:32:28.598 --> 00:32:30.816
recognize there's more
than one way to do it.

624
00:32:30.816 --> 00:32:33.829
And what I usually do is if I
figure out the more than one way,

625
00:32:33.829 --> 00:32:36.560
I document them with why I
chose one way over another.

626
00:32:36.560 --> 00:32:40.510
So that my second challenge of making sure
I'm running things the best, when I go and

627
00:32:40.510 --> 00:32:42.270
evaluate it in the future,

628
00:32:42.270 --> 00:32:44.900
I've already documented the three
other ways I could have done it.

629
00:32:44.900 --> 00:32:47.430
So let me just run those three ways and
compare the execution list.

630
00:32:47.430 --> 00:32:49.820
It's easy enough and
now you kind of spot it and go forward.

631
00:32:49.820 --> 00:32:54.145
So that's how we leverage
subqueries to achieve world peace.

632
00:32:54.145 --> 00:32:55.710
>> [LAUGH] Fantastic, Don.

633
00:32:55.710 --> 00:32:57.280
Hopefully we can get
world peace out of that.

634
00:32:57.280 --> 00:33:00.430
But if not, hey,
we got a great look at subqueries.

635
00:33:00.430 --> 00:33:05.790
We looked at scalar subqueries,
tabular subqueries, correlated subqueries,

636
00:33:05.790 --> 00:33:09.300
and really good examples of when
sometimes they really do benefit us.

637
00:33:09.300 --> 00:33:12.370
Sometimes it's kind of a wash and
we're looking more at maybe which

638
00:33:12.370 --> 00:33:13.810
one we like better.
>> [LAUGH]

639
00:33:13.810 --> 00:33:15.720
>> Sometimes, they don't help us.

640
00:33:15.720 --> 00:33:17.660
They might even slow things down.

641
00:33:17.660 --> 00:33:20.260
But as Don pointed out, it's one of
those things where's no absolute.

642
00:33:20.260 --> 00:33:23.630
It's something that you're gonna have
to look at using your data sets and

643
00:33:23.630 --> 00:33:26.380
your results, and
see which one works best for you.

644
00:33:26.380 --> 00:33:27.770
But hey, now you've got the options.

645
00:33:27.770 --> 00:33:31.770
So I hope everybody out there enjoyed
watching this episode and the part one.

646
00:33:31.770 --> 00:33:32.900
Make sure you go back and check that out.

647
00:33:32.900 --> 00:33:36.520
For now, signing off for ITPRO.TV I've
been your host, Mike Roderick.

648
00:33:36.520 --> 00:33:37.320
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

649
00:33:37.320 --> 00:33:38.130
>> And we'll see you next time.

650
00:33:38.130 --> 00:33:44.800
[MUSIC]

651
00:33:44.800 --> 00:33:47.867
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don expands on methods by which we can group query results in Transact-SQL. He begins by demonstrating the limitations of the GROUP BY command. He then shows to we can use GROUPING SETS, CUBE and ROLLUP to provide more advanced aggregation of our results.
episodes.title: Grouping Sets and Cubes

episodes.description: In this episode, Don expands on methods by which we can group query results in Transact-SQL. He begins by demonstrating the limitations of the GROUP BY command. He then shows to we can use GROUPING SETS, CUBE and ROLLUP to provide more advanced aggregation of our results.
episodes.title: Grouping Sets and Cubes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to four methods to rank results in Transact-SQL. He explains the different scenarios where ranking data is useful and then demonstrates using RANK, DENSE_RANK, NTILE and ROW_NUMBER to provide ranking data in our desired form.
episodes.title: Ranking Data with Window Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to four methods to rank results in Transact-SQL. He explains the different scenarios where ranking data is useful and then demonstrates using RANK, DENSE_RANK, NTILE and ROW_NUMBER to provide ranking data in our desired form.
episodes.title: Ranking Data with Window Functions Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don highlights a common problem with SQL tables where data is arranged in a form that is not useful for our needs. He then demonstrates how we can alter the arrangement of table data in RAM using the PIVOT and UNPIVOT commands to achieve our desired results.
episodes.title: Pivot and Unpivot Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how we can use functions to create on-demand views of existing table data. He then highlights a common error when using functions that return a table in our queries. Finally, he demonstrates how to use APPLY to overcome that error so that we can properly leverage our custom functions.
episodes.title: Table Expressions and Apply
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.059 --> 00:00:01.348
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.348 --> 00:00:02.931
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.931 --> 00:00:07.090
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.090 --> 00:00:08.393

5
00:00:08.393 --> 00:00:13.248
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

6

choosing ITPro.TV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:17.630
I'm your host, Zach Memos,

8
00:00:17.630 --> 00:00:22.890
as we continue on with we're reading data
with Transact SQL, Table Expressions and

9
00:00:22.890 --> 00:00:27.220
Applies is the title of this episode and
Don Pezet is here to show us the way.

10
00:00:27.220 --> 00:00:29.660
Don, great to have you.
>> And great to be back and

11
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:32.360
continuing our journey in the work
of Microsoft's Transact SQL.

12
00:00:32.360 --> 00:00:33.260
And in this episode,

13
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:36.410
we're going to take a look at really
we're going to look at apply.

14
00:00:36.410 --> 00:00:38.410
Apply is the star of this episode.

15
00:00:38.410 --> 00:00:41.380
But I can't really talk about apply
without talking about common table

16
00:00:41.380 --> 00:00:43.660
expressions, or CTEs, at the same time.

17
00:00:43.660 --> 00:00:44.970
So we're gonna group them all together and

18
00:00:44.970 --> 00:00:47.880
get a chance to see that common
table expressions, if you're not

19
00:00:47.880 --> 00:00:51.380
familiar with that, these are just
functions that we use to represent tables.

20
00:00:51.380 --> 00:00:53.800
We actually talked about them
back in the function episode.

21
00:00:53.800 --> 00:00:57.820
And apply, if you've never heard of it,
is very similar to a join.

22
00:00:57.820 --> 00:01:00.880
It's a way that I can take data
from two different tables and

23
00:01:00.880 --> 00:01:04.720
kind of combine it together to
represent a single set of information.

24
00:01:04.720 --> 00:01:08.440
So we're gonna get a chance to see
what apply does, how it works,

25
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:09.400
why we would use it.

26
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:13.180
All of that right here in this episode.
>> Don, if apply is similar to join then

27
00:01:13.180 --> 00:01:16.670
why not just use join?
>> Valid question, right.

28
00:01:16.670 --> 00:01:20.750
There's a lot of technologies that we talk
about in the series that seems similar

29
00:01:20.750 --> 00:01:23.330
like in the ranking episode.

30
00:01:23.330 --> 00:01:27.140
You got order buy or sorts which
Ranking is really very similar.

31
00:01:27.140 --> 00:01:28.410
So which one do you pick?

32
00:01:28.410 --> 00:01:29.450
Same thing happens here.

33
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:34.480
Apply and join are actually very
similar and nine times outta ten,

34
00:01:34.480 --> 00:01:38.180
maybe 99 times out of 100,
I don't know, you're gonna use join.

35
00:01:38.180 --> 00:01:39.380
Join is the way to go.

36
00:01:39.380 --> 00:01:44.330
So in the transact-SQL basics at the
beginning of this series we covered joins.

37
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:46.000
We didn't even mention applies.

38
00:01:46.000 --> 00:01:49.030
Same applies here for advanced, right.

39
00:01:49.030 --> 00:01:51.720
And the reason is applies
are really designed for

40
00:01:51.720 --> 00:01:54.630
one particular scenario that
you may never encounter.

41
00:01:54.630 --> 00:01:57.190
But if you do, you will need applies.

42
00:01:57.190 --> 00:02:00.700
So when you do a join,
a join is made up of two parts, right.

43
00:02:00.700 --> 00:02:03.110
You've got a left table and a right table,

44
00:02:03.110 --> 00:02:06.180
and when you're doing inner joins you
don't really worry about that so much.

45
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:09.100
But when you're doing outer joins,
you've got left outer joins and

46
00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:10.990
right outer joins and full outer joins and

47
00:02:10.990 --> 00:02:14.030
now you're really thinking about
this whole left and right idea.

48
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:18.440
Well, those two tables that you're pulling
data from are technically independent.

49
00:02:18.440 --> 00:02:21.470
Well, I guess you could be doing
a self join against the same table but

50
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:24.980
SQL treats them as two different tables,
two independent tables.

51
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:26.410
And then it works out the data.

52
00:02:26.410 --> 00:02:28.440
It grabs data from one,
it grabs data from the other.

53
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:32.320
It does the comparison, merges them
together and you end up with your join.

54
00:02:33.930 --> 00:02:39.630
But, when we start to leverage something
like a common table expression,

55
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:41.430
things get a little bit weird.

56
00:02:42.430 --> 00:02:43.540
With a common table expression,

57
00:02:43.540 --> 00:02:46.820
instead of joining to a table
we're joining to a function.

58
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:50.350
And that function is
generating a table for us, and

59
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:52.710
that's being done kind of in real-time.

60
00:02:52.710 --> 00:02:58.140
And when we do that, there are certain
scenarios where it breaks the join.

61
00:02:58.140 --> 00:03:01.030
All of a sudden,
the join doesn't work, right.

62
00:03:01.030 --> 00:03:02.710
So that causes a bit of a problem.

63
00:03:02.710 --> 00:03:04.780
Now, when we look at a normal join,
actually,

64
00:03:04.780 --> 00:03:06.520
I've got an example here of a normal join.

65
00:03:06.520 --> 00:03:09.260
And this is from a previous episode.

66
00:03:09.260 --> 00:03:13.300
This is actually a triple-join,
I'm joining three different tables.

67
00:03:13.300 --> 00:03:17.480
So what I wanted, here, I'll run it,
and then I'll show you what I wanted.

68
00:03:17.480 --> 00:03:20.360
What I wanted in whatever
episode this was,

69
00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:23.010
I wanted to get a lot of
all of my salespeople.

70
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:26.460
And I wanted to know the salesperson's
first name and last name.

71
00:03:26.460 --> 00:03:29.750
And I wanted to know
the region they were in.

72
00:03:29.750 --> 00:03:33.090
Well, I've got a table called
Sales.SalesPerson, and

73
00:03:33.090 --> 00:03:36.290
it's got all of my salespeople in it,
sort of.

74
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:38.160
It's got their business entity ID.

75
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:39.530
It doesn't have their first name and

76
00:03:39.530 --> 00:03:43.260
last name,
that's found in the Person.Person table.

77
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:44.926
That's where I have to go to
get first name and last name.

78
00:03:44.926 --> 00:03:49.670
And while Sales.SalesPerson has
the territory ID, it doesn't have

79
00:03:49.670 --> 00:03:54.250
the name of the territory ID, I've got
to get that from Sales.SalesTerritory.

80
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:58.870
So my data is spread across tables and
I'm doing it join here to create that.

81
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:01.720
Now the join is actually
made up of two parts.

82
00:04:01.720 --> 00:04:06.400
Well, each join is made up of two but then
my query is made up of two separate joins.

83
00:04:06.400 --> 00:04:09.447
One, I'm combining Sale.SalesPerson and

84
00:04:09.447 --> 00:04:14.430
Person.Person and two,
I'm combining Sales.Salesperson

85
00:04:14.430 --> 00:04:17.390
with Sales.SalesTerritory.
>> Hm.

86
00:04:17.390 --> 00:04:18.890
>> To be able to link those

87
00:04:18.890 --> 00:04:20.600
together, as well.

88
00:04:20.600 --> 00:04:22.650
So kind of two different steps here.

89
00:04:22.650 --> 00:04:28.000
But in each of these,
I am joining to actual tables, right.

90
00:04:28.000 --> 00:04:29.090
And so I can run this.

91
00:04:29.090 --> 00:04:30.380
I can do ware statements on it.

92
00:04:30.380 --> 00:04:32.920
I can do all sorts of craziness to it,
and it's going to run.

93
00:04:32.920 --> 00:04:33.810
It's going to work just fine.

94
00:04:33.810 --> 00:04:35.920
This is exactly what
we've seen in previous

95
00:04:35.920 --> 00:04:37.150
shows.
>> Right.

96
00:04:37.150 --> 00:04:40.430
>> But if I were to decide that I wanted

97
00:04:40.430 --> 00:04:42.110
to simplify this.

98
00:04:42.110 --> 00:04:47.280
Right, if you've watched most of these
episodes, you've seen me join sales

99
00:04:47.280 --> 00:04:51.220
dot salesperson and person dot person.
>> We have done that more than

100
00:04:51.220 --> 00:04:52.280
a few times, haven't we?

101
00:04:52.280 --> 00:04:53.610
I mean, my goodness.
>> Yeah,

102
00:04:53.610 --> 00:04:55.990
yeah, probably in half our episodes.

103
00:04:55.990 --> 00:04:58.240
I'm always joining these,
these are easy tables to join,

104
00:04:58.240 --> 00:04:59.510
it's a great example, right?

105
00:04:59.510 --> 00:05:02.080
So maybe I finally break, I snap,
and I'm like, that's it, I am so

106
00:05:02.080 --> 00:05:04.590
sick and tired of joining this thing.
>> [LAUGH]

107
00:05:04.590 --> 00:05:05.300
>> Let's go ahead and

108
00:05:05.300 --> 00:05:06.620
write a function for it.

109
00:05:06.620 --> 00:05:10.510
And for now on I can just call
the function, and save myself some time.

110
00:05:10.510 --> 00:05:13.650
Well, if I do that, if I start to
convert part of this to a function,

111
00:05:13.650 --> 00:05:18.190
like this first join, I could then go and
say okay, now that's a function.

112
00:05:18.190 --> 00:05:22.050
So instead of having to join
three tables I could just join

113
00:05:22.050 --> 00:05:26.750
the sales.sales.territory
table with my function and

114
00:05:26.750 --> 00:05:28.130
combine it and get the information.

115
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:32.460
But now that I'm doing that, that function
becomes a common table expression.

116
00:05:32.460 --> 00:05:35.630
It is a kind of version

117
00:05:35.630 --> 00:05:39.900
of the data that I've got being expressed
in a different way through this function.

118
00:05:39.900 --> 00:05:45.020
And now I'm exposed to the little
possible scenario where

119
00:05:45.020 --> 00:05:48.170
my join might break if I
start to use a function.

120
00:05:48.170 --> 00:05:52.620
So that's kind of what we need to be aware
of as we go through what we planned and

121
00:05:52.620 --> 00:05:54.080
we designed.
>> Well then,

122
00:05:54.080 --> 00:05:58.090
should we not use a function?
>> We certainly don't have to, right?

123
00:05:58.090 --> 00:05:59.400
I could say, I'll suffer.

124
00:05:59.400 --> 00:06:00.010
I'll just keep doing it.

125
00:06:00.010 --> 00:06:01.460
It's copy and paste work.

126
00:06:01.460 --> 00:06:03.110
It's not the end of the world, right?

127
00:06:03.110 --> 00:06:06.695
But you hate to give up on
something just because there's this

128
00:06:06.695 --> 00:06:09.310

129
00:06:09.310 --> 00:06:12.840
In fact, most of the time
the functions that you write aren't

130
00:06:12.840 --> 00:06:15.630
going to cause a problem at all,
right, and it's going to work.

131
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:17.040
So let me show you that.

132
00:06:17.040 --> 00:06:19.660
We'll show you one that works, before we

133
00:06:19.660 --> 00:06:21.170
start talking about how to fix it.
>> Okay.

134
00:06:21.170 --> 00:06:22.500
>> So let's say that

135
00:06:22.500 --> 00:06:23.300
I decide I want to do that.

136
00:06:23.300 --> 00:06:26.370
I want to take the sales.salesperson and
person.person join, and

137
00:06:26.370 --> 00:06:28.670
I want to make a function that does that.

138
00:06:28.670 --> 00:06:32.500
So in order to do that,
first off I need to create the function.

139
00:06:32.500 --> 00:06:36.790
So let me fire up a new query window

00:18:57.160 --> 00:18:59.646
So now, I'm calling the function and

369
00:18:59.646 --> 00:19:03.691
I'm expecting the function to
know what t.TerritoryID is.

370
00:19:03.691 --> 00:19:06.826
But the function never
touches the territory,

371
00:19:06.826 --> 00:19:09.630
the sales.sales.territory table.

372
00:19:09.630 --> 00:19:13.917
The function we wrote, which actually
I've got up here on the screen is,

373
00:19:13.917 --> 00:19:15.519
let me scroll back up to it.

374
00:19:15.519 --> 00:19:20.710
It is touching sales.salesperson and
it's touching person.person.

375
00:19:20.710 --> 00:19:24.527
Now if I was referencing
sales.salesterritory inside of this

376
00:19:24.527 --> 00:19:26.835
function, it would know what it was.

377
00:19:26.835 --> 00:19:32.037
But since I'm not, when I give it that
sales.salesterritory.territoryID,

378
00:19:32.037 --> 00:19:34.790
it doesn't know what to do with it.

379
00:19:34.790 --> 00:19:37.742
It can't make sense out of it and
I get this error.

380
00:19:37.742 --> 00:19:40.500
This is the example where it fails,
where it breaks.

381
00:19:41.830 --> 00:19:47.083
And so this situation right here
in the olden days would mean,

382
00:19:47.083 --> 00:19:49.521
I just wanna use a function.

383
00:19:49.521 --> 00:19:54.280
I'll go ahead and
I will just do manual joints.

384
00:19:55.380 --> 00:19:58.890
But in transact SQL,
we can do an apply and

385
00:19:58.890 --> 00:20:02.990
an APPLY can solve that problem
in this particular scenario.

386
00:20:02.990 --> 00:20:05.145
So you don't always have to use APPLY.

387
00:20:05.145 --> 00:20:09.083
But if you run into this situation right
here where you're trying to pass a more

388
00:20:09.083 --> 00:20:13.319
complex dataset in and you get a multipart
identifier error like this where it can't

389
00:20:13.319 --> 00:20:17.079
be bound, you're trying to hand
information from one side of the join over

390
00:20:17.079 --> 00:20:20.240
to the other side when
the other side is a function.

391
00:20:20.240 --> 00:20:22.826
That's where APPLY comes in and
solves the problem.

392
00:20:22.826 --> 00:20:26.430
So this is not a routine command
that everybody needs to know.

393
00:20:26.430 --> 00:20:28.652
That's why it wasn't in
the basic part of this show, but

394
00:20:28.652 --> 00:20:30.889
it is something that an advanced
user would need to know.

395
00:20:30.889 --> 00:20:34.160
Because this doesn't mean
let's abandon the functions.

396
00:20:34.160 --> 00:20:37.160
It means yeah, in this scenario,
I need to use and APPLY and

397
00:20:37.160 --> 00:20:39.743
that will help me fix this.
>> So functions are useful, but

398
00:20:39.743 --> 00:20:40.753
they can break joints.

399
00:20:40.753 --> 00:20:45.107
So how do we make it work?
>> So if we wanna make it work,

400
00:20:45.107 --> 00:20:46.613
we're gonna use APPLY.

401
00:20:46.613 --> 00:20:49.692
And APPLY is actually
kind of a neat thing,

402
00:20:49.692 --> 00:20:54.920
because what it does is it allows us
to make our queries even more simple.

403
00:20:54.920 --> 00:20:56.729
Because applies are easier than joints.

404
00:20:56.729 --> 00:21:00.898
So if I wanna take this one, I've got,
well, first off, I've got two choices,

405
00:21:00.898 --> 00:21:04.090
cuz there's actually two types of applies.

406
00:21:04.090 --> 00:21:08.120
The normal apply that most of us are gonna
do is what's called a CROSS APPLY.

407
00:21:08.120 --> 00:21:10.612
So cross, C-R-O-S-S.

408
00:21:10.612 --> 00:21:12.037
Apply, A-P-P-L-Y.

409
00:21:12.037 --> 00:21:16.268
And when we do a CROSS APPLY,
it's like a standard INNER JOIN.

410
00:21:16.268 --> 00:21:19.846
I'm going to be combining two sets of
data yhe same way an inter join would.

411
00:21:19.846 --> 00:21:22.710
It's just I need to be able to exchange
information between the two, so

412
00:21:22.710 --> 00:21:24.540
they recognize each other's information.

413
00:21:25.960 --> 00:21:30.190
An outer apply is like an OUTER JOIN.

414
00:21:30.190 --> 00:21:34.210
A CROSS APPLY doesn't include null values,
if something doesn't match,

415
00:21:34.210 --> 00:21:35.580
it doesn't get returned.

416
00:21:35.580 --> 00:21:38.170
A CROSS APPLY returns
things that don't match.

417
00:21:38.170 --> 00:21:40.625
Same thing with a join, an INNER JOIN.

418
00:21:40.625 --> 00:21:43.250
It doesn't return no values,
things that don't match.

419
00:21:43.250 --> 00:21:48.200
And outer joints does and then you
pick left, right or full outer joint.

420
00:21:48.200 --> 00:21:50.972
With applies, you don't have left,
right and outer.

421
00:21:50.972 --> 00:21:55.102
With applies, you have the CROSS APPLY
which is like an inner joint and

422
00:21:55.102 --> 00:21:58.500
you have the OUTER APPLY which
is like a full OUTER JOINs.

423
00:21:58.500 --> 00:22:00.494
So those are the two that we've got.

424
00:22:00.494 --> 00:22:03.682
So I would need to take this query and
rewrite it a bit, but

425
00:22:03.682 --> 00:22:06.500
I do need to make that
choice which do I wanna do.

426
00:22:06.500 --> 00:22:08.266
Well, I was doing INNER JOINs.

427
00:22:08.266 --> 00:22:12.350
So I'm gonna use a CROSS JOIN to
be able to solve this problem.

428
00:22:12.350 --> 00:22:15.602
A CROSS APPLY to solve the problem and
then we'll be able to get this query

429
00:22:15.602 --> 00:22:16.568
working.
>> So Don,

430
00:22:16.568 --> 00:22:20.374
is the syntax the same as a join?
>> It's similar, but

431
00:22:20.374 --> 00:22:22.487
actually it is a little bit easier.

432
00:22:22.487 --> 00:22:26.806
When we do a join,
we have to specify that the two tables and

433
00:22:26.806 --> 00:22:31.970
we have to specify what the relationship
is between those tables.

434
00:22:31.970 --> 00:22:33.677
So that it understands
what we're working with.

435
00:22:33.677 --> 00:22:39.630
Well, when we do an APPLY, we actually
don't have to specify the relationship.

436
00:22:39.630 --> 00:22:44.266
You can leave that out, because the APPLY
will take care of finding the relationship

437
00:22:44.266 --> 00:22:45.909
and mapping that data for me.

438
00:22:45.909 --> 00:22:48.930
So I'm gonna leave my select the same.

439
00:22:48.930 --> 00:22:51.615
I'm pulling from
sales.sales territory as T.

440
00:22:51.615 --> 00:22:53.340
I'll leave that the same.

441
00:22:53.340 --> 00:22:58.671
But then instead of joining on that
function, I'm gonna come in and

442
00:22:58.671 --> 00:23:03.643
I'm gonna say that I'm going to
CROSS APPLY on that function.

443
00:23:03.643 --> 00:23:05.927
And now, I specify the function.

444
00:23:05.927 --> 00:23:09.060
I'm providing t to a territory ID,
I would give it an alias of s.

445
00:23:10.130 --> 00:23:14.350
Now when I do that, what it's
really doing is not a normal join.

446
00:23:14.350 --> 00:23:18.209
It's gonna take that function and
it's gonna run it once or

447
00:23:18.209 --> 00:23:22.993
each row as it goes through in a process
is this sales.sales territory and

448
00:23:22.993 --> 00:23:27.468
that's why the function will know
where the territory ID column is,

449
00:23:27.468 --> 00:23:31.380
cuz it's going row by row
where the process is through.

450
00:23:31.380 --> 00:23:34.823
So when you're doing iterative query,
this kind of solves it.

451
00:23:34.823 --> 00:23:38.527
And I didn't mention it earlier,
but correlated queries.

452
00:23:38.527 --> 00:23:41.320
If you went back and
watched our subqueries episode and

453
00:23:41.320 --> 00:23:45.511
I talked about correlated queries and
how they aren't usually very efficient and

454
00:23:45.511 --> 00:23:49.517
they cause problems, well, this is one
of the problems I was talking about and

455
00:23:49.517 --> 00:23:52.460
a CROSS APPLY would actually
fix that correlated query.

456
00:23:52.460 --> 00:23:55.219
There are times where you need
to iterate through each row.

457
00:23:55.219 --> 00:23:57.256
And so that's what I'm telling it to do.

458
00:23:57.256 --> 00:24:01.900
Now when I do this I'm
feeding it every territory.

459
00:24:01.900 --> 00:24:05.617
And so it's gonna run in
the most optimal form possible.

460
00:24:05.617 --> 00:24:09.900
I do need to add, I don' thave to but
I want to add in order by.

461
00:24:09.900 --> 00:24:12.433
So the records will be near each other.

462
00:24:12.433 --> 00:24:15.110
It's gonna go in row
order from top to bottom.

463
00:24:15.110 --> 00:24:19.815
So I won't necessarily know the order
I'm gonna get this information back in.

464
00:24:19.815 --> 00:24:23.348
By applying an order by it'll just
make it look a little neater, okay.

465
00:24:23.348 --> 00:24:26.326
Now, once I've got that in here,
I've got that I'm pulling from

466
00:24:26.326 --> 00:24:29.380
Sales.SalesTerritory, that's
got an alias of T.

467
00:24:29.380 --> 00:24:36.373
I'm doing a cross-apply on this function,
the Sales.GetRegionalSalesPeople.

468
00:24:36.373 --> 00:24:38.880
And then I'm providing you
that territorial ID and

469
00:24:38.880 --> 00:24:40.170
giving it the order bias.

470
00:24:40.170 --> 00:24:44.365
So our query is a little bit smaller
now then it was with the joined and

471
00:24:44.365 --> 00:24:46.801
it should be a little bit easier for us.

472
00:24:46.801 --> 00:24:50.711
Now I do have some red underlines
on here which this window knew

473
00:24:50.711 --> 00:24:55.010
about the function and now it's
like it forgot about the function.

474
00:24:55.010 --> 00:24:57.717
So everything that's referencing that
function it got me a red underline; I'm

475
00:24:57.717 --> 00:24:58.961
gonna run it and see if I get an error.

476
00:24:58.961 --> 00:25:01.500
I might have missed a period or

477
00:25:01.500 --> 00:25:06.397
So let me run that and no, all right
IntelliSense isn't refreshing for me.

478
00:25:06.397 --> 00:25:10.880
But when it runs I didn't get
a multi-part identifier error, did I?

479
00:25:10.880 --> 00:25:16.316
This time it worked and I didn't just
get territory one I got every territory.

480
00:25:16.316 --> 00:25:20.541
Here's territory one followed by each of
the remaining territories after that two,

481
00:25:20.541 --> 00:25:23.898
three, four, five, all the way

482
00:25:23.898 --> 00:25:28.384
And I can see J Pack right there

483
00:25:28.384 --> 00:25:32.609
So I didn't have to say I'm not gonna do
a function I just had to say all right,

484
00:25:32.609 --> 00:25:36.119
I'm gonna use this function and
yeah, I'm gonna get an error so

485
00:25:36.119 --> 00:25:39.130
let me do a cross supply
instead of doing a join.

486
00:25:39.130 --> 00:25:42.189
And it solves the problem,
get the information I want and

00:25:42.189 --> 00:25:46.351
now I'm ready to rock.
>> Can you give us an example of

an outer apply?
>> Yes I can.

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

00:25:49.368 --> 00:25:50.979
>> So with an outer apply I had to

00:25:50.979 --> 00:25:54.147
think about it for
a second because with an outer apply.

If there's something that doesn't match it

00:25:56.450 --> 00:25:59.480
gets left out, okay.
Well right now everything has a match.

00:25:59.480 --> 00:26:04.370
I have ten regions, and every region

00:26:04.370 --> 00:26:06.265
So they're all coming back, all right.

00:26:06.265 --> 00:26:10.988
So if I wanna show you guys an example
of an outer apply I could say well,

you just change from cross to outer and

498
00:26:14.484 --> 00:26:18.359
Then I can run that, there's all

499
00:26:18.359 --> 00:26:21.441
But the problem is since
all of my regions have

00:26:21.441 --> 00:26:24.490
sales people that data is no different.

00:26:24.490 --> 00:26:26.316
So how do we know that it actually works?

So let me give you an example.

Let's say that Jae Pak here
he's working in the UK and

00:26:31.798 --> 00:26:35.584
he's just doing a great job but

00:26:35.584 --> 00:26:39.549
He's by himself and I say you know
what I thinkIi'm gonna move Jay

So I'm gonna move him over there and

that way I can close down the building
UK to save a little money or what.

00:26:48.363 --> 00:26:54.140
Now when I move Jay out the United Kingdom

00:26:54.140 --> 00:26:58.052
So when we're iterating through

it's not gonna find anybody from the UK,

00:27:00.370 --> 00:27:02.160
that's a null value.

00:27:02.160 --> 00:27:05.396

515
00:27:05.396 --> 00:27:08.340
So I'm gonna put that
back to a cross-apply.

516
00:27:08.340 --> 00:27:12.979
And it would leave it out and outer apply
would include it, so let me transfer Jay.

00:27:12.979 --> 00:27:17.765
So we're gonna give him

00:27:17.765 --> 00:27:22.322
So let me do a update

00:27:22.322 --> 00:27:26.631
I will set the territory id to let's see,

France is 7, so

00:27:31.820 --> 00:27:39.177
Where is this entity id is equal to and

All right, so

00:27:42.737 --> 00:27:44.751
So now he's moved over to France,

00:27:44.751 --> 00:27:46.273
fastest move ever.

00:27:46.273 --> 00:27:47.266
>> And now when I go back and

00:27:47.266 --> 00:27:50.080
I run this query,
I'm still doing a cross apply, right.

00:27:50.080 --> 00:27:54.832
So when I do the cross apply I

00:27:54.832 --> 00:27:58.342
And so when I come down here and

did I get the wrong person?

They there are, Jae Pak,
289, he's in France now.

531
00:28:03.259 --> 00:28:03.954

00:28:03.954 --> 00:28:06.517
>> And if I scroll down to the UK I can't

00:28:06.517 --> 00:28:09.050
cuz it's not there, right.

00:28:09.050 --> 00:28:13.535
When the cross supply runs,
if there's not a match it leaves it off.

00:28:13.535 --> 00:28:17.016
And so there is no 10 on this,

00:28:17.016 --> 00:28:21.474
I can't scroll down any further,

If I stretch this window

00:28:26.320 --> 00:28:29.880
So hard to get your mouse right on

00:28:29.880 --> 00:28:30.573
there we go.

00:28:30.573 --> 00:28:33.281
I can see them all and
there's no more room for

541
00:28:33.281 --> 00:28:36.240
me to scroll down,

542
00:28:36.240 --> 00:28:41.886
So if I change my query to be a outer

00:28:41.886 --> 00:28:46.944
apply, now it's gonna run.

00:28:46.944 --> 00:28:52.160
It's gonna see that there's nobody in

00:28:52.160 --> 00:28:54.818
So if I scroll down, there's the UK.

I see United Kingdom and

So if that's what I want,

The rest of the syntax is entirely
the same and unlike a join I don't have to

00:29:07.042 --> 00:29:11.995
think about left or right, or full outer

00:29:11.995 --> 00:29:15.682
Because it's going each row as it

So there it is, it's still on

00:29:20.522 --> 00:29:23.168
thanks to apply.

00:29:24.455 --> 00:29:27.329

well this was another example of

And if you just know the tools that are

make use of that technology and

00:29:41.760 --> 00:29:44.912
So apply is not going to be

00:29:44.912 --> 00:29:46.671

00:29:46.671 --> 00:29:48.113
>> In my mind I always think okay,

00:29:48.113 --> 00:29:49.727
do I need to iterate through data?

I'll probably need to do an apply,

00:29:51.790 --> 00:29:53.450
Or if I'm just writing a join and

00:29:53.450 --> 00:29:57.141
I ran into one of these situations

00:29:57.141 --> 00:30:00.665
can't be bound error I say that's

00:30:00.665 --> 00:30:03.765
If I'm not neither of those two scenarios

00:30:03.765 --> 00:30:06.400
I'll just automatically right join it,

00:30:06.400 --> 00:30:11.616
Or I create views that act as that data

00:30:11.616 --> 00:30:13.180
So those are all options.

572
00:30:13.180 --> 00:30:15.158
But when we're working with functions,

when we're in these scenarios apply

in the bottom of the toolbox that

And your really miss it

episodes.description: n this episode, Don explains how we can work with XML data inside of Transact-SQL. He demonstrates how to configure the output of a query to be formatted as XML. He then demonstrates how to use XML data as the input for a query.
episodes.title: Working with XML

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how we can work with JSON data inside of Transact-SQL. He demonstrates how to configure the output of a query to be formatted as JSON. He then demonstrates how to use JSON data as the input for a query.
episodes.title: Working with JSON

we are working with JSON,

17
00:00:36.201 --> 00:00:40.970
which is not a third person on this show,
