18
00:00:40.970 --> 00:00:44.948
It's a way of outputting data that is
kind of like the hot buzz word right now-

19
00:00:44.948 --> 00:00:45.551
>> Yep.

20
00:00:45.551 --> 00:00:47.538
>> That has dethroned XML.

21
00:00:47.538 --> 00:00:50.820
So we're gonna be looking at how we
can work with our SQL server and

22
00:00:50.820 --> 00:00:54.118
use Transact-SQL that handle
queries that deal with JSON data.

23
00:00:54.118 --> 00:00:57.973
Data stored as JSON or
creating data to be represented as JSON,

24
00:00:57.973 --> 00:01:01.190
which we can see all that
right here in this episode.

25
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:04.205
>> So Don, for
the unititiated, what is JSON?

26
00:01:04.205 --> 00:01:06.828
And well, why should we care about it?

27
00:01:06.828 --> 00:01:12.889
>> All right, so well the acronym, my
artist was the JavaScript Object Notation.

28
00:01:12.889 --> 00:01:13.496
>> Right.
>> And

29
00:01:13.496 --> 00:01:16.201
what that should tell you is a few things,
right?

30
00:01:16.201 --> 00:01:19.110
So JavaScript,
that's where this came from.

31
00:01:19.110 --> 00:01:21.062
And the world, the World Wide Web,

32
00:01:21.062 --> 00:01:24.851
especially the Internet is kind of
powered by JavaScript right now.

33
00:01:24.851 --> 00:01:29.111
It is a rare, rare website that you can go
to that isn't using JavaScript to render

34
00:01:29.111 --> 00:01:31.422
all of its elements in
the right positions.

35
00:01:31.422 --> 00:01:33.660
>> True story.
>> And do all sorts of fun stuff.

36
00:01:33.660 --> 00:01:37.635
If you ever wonder, turn off JavaScript
in your web browser and see what happens.

37
00:01:37.635 --> 00:01:38.633
>> It's fun.

38
00:01:38.633 --> 00:01:39.744
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, very,

39
00:01:39.744 --> 00:01:43.810
very few pages function at all,
so really, really relevant.

40
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:48.272
And in JavaScript, you got these web
apps than neither data from someone.

41
00:01:48.272 --> 00:01:51.719
And so they created this object notation,

42
00:01:51.719 --> 00:01:55.366
a way to present what's
tabular data in SQL.

43
00:01:55.366 --> 00:02:00.139
But basically these attributes and their
values, the information that we can pull

44
00:02:00.139 --> 00:02:05.400
from a database, built to represent it in
a simple way the JavaScript can handle.

45
00:02:05.400 --> 00:02:08.790
And so they created this
text-based format called JSON.

46
00:02:08.790 --> 00:02:10.341
Very, very similar to XML, right?

47
00:02:10.341 --> 00:02:11.780
The Extensible Markup Language.

48
00:02:11.780 --> 00:02:17.696
We saw XML in a previous episode,
it was the big buzzword in the year 2000.

49
00:02:17.696 --> 00:02:20.886
And really the first
decade of the century, but

50
00:02:20.886 --> 00:02:25.930
now not many people write new things for
XML, instead JSON is the way to go.

51
00:02:25.930 --> 00:02:29.666
And not just with JavaScript,
with all sorts of language now,

52
00:02:29.666 --> 00:02:33.980
most programming languages have
libraries to support the JSON format.

53
00:02:33.980 --> 00:02:35.714
So this is become pretty ubiquitous.

54
00:02:35.714 --> 00:02:38.393
So Microsoft,
recognizing this is important,

55
00:02:38.393 --> 00:02:42.721
have introduced features inside of
Transact-SQL, so we can work with this.

56
00:02:42.721 --> 00:02:45.850
Now JSON is an industry standard.

57
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:50.777
It's not an ANSI standard yet,
but it is RFC 8259 with the IEEE.

58
00:02:50.777 --> 00:02:54.914
So that means that if you're receiving
JSON-formatted data from a third party

59
00:02:54.914 --> 00:02:58.460
company, the odds are you'll
be able to handle it in SQL.

60
00:02:58.460 --> 00:03:00.174
And in SQL if we generate JSON data,

61
00:03:00.174 --> 00:03:04.078
the odds are we can hand that to somebody
else and they'll be able to handle that.

62
00:03:04.078 --> 00:03:06.151
So it makes for a great language for

63
00:03:06.151 --> 00:03:09.663
handing off information
between the different systems.

64
00:03:09.663 --> 00:03:14.360
If you look at a JSON file or
the JSON data, it's really pretty simple.

65
00:03:14.360 --> 00:03:16.671
You've got attributes and values, right?

66
00:03:16.671 --> 00:03:20.814
So I might have first name,
Don, last name, Pezet, right?

67
00:03:20.814 --> 00:03:24.439
[INAUDIBLE] And they're represented in a
certain format that the computer expects,

68
00:03:24.439 --> 00:03:25.620
and it can look and define.

69
00:03:25.620 --> 00:03:30.469
And it even does basic data typing,
although the data typing it doesn't say

70
00:03:30.469 --> 00:03:33.588
like, as int or as and
variable character 50.

71
00:03:33.588 --> 00:03:36.390
It just says, hey, if it's in
double quotes then it's a texture,

72
00:03:36.390 --> 00:03:39.630
if it's not then it's a number,
and if it's a slash, it's escape.

73
00:03:39.630 --> 00:03:43.232
So it's some basic data typing that's
found inside of it to make sure that

74
00:03:43.232 --> 00:03:45.394
the information is represented properly.

75
00:03:45.394 --> 00:03:50.647
So that's basically what JSON is and
it is used by Node.js,

76
00:03:50.647 --> 00:03:54.870
by Docker,
just tons of different systems now,

77
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:58.683
that are supertech buzzwords in 2018.

78
00:03:58.683 --> 00:04:02.848
So that is something we definitely wanna
learn about cuz you'll likely use it out

79
00:04:02.848 --> 00:04:03.899
there in the field.

80
00:04:03.899 --> 00:04:07.287
>> So Don,
how do we use JSON with Transact-SQL?

81
00:04:07.287 --> 00:04:11.649
>> Well, Microsoft has some tools built
right in to Transact-SQL that we can take

82
00:04:11.649 --> 00:04:15.049
advantage of that will basically
represent our data as JSON.

83
00:04:15.049 --> 00:04:17.873
So let me show you a standard query,
so here I've got a query.

84
00:04:17.873 --> 00:04:22.375
And this is one we did in the previous
episode where I was trying to generate

85
00:04:22.375 --> 00:04:26.675
a list of my sales people and
how big a bonus they got last year, right?

86
00:04:26.675 --> 00:04:30.110
So this query, it's just a simple join,
nothing too fancy.

87
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:35.551
I'm ordering it by the bonus, until I can
see where Tsvi Reiter got a $6700 bonus.

88
00:04:35.551 --> 00:04:39.032
And it ticks all the way down to the
bottom of the list where there were a few

89
00:04:39.032 --> 00:04:41.731
employees who had nothing,
maybe they were new or bad.

90
00:04:41.731 --> 00:04:44.082
>> [LAUGH]
>> So one way or the other, so

91
00:04:44.082 --> 00:04:46.418
that's just a standard query.

92
00:04:46.418 --> 00:04:49.984
When it's returned to me,
it's returned as a SQL data table and

93
00:04:49.984 --> 00:04:52.040
the query analyzer can handle that.

94
00:04:52.040 --> 00:04:57.140
And if I have an application that's using
the SQL native client, it can handle that.

95
00:04:57.140 --> 00:04:59.130
But if I've got a third
party application or

96
00:04:59.130 --> 00:05:03.460
an in-house built application that's
expecting JSON, this doesn't help it.

97
00:05:03.460 --> 00:05:06.070
And I might not wanna go and
incorporate the SQL native library,

98
00:05:06.070 --> 00:05:07.400
cuz that's a lot of work.

99
00:05:07.400 --> 00:05:11.556
So I could just tell the SQL Server,
hey, can you give me this data and

100
00:05:11.556 --> 00:05:13.718
represent it as JSON data, right?

101
00:05:13.718 --> 00:05:18.089
Now to do that, the easiest example,
we can just add one line,

102
00:05:18.089 --> 00:05:20.081
at the very end of the query.

103
00:05:20.081 --> 00:05:22.480
So you write your query just like normal.

104
00:05:22.480 --> 00:05:28.138
You could then say FOR JSON AUTO, right?

105
00:05:28.138 --> 00:05:32.201
Which means look at the query and
use the tables that

106
00:05:32.201 --> 00:05:38.200
are referencing to automatically
format this data as JSON data.

107
00:05:38.200 --> 00:05:42.177
And normally when I run a query like this,
I would get a table back,

108
00:05:42.177 --> 00:05:46.599
but when I run this query I get a simple
block of information here, right?

109
00:05:46.599 --> 00:05:50.745
And if you watch the XML show, what I
did next is I would click on this and

110
00:05:50.745 --> 00:05:55.270
the query analyzer would give you a nice
big rendering of what that data was.

111
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:59.723
Unfortunately query analyzer doesn't
understand JSON, no, it's not yet,

112
00:05:59.723 --> 00:06:02.587
may be that will come in SQL 2019 or
something.

113
00:06:02.587 --> 00:06:04.174
>> [LAUGH]
>> But as since it doesn't,

114
00:06:04.174 --> 00:06:07.770
so if I click on it, it's not gonna
give me a nice neat representation like

115
00:06:07.770 --> 00:06:12.150
it did with XML, with like a little
collapsible trees and all that stuff.

116
00:06:12.150 --> 00:06:16.050
So what I normally end up doing is kind
of having to mess around with this data

117
00:06:16.050 --> 00:06:20.440
a little bit to get it where it's legible
and I can understand what I'm looking at.

118
00:06:20.440 --> 00:06:24.430
As you look at this information,
I can see business entity id for somebody.

119
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:28.549
And it goes along until I hit a comma for
the next person.

120
00:06:28.549 --> 00:06:30.497
And as I look at this information,

121
00:06:30.497 --> 00:06:33.799
actually that's a square
bracket here in the beginning.

122
00:06:34.910 --> 00:06:39.095
As I look at this information, it starts
to make a little more sense, or at least

123
00:06:39.095 --> 00:06:43.103
appears a little more clear once I start
breaking it up into multiple lines.

124
00:06:43.103 --> 00:06:48.130
You can see where each one of these lines
are representing one of my sales people.

125
00:06:48.130 --> 00:06:52.620
And inside of each line,
you can see an attribute and

126
00:06:52.620 --> 00:06:55.100
a value, BusinessEntityID is an attribute.

127
00:06:55.100 --> 00:06:55.660
What's the value?

128
00:06:55.660 --> 00:06:58.589
Well, for row one,
the value is 279, right?

129
00:06:58.589 --> 00:07:01.986
And then the bonus,
well that's an attribute, and the value?

130
00:07:01.986 --> 00:07:05.137
$6,700, now I don't know
that it's dollars, right?

131
00:07:05.137 --> 00:07:06.760
But I do know that that's a number.

132
00:07:06.760 --> 00:07:08.990
See, all the numbers are not in quotes.

133
00:07:08.990 --> 00:07:12.894
But then like first name,
Tsvi is in quotes.

134
00:07:12.894 --> 00:07:18.148
That's it telling, hey, it's a text stream
data type versus a numeric data type.

135
00:07:18.148 --> 00:07:22.019
So that's the basic typing that JSON does.

136
00:07:22.019 --> 00:07:24.659
But it's basically just
laying it out here and

137
00:07:24.659 --> 00:07:27.036
each entry has its own little value here.

138
00:07:27.036 --> 00:07:28.857
It's very, very similar to XML.

139
00:07:28.857 --> 00:07:31.054
And because it's just straight up text,

140
00:07:31.054 --> 00:07:34.398
it doesn't take a massively
complex library to support this.

141
00:07:34.398 --> 00:07:36.536
So I thought I only had 17 salespeople,

142
00:07:36.536 --> 00:07:38.867
I feel like I've been doing this for
an hour.

143
00:07:38.867 --> 00:07:40.929
>> [LAUGH]
>> So basically it lays it out here.

144
00:07:40.929 --> 00:07:45.392
And the information that's being returned
to me is all right there, right?

145
00:07:45.392 --> 00:07:49.756
And it's even indicating where some of
the data came from, like this p here.

146
00:07:49.756 --> 00:07:51.999
Notice how the p is preceded or

147
00:07:51.999 --> 00:07:56.678
followed by a square bracket
letting me know this is an array.

148
00:07:56.678 --> 00:08:01.473
Here's an array of all the data that
came from the person.person table.

149
00:08:01.473 --> 00:08:04.017
I got FirstName and
LastName from Person.Person.

150
00:08:04.017 --> 00:08:10.050
I got BusinessEntityID and Bonus, those
came from the Sales.Salesperson table.

151
00:08:10.050 --> 00:08:14.110
So it separated those so that I could see
that, that yeah this is data that came

152
00:08:14.110 --> 00:08:18.600
from two different places, and
it's denoted right in there.

153
00:08:18.600 --> 00:08:22.590
That's what JSON does,
tries to keep things simple, easy, and

154
00:08:22.590 --> 00:08:24.990
ready to be parsed by any application.

155
00:08:24.990 --> 00:08:27.750
>> So that's it just FOR
JSON AUTO and we're done?

156
00:08:28.750 --> 00:08:31.799
>> Maybe, so yeah, technically
you take that query that I wrote.

157
00:08:31.799 --> 00:08:34.024
>> [LAUGH]
>> Like, all I did was add FOR

158
00:08:34.024 --> 00:08:35.260
JSON AUTO and we were done.

159
00:08:35.260 --> 00:08:37.249
But there are some things that
me might wanna tweak, right,

160
00:08:37.249 --> 00:08:39.240
there's some options and
stuff that we might wanna modify.

161
00:08:39.240 --> 00:08:41.279
And in fact if you were looking
at my information here,

162
00:08:42.340 --> 00:08:46.020
I've got a square bracket at the beginning
and a square bracket at the end.

163
00:08:46.020 --> 00:08:52.070
Okay, that means that this entire data
set is being provided as an array,

164
00:08:52.070 --> 00:08:53.370
as a single array.

165
00:08:53.370 --> 00:08:55.840
Now in your application,
you might take that array and

166
00:08:55.840 --> 00:08:59.820
store it into a variable and then start
to work with it from there, right.

167
00:08:59.820 --> 00:09:02.160
But in your application,
you might not want it as an array.

168
00:09:02.160 --> 00:09:05.680
So we might tell it not to include
those square brackets, and

169
00:09:05.680 --> 00:09:06.770
just give me the rest of the data.

170
00:09:06.770 --> 00:09:10.385
Now each one is its own entity
instead of being one big array.

171
00:09:10.385 --> 00:09:12.210
My application would have to expect that.

172
00:09:12.210 --> 00:09:14.100
But if I wanna tweak that,
that's not so hard.

173
00:09:14.100 --> 00:09:19.154
I just come back here to the FOR
JSON AUTO, and

174
00:09:19.154 --> 00:09:26.087
I add a comma, and
then I just say WITHOUT_ARRAY_WRAPPER.

175
00:09:26.087 --> 00:09:29.560
And when I run that,
I'm gonna get the same data back.

176
00:09:29.560 --> 00:09:33.660
But if you look, you can see where
that square bracket is gone, right.

177
00:09:33.660 --> 00:09:38.880
So if I look at it right now,
I start with a curly brace, right.

178
00:09:38.880 --> 00:09:43.260
And if I comment out that
WITHOUT_ARRAY_WRAPPER and

179
00:09:43.260 --> 00:09:48.200
I run it again, I can see where that
square bracket has come back again, right.

180
00:09:48.200 --> 00:09:51.070
So I'm just telling it whether or
not I want it to be in an array, or

181
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:52.190
I don't want it to be in a array.

182
00:09:52.190 --> 00:09:53.730
I'll take mine out of an array.

183
00:09:53.730 --> 00:09:57.450
But that's an example of one
modifier that we might wanna change.

184
00:09:57.450 --> 00:10:02.321
So FOR JSON AUTO might be enough, or
we might need to tweak it a little bit to

185
00:10:02.321 --> 00:10:07.680
kind of get that working the way that we
want it to come in and include everything.

186
00:10:08.910 --> 00:10:14.830
Another example, let's see that was for
removing the array wrapper.

187
00:10:15.910 --> 00:10:17.530
Null values, right.

188
00:10:17.530 --> 00:10:19.460
I might want to show null values.

189
00:10:19.460 --> 00:10:22.500
And I don't have a whole lot
of null values in mine, so

190
00:10:22.500 --> 00:10:25.370
I didn't really see a great example there.

191
00:10:25.370 --> 00:10:29.910
But if I want to see some null
values on mine, I could go in it and

192
00:10:29.910 --> 00:10:33.110
blank one out, and come and
see that data, right?

193
00:10:33.110 --> 00:10:38.610
So, for example, let me jump over to
another window, here I'll take this one.

194
00:10:38.610 --> 00:10:45.940
And I'm going to, let's, I'm gonna
null out somebody's bonus, right?

195
00:10:45.940 --> 00:10:48.430
Right now if somebody didn't get
a bonus they have a zero in there.

196
00:10:48.430 --> 00:10:52.390
But let's say that I just nulled
their bonus altogether, right?

197
00:10:52.390 --> 00:10:55.310
Well that column doesn't allow null so
I need to change that real quick.

198
00:10:55.310 --> 00:11:01.945
So I'll do an ALTER TABLE,
Sales.Salesperson, ALTER COLUMN.

199
00:11:04.654 --> 00:11:10.364
I'm gonna alter the Bonus column to be
a money data type that allows nulls,

200
00:11:10.364 --> 00:11:11.730
all right.

201
00:11:11.730 --> 00:11:17.450
So ALTER TABLE with only one s,
and that should fix that.

202
00:11:17.450 --> 00:11:18.380
There, all right.

203
00:11:18.380 --> 00:11:20.670
So now I have allowed nulls.

204
00:11:20.670 --> 00:11:25.870
So I can take somebody's bonus and
I can go through and I can blank it out.

205
00:11:26.870 --> 00:11:32.929
So Sales.SalesPerson,
we'll set Bonus equal to NULL,

206
00:11:32.929 --> 00:11:37.381
WHERE, BusinessIdentityID equals and,

207
00:11:37.381 --> 00:11:42.218
whose bonus do we want
to take away today Zach?

208
00:11:42.218 --> 00:11:44.550
>> [LAUGH] I will not say.

209
00:11:44.550 --> 00:11:47.060
>> Let's do the leader here
because he's on my screen.

210
00:11:47.060 --> 00:11:48.194
>> Okay.
>> So Tavi Reiter,

211
00:11:48.194 --> 00:11:52.310
he's got that big bonus, $6,700,
he's BusinessEntityID 279.

212
00:11:52.310 --> 00:11:56.141
So, I'm gonna knock out his bonus,
teach him to win.

213
00:11:56.141 --> 00:11:58.770
And [LAUGH] there we go.

214
00:11:58.770 --> 00:12:01.604
So I'll run that, and
now he's got a nulled out bonus,

215
00:12:01.604 --> 00:12:04.679
which I could probably see,
well here we'll just go back and

216
00:12:04.679 --> 00:12:08.200
we'll just query it again and
we'll see it in the JSON data.

217
00:12:08.200 --> 00:12:12.235
So normally when I run just
like I've got right here.

218
00:12:12.235 --> 00:12:14.050
>> Mm-hm.
>> Null values will get left out.

219
00:12:14.050 --> 00:12:17.156
So see our BusinessEntityID
279 is first and that's Tavi.

220
00:12:17.156 --> 00:12:17.850
>> Mm-hm.

221
00:12:17.850 --> 00:12:22.400
>> If I run this query again,
BusinessEntityID 286 is first, right?

222
00:12:22.400 --> 00:12:25.377
>> Okay.
>> Tavi is gone, he had a null value so

223
00:12:25.377 --> 00:12:28.140

And when I go in and take a look at these

00:18:42.211 --> 00:18:46.829

00:18:46.829 --> 00:18:47.947

The hardest part on JSON's input is

So maybe it's coming from a text file,

00:18:54.870 --> 00:18:58.730

00:18:58.730 --> 00:19:03.400
So we have the Xquery functions,

00:19:03.400 --> 00:19:06.850
reach inside of text, and

00:19:06.850 --> 00:19:08.620
And we can leverage that

00:19:10.800 --> 00:19:13.250

00:19:18.280 --> 00:19:22.080

00:21:04.410 --> 00:21:09.240
Quick bit of advice here,

00:21:09.240 --> 00:21:12.900
And Unicode characters are really

00:21:12.900 --> 00:21:15.580

00:21:15.580 --> 00:21:17.780
SQL doesn't default to Unicode.

00:21:17.780 --> 00:21:22.000
So if I leave it just like it is,
Unicode characters might be a problem.

379
00:21:22.000 --> 00:21:26.630
So whenever you ingest JSON,
it's a good idea to stick a capital N,

380
00:21:26.630 --> 00:21:28.600
right before the text field.

381
00:21:28.600 --> 00:21:32.005
And that let's it know that you're gonna
support Unicode characters inside of it,

00:21:32.005 --> 00:21:32.880

00:21:32.880 --> 00:21:36.520
We used to not worry about this stuff but
in today's day and age where everybody is

384
00:21:36.520 --> 00:21:39.630
in international business,
you really need to think about that.

385
00:21:39.630 --> 00:21:41.580
So I'm gonna stick that N
right at the beginning.

386
00:21:41.580 --> 00:21:44.860
So that's what that means is I'm gonna
be accepting Unicode characters.

00:21:44.860 --> 00:21:45.460

00:22:41.600 --> 00:22:44.150
Now, when I pull it up like this though

00:22:45.190 --> 00:22:47.600
it's not represented the way

Obviously it did access the jsondata and

00:22:53.100 --> 00:22:55.450

00:22:55.450 --> 00:22:59.620
But the way it's represented is a lot

00:22:59.620 --> 00:23:02.350
And the main reason is the data types,

00:23:03.640 --> 00:23:06.240
In JSON data typing is really simple.

00:23:06.240 --> 00:23:09.520
You have text versus numbers, right?

00:23:09.520 --> 00:23:13.410
In SQL we have eight

eight different types of numbers and

00:23:16.840 --> 00:23:21.390
So what it's showing me here, is on

00:23:21.390 --> 00:23:22.940

00:23:22.940 --> 00:23:27.350
And then based on what JSON was telling

00:23:27.350 --> 00:23:30.010
If it's a one it was a string,

Which is the loose data type, right?

00:23:32.570 --> 00:23:35.730
So that's what it's giving me back here so

00:23:35.730 --> 00:23:40.130
Well, that means that just querying it

Right here.

00:26:33.391 --> 00:26:36.530

00:26:36.530 --> 00:26:39.570
LastName, there.

00:26:39.570 --> 00:26:41.240

00:26:42.390 --> 00:26:44.950
So by doing this,

00:26:44.950 --> 00:26:48.680

00:26:48.680 --> 00:26:50.750

00:26:50.750 --> 00:26:53.400

00:26:53.400 --> 00:26:59.390
And when I run that, now the data

00:27:01.160 --> 00:27:03.240
I could have.
